courses.description: (UGEC1016 is double-coded with ARCH1320.) The course provides a general outline to architecture. The aim is to introduce architecture as a cultural phenomenon. The course will increase the student's awareness of the built environment as it exists all around. It examines a variety of spatial experiences encountered in exemplary places and buildings. The scope of the course is not limited to buildings alone, but includes cities and landscapes as extensions of architecture. The course introduces a range of topics, including the historical, symbolic, aesthetic, functional, cultural and green aspects of architecture.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEC1016 is double-coded with ARCH1320. 
Not for Architectural Studies Majors; and students who have taken ARCH1320[1330] or 2111.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
To comprehend the discipline of architecture in relation to the broader contexts of history, culture and civilization.
To remember the key concepts and some significant works of architecture.
To analyze the relationship between architecture, city, and landscape, cultural memory.
To comprehend the design and building process of architecture.
To enrich students with direct dialogue with the architects/designers who have created the architecture.
To apply skills for clear expression in written and oral presentations.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course introduces a number of topics related to the conceptual and aesthetic aspects of architecture. Among the topics introduced will be the following:
Introduction of Architectural Vocabulary
A Brief History of Hong Kong Architecture
Architecture through the Ages
Architecture and Culture
Architecture and Heritage
Green Architecture
The Design Process
The Building Process and Architectural Practice
China New Architecture
The course format involves regular lecture sessions, with occasional discussion sessions and short group presentations. The course may also include occasional field trips/excursions to selected sites in
Hong Kong
as well as some workshop exercises.

courses.title: History of England: From Nation to Empire
courses.description: This course provides a framework of the history of England for nearly two thousand years. It is hoped that through this course students will be able to broaden their knowledge of some key aspects of the history of England integrated into SDGs themes.Students, thus, will be more connected to the modern world by understanding the past since some important ideas and inventions are legacies from England. Students will discuss from different perspectives of 'England' in this course, such as political development, intellectual ideology, cultural influences and transformation of society in modern Britain. For example, the concept of 'democracy' is based on the constitution movement and it still affects the modern world (#16 Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions)The industrial revolution and the changing the modern consumption. (#8 Decent Work and Economic Growth #9 Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure). Women's suffrage in the United Kingdom was a pioneer women movements (#5 Gender Equality)It is hard to understand the shaping of modern world without knowing the role of England in the WWII.Finally, the discussion of the role of Britain in colonial Hong Kong also provides an opportunity for students to understand the legacy of Britain in Hong Kong today. Students should be able to review the following SDGs themes, including #5 Gender Equality #8 Decent Work and Economic Growth #9 Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure #16 Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions after this course, which fulfills the SDGs goals.

Dr. LEE Wai Ying Joanna

Dr. GUO Chunlan, 
Dr. LEE Wai Ying Joanna

courses.description: (UGEC1120 is double-coded with GRMD1301.) Since the establishment of the Special Administrative Region in 1997 under “One Country Two Systems”, the synergy between Hong Kong, Macao and the PRD has been renewed. With the recent Central Government's initiative of the development of Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area, there will be closer and mutually beneficial co-operation among cities in this economic region. This will reshape the socio-economic relations and the urban landscapes of the three places. Studying the changing relations of Hong Kong, Macao and the PRD will not only help students understand the dynamic socio-economic development of the Greater Bay Area as a rapidly growing mega-city region in the world, but also capture the latest transformation of the region. A wide variety of teaching and learning activities, including lectures, forums and video watching will be conducted to present a lively and comprehensive picture of the Greater Bay Area to students.
courses.enrollment_requirement:

Not for Geography and Resource Management Majors; and students who have taken GRMD1301[1033].
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.course_syllabus:
Lecture topics:
Getting to know Hong Kong and the Pearl River Delta
• Hong Kong, Macao and the PRD: The geographical setting and changing spatial relationship (香港、澳門與珠江三角洲:地理位置與空間關係轉變)
• From farming to manufacturing: socio-economic transformation of the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area (從桑基魚塘到世界工廠：粵港澳大灣區經濟社會變遷)
Economic aspect
• Foreign direct investment: angel or devil? (外來投資：天使或魔鬼？)
• CEPA and Greater Bay Area (CEPA 與粵港澳大灣區)
• Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area: a premier tourist destination (粵港澳大灣區:旅遊業新景象)
Social and environmental aspects
• Cross-border infrastructure development in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area: competition vs cooperation (粵港澳大灣區跨境基建：全面規劃還是各施各法？)
• Migration in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area (粵港澳大灣區人口流動)
• From state to market: how to satisfy the housing demand in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area (從國家分配到市場機制：如何滿足粵港澳大灣區人口的住房需求?)
• Environmental degradation – a necessary evil of economic growth? (環境惡化–經濟增長之必然代價？)
Governance and planning
• Planning sustainable cities and region in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area (粵港澳大灣區城市與區域可持續發展規劃)
• One country, many systems: competition or cooperation in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area ‘一囯多制’：競爭還是合作？
• Mega-city regions: the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area from global perspective (全球視野中的粵港澳大灣區城市群發展)
Two video watching and discussion sessions

courses.title: Thinking Gender: An Introduction to Gender Studies
courses.description: (UGEC1209 is double-coded with GDRS1001.)  This course aims to develop students’ ability to analyze the everyday life through the lens of gender. Drawing on the interdisciplinary nature of Women’s and Gender Studies, the course will guide students to examine how gender works as one of the primary social organizing principles in the movies we watch, the housework we do, the behaviors we express and many other daily activities that have been routinized. The first three lectures will equip students with a critical gender lens by questioning biology and getting familiar with theories of gender role, socialization, gender schema, doing gender and queer theory. All concepts to be explored in class will be explained with reference to research. At the end of the course, students will come to understand how political their personal life is. In particular, the course hopes to inspire students to take part in creating social change for gender equality, which is in line with the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Japanese Culture and Society
courses.description: (UGEC1232 is double-coded with JASP1100.) The main objective of this course is to give students a general idea of Japanese cultural history and social background of modern Japan. Guidance leading to a better understanding of Japan will be provided.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEC1232 is double-coded with JASP1100. 
Not for Japanese Studies Majors; and students who have taken JASP1100, SOCI2103 or UGEC2260. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) Students are expected to gain an understanding of the main areas of Japanese life including work, family, gender roles, marriage, and religion. They are expected to understand the ways in which Japanese see their own society in terms of economic growth,
Japan
's place in the world, social order, and political structure.
2) Students are expected to understand and be able to use a variety of social theories and perspectives in understanding
Japan
. They are also expected to have gained an understanding of how these same perspectives might be used to analyze their own society, or other societies which they may wish to study in the future.
3) Students are expected to develop a clearer understanding of their own values regarding work, leisure, marriage, family, love, and religion through a comparison with the debates and competing interpretations of these values in
Japan
.
Remarks:
Department Board members disagreed with the suggestion that they replace the word 'understanding' with another word such as 'identity, explain, analyze or synthesize' as suggested by UGE.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Images of
Japan
This lesson introduces students to widespread popular images of
Japan
in Asian and Western media and academia. It considers how and why these images have changed over time and asks students to consider the usefulness and limits of generalizations about other people and societies.
Week 2: Nation, Nationalism and the Imperial System
This lesson introduces students to theories explaining nationalism. It then uses these theories to consider nationalism in
Japan
. It explores the Japanese Imperial system in the context of historical developments in Japanese nationalism.

's economic development and subsequent recession of the 1990s. It considers the reasons for

Japan

This lesson explores the development of mass culture in
Japan

Japan

Week 13: Conclusion
This lesson reviews the social issues which Japanese consider to be most serious such as the emergence of diversity, subcultures, and changing youth expectations and desires regarding adulthood. It discusses, through surveys, how Japanese people view their society and how they view their future. It asks students to consider which problems are seen as the most critical in their societies, how their own societies view their future, and how popular views about their societies and about their societies' future are related to the beliefs held by individuals.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Japanese Popular Culture in Cultural Globalization
courses.description: (UGEC1271 is double-coded with JASP1160.)  This course examines the development and academic significance of various forms of Japanese popular culture such as films, comics, music, TV dramas and culinary culture, from multidisciplinary perspectives, including history, cultural anthropology, cultural studies and media studies. It aims to deepen understanding the following three facets of Japanese popular culture:1) the applicaton of cultural globalization theory in Japan; 2) the global strategy of Japanese cultural industries; and 3) social and intellectual transformation of contemporary Japanese society. Using concrete examples and grounding on representative academic writings, this course discusses the globalization of Japanese popular culture and relevant issues in indigenization, glocalization, hybridization, transnational cultural flows and media-mix. Students are trained to understand the nature and cultural implications of Japanese popular culture in an Asian context. Besides lectures, discussions and readings, this course selectively utilizes topical essays (projects), e-learning, audio-visual materials and fieldwork-based assignments as supplementary teaching tools.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEC1271 is double-coded with JASP1160. 
Not for Japanese Studies Majors; and students who have taken JASP1110 or 1160.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
Through a historical and cultural analysis of different facets of Japanese popular culture, this course aims to achieve the following three academic goals:
1)
It aims to use Japanese popular culture as a medium or stepping stone to enhance students’ interest in and understanding of Japanese history, society and culture.
2)
It aims to deepen understanding of nature and impact of Japanese cultural industry and its cultural implications in an Asian context.
3)
It aims to discuss Japanese popular culture within the theoretical framework of cultural globalization. Having taken this course, students will be equipped with a basic ability to analyse cultural phenomenon in the lens of such cultural concepts as indigenization, glocalization, hybridization, transnational cultural flows, media mix, cultural colonialism and orientalism.
courses.course_syllabus:
Main Objective
:
This main purpose of course is to examine the global popularization and localization of Japanese popular culture from historical, cultural and comparative perspectives within the theoretical framework of cultural globalization. It aims to indicate that the cultural flows between
Japan
and
Asia
are by no means one-way traffic and
Asia
has been interacting and collaborating with the Japanese in creating, manufacturing, marketing and distributing cultural products for decades. Lectures, discussions and readings highlight different facets of cultural acculturation and transnational interaction found in Japan-Asia cross-cultural flows, such as appropriation, hybridization, global localization business strategy, the making of localized editions, the local application of Japanese formula, joint production, and the participation of foreign artists and staff. Solidly grounding on empirical data as well as theories from cultural globalization and cross-cultural studies, this course will be a pioneering teaching and learning project to explore uncharted research territories in Japanese studies, Japan-Hong Kong relations, and cultural studies.
Key Issues and Problems
:
The following key issues and problems regarding the globalization of Japanese popular culture in an Asian context will be addressed in this course within the theoretical fiarnework of cultural globalization:
1) The idea that the influx of Japanese cultural products is a form of cultural imperialism that aims to expand Japanese economic interest and to spread Japanese value and lifestyle in
Asia
will be empirically and theoretically reexamined and challenged. It shows that cultural imperialism is an outdated model in cross-cultural studies, because it fails to understand the dynamic mechanism in transnational cultural flows and cultural forces of localization and hybridization.
2) While using "glocalization" (Roland Robertson uses it to refer to the localization strategy employed by multi-national companies to promote their products in different nations) to investigate the global business strategy of Japanese companies such as Sony, Nintendo, Capcom and Bandai in Asian and global markets, this course underscores the limitation of the glocalization theory in the East Asian context, as it fails to see the initiative taken by Asian artists and businessmen to creatively and selectively domesticate Japanese elements.
3) This course uses Japanese popular culture as a mirror or text to decode social and cultural issues of contemporary
Japan
. For examples, themes about ethnicity, gender, social hierarchy, political ideology, and cultural identity will be examined in the lens of Japanese popular culture.
Core Content, Structure and Selected Topics
:
The course content of this course investigates the three facets of Japanese popular culture:
(1) the application of cultural globalization theory in
Japan
,
(2) the global strategy of Japanese cultural industries,
(3) social and intellectual transformation of contemporary Japanese society. Accordingly, its structure follows the design of core content and contains the following three parts:

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Understanding Japanese Languages and Culture
courses.description: (UGEC1281 is double-coded with JASP1120.) This course explores the relationship between Japanese language and culture. Everyday communication strategies adopted by people in Japanese society will be examined in terms of Japanese language expressions, styles and structures. Linguistic approaches will be the principal analytical tools employed in this course but interdisciplinary approaches will also be adopted. This course is designed for students who are interested in knowing more about Japan but who have very limited or no knowledge of the Japanese language. Student will gain an understanding of the basic structure of the Japanese language, learn how usage of the language reflects Japanese culture and behavior, and explore how communication patterns of Japanese speakers differ from speakers of other languages.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEC1281 is double-coded with JASP1120. 
Not for Japanese Studies Majors; and students who have taken JASP1120. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students are expected to have gained a basic understanding of the structure of the Japanese language and historical changes of the writing system. Moreover, students will be able to understand the usage of the language, different styles and when each should be used, and different strategies used in expressing politeness.
2. Students are expected to understand the relationship between the language expressions and the behaviors of Japanese people in various circumstances and the reasons behind such behaviors.
3. Through comparing the culture of
Japan
with that of
Hong Kong
, students will become able to make comments on the characteristics of each and distinguish between the two.
4. Students will be able to perform an elementary study regarding Japanese culture and this will help the students to develop his/her further study in Japanese Studies.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1
Lesson 1
Introduction to Japanese culture
:
This lesson explains how Japanese culture influences daily life in
Hong Kong
today. The usage and the characteristics of Japanese language will also be discussed.
Week 2
Lesson 2
Introduction to the historical changes of kanji and kana in the Japanese language
:
This lesson explains the historical changes of kanji and kana in Japanese language. Focus will be on why Japanese absorbed Chinese characters into their writing system and the process of how Chinese characters were converted to the modern
kana (hiragana and katakana)
.
Week 3 – Week 4
Lesson 3
Introduction to the phrases expressing linguistic politeness
:
This lesson briefly explains the phrases expressing linguistic politeness. These include honorific expressions, expressions used in making requests, making apologies, expressing gratitude and personal opinions, giving advice and asking for permission. Emphasis will be placed on when and how these expressions are used. The relationship between such expressions and the characteristics of hierarchy in Japanese society will also be discussed.
Week 4 - 5
Lesson 4
Strategies used in making requests and refusals in Japanese
:
This lesson discusses how Japanese make requests and refuse the requests of others. Such expressions are often used in daily life by Japanese but are not easily understood by foreigners. Special attention will be given to:
a. the difference in behaviour between Japanese and non Japanese in making requests and refusals.
b. how this behaviour reflects characteristics of Japanese culture.
Week 6 – Week 7
Lesson 5
Strategies used in making apologies and taking responsibility
:
This lesson discusses how Japanese apologize and take responsibility after misconduct such as scandals or accidents. For example, we often see the top management of Japanese companies bow to the public to apologize for their misconduct and they may even quit the company in order to take responsibility for problems. In
Hong Kong
, it is rare to see such a phenomenon. We will discuss the mechanism of how Japanese make an apology and the effect of the Japanese way of apologizing upon social situations. Special attention will be given to the comparison of the styles of apology in Japanese and
Hong Kong
societies. We will also discuss the relationship between the Japanese way of apologizing and issues related to the Sino-Japanese War.
Week 8 – Week 9
Lesson 6
Ambiguity in the Javanese language
:
Compared with other languages such as Chinese, there are many ambiguous linguistic practices in Japanese. These include, for example, the deletion of the subject "
watashi
" (I), the use of "
koto ni
narimashita
" (become something) rather than "
koto ni shimashita
" (I decided to do something) when talking about personal matters such as getting married, and the frequent use of intransitive verbs rather than transitive verbs. Most Japanese language learners including
Hong Kong
learners have experienced difficulties with these expressions and practices in their learning process. We will analyze and comment on this phenomenon.
Week 9 – Week 10
Lesson 7
The Business Manner of Japanese
:
This lesson discusses how Japanese behave in business negotiations. Japanese are often criticized for not stating their true feelings and opinions. They often use expressions such as "
kangaesasetekudasai
" (Please let me think about it), "
kekkoo desu
" (It's O.K. /No, thank you) to indirectly express their opinions. We will discuss why Japanese behave in such a way and the correct way to deal with a Japanese business partner.
Week 10 - Week 11
Lesson 8
Japanese language in a sociolinguistic perspective
:
In this lesson we discuss the following items of importance in sociolinguistics as they appear in the Japanese language.
a. the comparison between written and colloquial styles
b. the comparison of language usage for men and women
c. the comparison between the standard language and dialect
d. the comparison of language usage between the young and the elderly
e. the comparison between formal styles and informal styles
f. the comparison between jargon and standard expressions
Week 12
Lesson 9
The success and failure in learning Javanese language (with a focus on
Hong Kong
Cantonese speaking learners)
:
First, we will give a brief introduction to the theories of second language acquisition. Next, the factors affecting the results of the process of second language learning will be discussed. To ensure a better understanding, case studies comparing English language acquisition among Japanese and
Hong Kong
people will be introduced. Finally, by summarizing the above observations and the characteristics of both Japanese and Cantonese, we will comment on the difficulties experienced by Hong Kong Cantonese speaking Japanese learners.
Week 13
Lesson 10
Special topics on Japanese 1anguage and Japanese culture
:
Special topics will be selected to help students understand the relationship between Japanese language and culture.
a.
"shin go ryuukoogo taishoo"
(New words and buzz terms Grand Prix)
b.
"kotoshi no kanji"
(The Chinese character of this year)

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Understanding Japanese Culture and Society Through Movies

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 803

courses.description: (UGEC1302 is double-coded with JASP1140.) Film is always regarded as an important medium for understanding society and culture. This course looks into the formation and characteristics of Japanese mentality and behaviour, through Japanese movies and academic readings of Japanese studies. This course consists of two major parts: 1) Lesson 2 to Lesson 7: Japanese Self-Image as Revealed in Japanese Movies; 2) Lesson 8 to Lesson 12: Comparison of the Thinking Patterns of Japan and Others. This course emphasizes interdisciplinary research and study methods, including film criticism, history and cultural studies. The lecturer will commence each lesson by referring to various academic readings, and will show movie clips if necessary, to serve as the basis for in-class discussions.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEC1302 is double-coded with JASP1140. 
Not for Japanese Studies Majors; and students who have taken GESC2080, JASP1140 or 1150. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Ø
Be able to understand the Japanese mentality and behaviour.
Ø
Acquire the ability to examine and investigate the academic and cultural meanings of movies from a macroscopic – cross-border, cross-era, interdisciplinary – perspective.
Ø
Be able to extract and digest messages carried in movies, in order to obtain a more thorough understanding of the relationships between Japan and other countries, including China, Korea and America.
Ø
Acquire a more thorough understanding of the influence of Japanese culture.
Ø
Further develop their critical thinking, presentation and writing skills through interactive teaching methods such as discussions, classwork and essay writing.
courses.course_syllabus:
Lesson 1
Introduction
(課程介紹)
This lesson introduces the objectives and learning approach of this course.
Part 1 (Lesson 2 to Lesson 7)
Japanese Self-Image as Revealed in Japanese Movies
(從電影看日本人的自我觀
)
This part brings out different predominant theories on Japanese mental structure, and discusses whether they can be applied to the Japanese mentality revealed in Japanese movies produced from the post-war period to present, so as to investigate the degree of their validity.
Lesson 2
Japanese Hierarchy and
Bushido
(日本的階級觀念與武士道)
This lesson discusses the function of hierarchy in Japanese society, and the important role of
bushido
in establishing the traditional Japanese ideals of conduct.
Readings:
Kurosawa-Film Studies and Japanese Cinema
, and《武士道》
Lesson 3
Japanese Moral Standards and the Shame Culture
(日本道德觀與恥的文化)
This lesson compares the Japanese shame culture to the guilt culture by investigating the relationship between groupism and individualism in Japan, and sees how it shapes the Japanese moral standards.
Readings:
The Anatomy of Dependence,
and《日本倫理思想與日本現代化》
Lesson 4
Passive Individualism Among the Youth
(日本新一代的被動個人主義)
This lesson examines the difference between individualism in Japanese new generation’s view of love and that of traditional thinking, and investigates the profound influences of Japanese movies and television culture on young people.
Readings:
The Creative Edge: Emerging Individualism in Japan
“Transcending the Outsider’s Role: A Japanese Superstar in Japan and Hong Kong”
,
and
Lesson 5
Japan’s Return to Asia: Political Meaning Behind the Boom of Takeshi Kaneshiro
(金城武熱潮的形成和意義)
This lesson discusses the transformation of Japanese identification of being Asian from the Meiji Westernization to the age of globalization, by examining the political meaning behind the boom of Takeshi Kaneshiro in the 1990s.
Reading: “Facing Challenges in a New Age: A Multicultural and New Generation Identity for Japan, through Kaneshiro Takeshi and Kubotsuka Yōsuke”
Lesson 6-7
A New Stage in Japan-China and Japan-Korea Relationships
(對中和對韓的日本新觀)
This lesson analyzes the new views on China and Korea revealed in Japanese movies produced from the 1990s to present.
Readings:
Interpreting History in Sino-Japanese Relations
, and 《東亞三國的近現代史》
Part 2 (Lesson 8 to Lesson 12)
Comparison of the Thinking Patterns of Japan and Others
(
比較日本與其他民族集團的思維模式
)
Through the comparison between movies of Japan and other nations, this part focuses on the different thinking patterns of Japan and others.
Lesson 8
Japanese Self-Deprecation and Male Chauvinism
(日本自嘲文化與男尊女卑)
Through the comparison of comedies of Japan and America, this lesson investigates the unique culture of self-deprecation, and the different roles of men and women in Japan.
Readings:
Beyond Common Sense: Sexuality and Gender in Contemporary Japan
, and
Different Games Different Rules - Why American and Japanese Misunderstand Each Other
.
Lesson 9
The Logic and Influence of
Amae
(“依愛”的邏輯與影響)
This lesson discusses how
amae
(dependence) affects the Japanese logical thinking and behaviour by comparing suspense movies of Japan, Hong Kong and Korea.
Readings: “
Higaisha-ishiki
: The Psychology of Revolting Youth in Japan,” 《日本的自我：社會心理學家論 日本人》及〈《花樣奇緣》呈現的日本人精神面貌〉
Lesson 10
Imaged Masculinity and the Aesthetics of Violence
(男性想像與暴力美學)
This lesson investigates the meaning of
ninjo
(human feelings) and
giri
(obligation), and the relationship between Japanese
yakuza
culture and gangster films. It also compares the different points of view of Takeshi Kitano and Quentin Tarantino in presenting the “aesthetics of violence” and “tragic hero”.
Readings:
The Chrysanthemum and the Sword: Patterns of Japanese Culture,
and
Myth and
Masculinity in the Japanese Cinema: Towards a Political Reading of the “Tragic Hero”.
Lesson 11
Self and Others: A Comparison of Japanese and American
Godzillas
(日美哥斯拉呈現的 “我” 與“他”)
This lesson investigates the socio-political meanings of
Godzilla
in Japan, and looks into the different viewpoints on the concepts of “others” between Japanese and American monster films.
Readings:
Hibakusha Cinema: Hiroshima, Nagashima, Nagasaki, and the Nuclear Image in Japanese Film
;
and
“From
Godzilla
to
Train Man:
A Study of the Japanese Self Image in the Context of the West”
Lesson 12
Cinderella & Women Warrior: A Comparison of Disney and Miyazaki’s Heroines
(比較日美動畫中的女性形象)
This lesson investigates the Japanese national spirit revealed in animations, compares the different images of female characters in Hayao Miyazaki’s and Disney’s animations, and examines their different cultural significance.
Readings:
Mouse Morality: The Rhetoric of Disney Animated Film,
and
Anime from Akira to Princess Mononoke: Experiencing Contemporary Japanese Animation
Lesson 13
Mid-Term Report Review and Conclusion
(中期報告成績討論與課程總結)
A follow-up discussion of the mid-term reports submitted by students; and a general review
of the topics, discussions and materials covered in the course, and helps students to
prepare for the final examination.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Tourism and Sustainable Development
courses.description: (UGEC1372 is double-coded with JASP1190.) Since 2015, tourism has been listed by the United Nations as one of the means to achieve sustainable development goals. How does tourism contribute to the sustainable development of human society? What are the impacts of tourism upon the cities and communities? Using Japan as a principal example, this course aims at examining the possibilities and challenges of achieving sustainable development goals through tourism. The first part of this course introduces basic concepts of tourism and sustainable development goals, and discusses their relationship. The second part of the course compares Japan to China and other countries, and investigates the benefits and costs of tourism in relation to sustainable cities and communities, indigenous culture, and natural resources. Additional discussions further explore the potentials of sustainable tourism in Hong Kong. With assigned readings and coursework, students are expected to acquire knowledge on sustainable development goals, and critically evaluate tourism as a means to achieve these goals.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEC1372 is double-coded with JASP1190.
Not for Japanese Studies Majors; and students who have taken JASP1190.
Co-requisite: Any course with "UGFH" or "UGFN" as prefix (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.course_attributes: SDG-GE #11 Sustainable Cities and Communities
courses.course_syllabus:
Part One – Overview
Week 01: Overview: Why Do People Travel? How Does Traveling Relate to Sustainable Development Goals?
This lecture topic introduces basic theories in social studies of tourism, and the current discussions on tourism in relation to sustainable development goals.
Week 02: Introduction to Sustainable Development Goals
This lecture topic further examines the UN Sustainable Development Goals, and requests students to discuss the possible challenges of achieving these goals through tourism.
Week 03: The Sustainable Destination
There is no tourism without destinations. This lecture topic examines features that make a destination sustainable.
Week 04: Overtourism? Cases of Kyoto, Macau and Venice
Overtourism is one of the keywords that address the problems incurred by tourism. Drawing cases from both Europe and Asia, this lecture topic examines these problems, and invites students to suggest solutions.
Part Two – Sustainable Development and Tourism in Japan and Beyond
Week 05: Overview of Tourism in Japan
This lecture topic introduces the socioeconomic background in the historical development of tourism in Japan. Drawing Japan as an example, students are encouraged to reflect on the social and political agenda of tourism.
Week 06: Gentrification: The Impacts of Urban Tourism
This lecture topic examines the problem of urban gentrification and its relation to tourism in Japan, China and beyond.
Week 07: Mega Events
Drawing on the Olympic Games as one of the examples, this lecture topic scrutinizes the effects and impacts of hosting mega events to attract tourists in Japan and beyond.
Week 08: Cultural Heritage and Local Communities
This lecture topic scrutinizes the impacts of tourism on local communities at world cultural heritage sites.
Week 09: Environment and Ecotourism
The lecture topic examines ecotourism and its impact on the local and global environment.
Week 10: Tourism and Indigenous Culture
This lecture topic investigates the role and impact of tourism on the sustainability of indigenous culture.
Week 11: Tourism and Rural Revitalization
This lecture topic focuses on the possibilities and challenges of introducing tourism for sustainable development in depopulating regions in Japan and beyond.
Week 12: Tourism and Disasters
This lecture topic discusses the phenomenon of transforming places associated with tragedy into tourist attractions, its cultural meanings, and social impacts upon local communities in Japan and beyond.
Week 13: Discussion: Sustainable Development and Tourism in Hong Kong and Japan
During the concluding lecture, students are invited to exchange their views on sustainable development in Hong Kong, in comparison to Japan and other localities discussed over the semester.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Perspectives in Economics
courses.description: (UGEC1511 is double-coded with ECON1010.)   This is an introduction to the nature of the economic problem and how society and man deal with the economic problem. It will cover resource allocation and the concept of economic efficiency, product and factor markets, macroeconomic indicators and the nature of macroeconomic problems, and macroeconomic policy. Economic concepts and theories will be applied to various social and economic issues such as marriage, crime and government policies.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEC1511 is double-coded with ECON1010
Not for majors in Fac of Bus Admin or IDA + X Double Maj Prog, ECON, GLEF, QFRM Majors; & students who have taken DOTE/DSME1030,1040, ECON1010 or 2011.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix.
courses.learning_outcomes:
It is expected that students will:
- 
acquire problem solving skills to think like an economist.
- 
master a set of concepts that will help them think more coherently and consistently about a wide range of problems
- 
be able to use these skills in their everyday lives as consumers, savers, entrepreneurs, investors, workers, citizens and participants in a global economy.
courses.course_syllabus:
Perspectives in Economics will introduce the fundamental concepts of economic and issues in economic research, covering both micro and macro economics. The course attempts to illustrate the importance and beauty of economics via a non-technical approach, using only elementary mathematics and graphs for expositions. Topics will include concepts of rationality, opportunity cost analysis, the functioning of supply and demand, the role of government and fiscal policy, the banking system and monetary policy, pricing, and some topics pertaining to crime, marriage and international trade. Students in this course will learn how to apply the fundamental economic principles to almost every aspect of their life.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Fundamentals of Public Administration
courses.description: (UGEC1522 is double-coded with GPAD1030.)  This course introduces contemporary study and practice of public administration, and the characteristics and roles of public bureaucracy in various types of administrative systems. Students will also learn to analyze some issues such as codes of conduct for civil servants, budgetary politics and redress of administrative grievances.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEC1522 is double-coded with GPAD1030. 
Not for Government and Public Administration Majors; and students who have taken GPAD1030 or UGEC1732. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, it is expected that students will have developed the following capabilities and skills:
By the end of this introductory course students should be able to develop broad sweep knowledge of a range of approaches to the study of public administration and, to a certain degree, an in-depth knowledge of selected concepts and theories. These theories were selected because of their direct relevance for developing an understanding of modern government behaviour.
Public administration is often considered in a managerial manner, as little more than control and straightforward analysis of efficiency and economy. This is not necessarily the case. People from different walks of life tend to have different expectations of government. This course is intended to foster a change in attitudes among students. After the course, students are expected to have the ability and tendency to think critically from multidisciplinary perspectives and to provide a critical appreciation of the strengths and weaknesses of any theoretical approach.
Most important of all, by taking this course, students should have developed an understanding of the basic concepts and theories in public administration and should have gained the ability to apply them to the context of Hong Kong. Public administration, as an area of study, is very much a study based in American context. Therefore, it is important for students to reflect on the concepts and approaches covered in the course, and to consider how they can contribute to a better understanding of public administration in Hong Kong.
The course is intended to reinforce communication skills on the part of students. Through the training in debates and discussions, students should have developed the ability to convey abstract ideas and complicated issues in a concrete and organized manner.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Government and Politics of China
courses.description: (UGEC1540 is double-coded with GPAD1070.)  This is an introductory course that surveys key issues in Chinese politics, including the historical background of the system, the roles of the party/state, the style of leadership, the forms of popular participation, and the distinctive features of Chinese politics. The focus of this course is political change. Classic essays by Sun Yatsen, Lu Xun, Mao Zedong and others provide students with grounding in the key problems modern China has faced, as well as the solutions it has pioneered. From that foundation, we will move on to contemporary institutions and intellectual debates over inequality, human rights, and the future shape of political reform in China.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEC1540 is double-coded with GPAD1070. 
Not for Government and Public Administration Majors; and students who have taken GPAD1070.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
By successfully completing this course, you should be able to
- 
Acquire a knowledge and understanding of the Chinese political history and contemporary politics of China
- 
Explore the main theoretical, empirical, and methodological approaches to the study of Chinese politics;
- 
Relate these approaches to the broader field of comparative politics;
- 
Develop conceptual ability to analyze and explain major issues and challenges confronting China today.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Globalization of Korean Popular Culture
courses.description: This course is designed to introduce students to contemporary Korean popular culture, and more specifically the 21st century South Korean cultural phenomenon called Hallyu (Korean wave) – its promises and limitations as well as its popularity and backlash against it. By taking an interdisciplinary approach to the topic, we will study food, film, television, music, fashion and sports and ask how they participate in the transnational production, distribution and circulation of culture, identity, modernity, tradition, ideology and politics both regionally and globally. One of the major questions this course will explore is the curious ways in which these popular media continuously re-stage and re-define Korea’s historical past in order to comment on its present. This course also targets to equip students with analytical tools to critically think about popular culture as well as understand theories of cultural globalization.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Global Studies (GLBS and GLSD) Majors; and students who have taken GLBS3202 or 3402.
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
To identify the historical developments and current content trends of the Korean wave.
To analyze the causes and outcomes of the Korean wave.
To recognize the importance of critical thinking skills for analyzing the transnational media content and effects in a global, cultural context.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Understanding Global Issues from Movies
courses.description: This course aims to introduce students to an array of global issues by using popular movies as major teaching instruments. In class, students will learn basic theories of globalization, development of global history since 1945, the contemporary structure of global order, and challenges/opportunities in the realm of global security (e.g. terrorism), global economy (e.g. free trade and inequality), global politics (e.g. global governance). The selected movie texts in this course would serve two purposes: learning tools and learning objects. On the one hand, students will analyze the features and real-life impacts of global issues depicted from these movies. On the other hand, they will also be trained to exercise critical thoughts towards the narratives conveyed from these movies. This course is suitable for students who have no prior knowledge in International Relations or Global Studies.

courses.learning_outcomes:

- Diagnose the causes and backgrounds of different global issues
- Apply different theories and perspectives of Globalization to the analysis of different global issues
- Review and critique the narratives about certain aspects of Globalization which are embedded in the selected movie texts
- Think critically

courses.title: Basic Banking and Finance
courses.description: (UGEC1560 is double-coded with ECON1420.)   This course is an overview of the institutional and practical aspects of the banking and financial sectors of the economy, with emphasis on how the two sectors impact on the economic well being of workers, consumers, and investors. This course is designed for students with no previous knowledge or training in economics. Topics to be discussed include: interest rate determination, operation and management of the banking system, banking policy and supervision, interbank market and liquidity, money supply, exchange rate systems and linked exchange rate, investment returns, risk diversification and portfolio choice, stock market movement, initial public offering and derivatives, financial ethics, international debt crisis, and their relationships with consumer prices, trade, investment, unemployment and the level of economic activity.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Marriage, Family and Kinship
courses.description: (UGEC1625 is double-coded with ANTH1310.) This course invites students to explore the issue of gender cross-culturally through the framework of kinship. It introduces basic concepts and major issues in the areas where the study of gender and the study of kinship intersect through an anthropological lens. Issues to be explored include kinship structures and related gender roles in cross-cultural perspective, the changing relationship between marriage and love, and the various new ways of people “doing” kinship in contemporary societies and the emerging social problems resulted from these changes. Themes such as kinship and the new reproductive technologies, fictive kinship and human-pet bond will all be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEC1625 is double-coded with ANTH1310.
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH1310. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Be familiar with the basic concepts, theories and contemporary social issues relating to gender and kinship.
• To gain appreciation of the culturally diverse forms and understanding of gender, marriage, family and kinship.
• Be able to identify and summarize key points and arguments in scholarly anthropological writings.
• To understand the practice of kinship as a means to ensure survival and establish meaningful social relations.
• To think analytically about the complex linkages between individuals and society in understanding and performing various forms of intimate relationships.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course introduces basic concepts and major issues in the areas where the study of kinship and the study of gender intersect through an anthropological lens. Issues to be explored include kinship structures and related gender roles in cross-cultural perspective, the changing relationship between marriage and love, and the various new ways of people “doing” kinship in contemporary societies and the emerging social problems resulted from these changes. Themes such as kinship and the new reproductive technologies, fictive kinship and human-pet bond will all be discussed. Overall, the course encourages reflection on the origin and nature of human social relations by elucidating the complex linkages between individuals and society in understanding and performing various forms of kinship.
PART I: BASIC CONCEPTS OF FAMILY AND KINSHIP
1. Introduction: Concepts, Abbreviations and Symbols
Issues to be discussed: What is Kinship? WHY do we study kinship, family and marriage? Kinship, family and marriage in modernity.
2. Unilineal (Patrilines and Matrilineal) and Cognatic Descent
Issues to be discussed: Why is virginity so valued in patrilineal and cognatic descent groups? Do women have more power in matrilineal societies?
PART II: Kinship, Marriage, and Family Related Issues
3. Choice of Mate, Courtship and Romance before Marriage
Issues to be discussed: What is romantic love and how has the notion changed over time? With whom one falls in love? What are the other factors that people consider when choosing a marital partner? How has the technological development changed how people love?
4. The “Big Day” and Romance after Marriage
Issues to be discussed: What is Marriage? Why is it nearly universal? How many people can you marry? With whom? By whom? The changing wedding rites and their meanings; Globalization and International Marriages.
5. Kinship, Social Relations, and Economy
Issues to be discussed: How do various practices of kinship function as means to ensure economic survival and enhancement?
6. Gender, Power and Family
Issues to be discussed: What is family? Why is it important? What are the mainly types of family and how are they related to particular social structures? How do family members bond together? What are the expected gender roles of wives and husbands in modern societies across the world? Gender and power dynamics within family.
7. Childhood, Parenthood and Social Reproduction
Issues to be discussed: What are the changing roles of and expectations for children? What are the roles and practices of parents in different societies in terms of childrearing and social reproduction? How are the experiences and meanings of childhood and parenthood influenced by globalization?
8. Marriage “Troubles”: Incest, Extra Marital Sex, Divorce and Remarriage
Issues to be discussed: Why the incest taboo? Are we really facing marital “crises” today?
9. Adoption, Fictive Kinship and Network of Care
Issues to be discussed: Why adoption? Why and how do we create fictive kinship? What are the potential challenges? Is fictive kinship fictive?
10. New Reproductive Technologies and Kinship
Issues to be discussed: Reproduction and conjugal relationships; Infertility and NRTs; Do NRTs give more power and freedom to woman?
11. Homosexuality and Kinship
Issues to be discussed: Consider homosexuality cross-culturally; Is homosexuality “abnormal”?
Homosexuality, social discriminations and various strategies to “cope”.
12. The Elderly, Caregiving and Haven in a Heartless World
Issues to be discussed: What are the social implications of an aging society? What is the comparative power of children, young adults, and the elderly within different societies? New Challenges faced by modern families in aging societies.
13. Conclusion: Biology, Culture and Kinship
Issues to be discussed: Course wrap-up; Underlining the complex linkages between individuals and society in understanding and performing various forms of intimate relationships.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Understanding Archaeology
courses.description: (UGEC1633 is double-coded with ANTH1710.) This course aims to provide students with some basic understanding of archaeology. It will introduce the basic theory, method and practice of archaeology. It will focus on the nature and development of archaeology, data acquisition (archaeological surveys and excavations), data processing and analysis, synthesis and interpretation (reconstruction of the past environmental ecology, economic, social and cultural life) and important archaeological discoveries and studies around the world. The significance of archaeology to contemporary societies will also be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEC1633 is double-coded with ANTH1710. 
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH1710. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to:

Have a basic understanding of what archaeology is about.

Know the basic archaeological research methods and field methods.

Obtain basic knowledge on the developments of humans and cultures, the dynamics between nature, human and cultures, and what can we learn from the past experiences.

Appreciate the diversity and achievements of human societies and cultures.

Know how archaeology is relevant to modern societies.

Cultivate the ability of inter-disciplinary thinking, critical thinking, and the ability to conduct holistic analysis.

Have broadened the academic and intellectual horizon, and acquired new information/knowledge.
courses.course_syllabus:


What really is archaeology? Objectives of archaeology as a scientific discipline vs. 'archaeology' created by
Hollywood
movies.

How did archaeology occur? -A brief history of modern archaeology.

What are the tasks of archaeologists? -Basic principles and research approaches of archaeology

Some very significant archaeological discoveries in the world, which have shaped our knowledge today.

Academic dynamics of archaeology and sciences, and archaeology and social sciences.

The meaning of archaeological remains and research in contemporary societies: how archaeological works are relevant to us?

Archaeology in the 21
st
century: achievements, new objectives, challenges, and the use and abuse of archaeology in the world.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Drugs and Culture
courses.description: Many drugs have mind-altering effects but some are defined as legal and some as illegal. The War on Drugs have been launched in many societies but none of them has successfully become a drug-free society. This course provides students an understanding of drug-related issues from a perspective of medical anthropology. Through close readings of ethnographies, viewing of videos, and fieldtrips, the class explores drug use, prevention, and treatment in both scientific and cultural perspectives and re-examines the linkages between legal and illegal behaviours, healthy and unhealthy bodily conditions, as well as science and culture.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Anthropology Majors. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.course_syllabus:
The major concepts in this course include drug addiction, harm reduction, and medical anthropology. The core content includes:
Module 1: What is Drug?
Chapter 1&2 Introduction to Drugs
The first two chapters discuss the physiological and psychological effects of mind-altering substances and their use from “traditional” societies to modern societies.
Module 2: Drug Effects
Chapter 3&4 Addictive Drugs: Alcohol and Heroin
These two chapters introduce two highly addictive drugs, namely alcohol and heroin. We discuss their cultural consumption and harmful effects and how institutional mechanisms in different societies regulate these drugs.
Chapter 5&6 Psychoactive Drugs: Marijuana and LSD
These two chapters discuss the controversy over drug legalization, particularly marijuana and LSD. We discuss the effects of these drugs and whether their medical and/or recreational use should be legalized.
Module 3: Drug Prevention and Treatment
Chapter 7&8 Drug Scene in Hong Kong and China
These two chapters discuss the changing drug use patterns in Hong Kong and China and examine how these changes are interweaved with an array of social factors, such as migration and economic development.
Chapter 9&10 The War on Drugs vs. Harm Reduction
These two chapters introduce the common two approaches to handling drug use issues in a society: zero tolerance and harm reduction. We discuss the effectiveness of these two approaches.
Chapter 11&12 Health Consequences of Drug Taking
These two chapters discuss the associated risks of drug taking, including HIV/AIDS and HCV contraction. We also discuss the effectiveness of the treatment of these drug-related diseases.
Various topics in relation to drugs and culture, such as cocaine use, club drug use, ketamine use, misuse of prescription drugs, and use of new pharmaceutical products, such as Prozac and Viagra, are the selected topics for this course.

courses.description: (UGEC1814 is double-coded with GPAD1100.)  This course aims to provide an introductory examination of legal systems and the role of law in the shifting social and political contexts. Interdisciplinary perspectives (e.g. philosophical, political and sociological etc.) will be taken on to deal with the conceptual and empirical issues. The course is not designed for professional legal training, but aims to assist students to reflect on the legal phenomena they experience in their daily life.
courses.enrollment_requirement:

Not for Government and Public Administration Majors; and students who have taken GPAD1100.

courses.learning_outcomes:
On knowledge and comprehension level
Students are expected to recognize and have basic understanding on a broad conceptual vocabulary and analytical approaches in legal discussion.
On application level
Students are expected to command writing skills to convey legal and political concepts and analysis.
Students are expected to command presentation skills to convey legal political concepts and analysis.
Students are expected to identify and recognize legal issues in the shifting social and political contexts, through the lens of the legal conceptual vocabularies and analytical approaches.
On analysis level
Students are expected to be able to analyze different perspectives, values and theories in relation to the controversial legal issues.
On synthesis level
From the interdisciplinary perspectives and intellectual horizons the course provides, students are expected to develop critical analytical skills, so that their self-expression and communication with other people will be improved.
On evaluation level
Students are expected to formulate one’s own view in understanding the legal issues, and the basic jurisprudential debates about the nature of law behind them

courses.description: (UGEC1823 is double-coded with SOCI1102.) This course explores into the significance of sociological perspectives in understanding modern society. Attention will be given to the application of sociological concepts in the observation and analysis of social phenomena in modern society. The course is designed particularly to develop intellectual skills, as part of a student's general education, for a better understanding of the nature of modern society.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Culture of Hong Kong
courses.description: (UGEC1835 is double-coded with ANTH1410.)  This course introduces students to characteristic aspects of Hong Kong culture. It will cover a wide range of cultural changes that have taken place since WWII. The course starts with an introduction to anthropological research in Hong Kong, and looks at topics including village culture and urbanization, food culture, marriage, family and gender, religion, and popular culture. Underlying most topics are questions of the modern versus the traditional, rural versus urban, cosmopolitan versus parochial, and how all these opposites interact to construct culture in Hong Kong. Hong Kong has been developed at a rapid pace since WWII. This course also discusses to what extent the development in Hong Kong meets the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), in particular in the area of gender equality, cultural inclusiveness, and socially responsible production and consumption.
courses.enrollment_requirement:

Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH1410.

courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students will be able to:
explicate the development of Hong Kong culture after the Second World War, including changes in the urban and rural areas, and critically identify the different factors affecting such development.
analytically discuss aspects of culture that they had previously taken for granted, including daily activities such as entertainment, food culture, and religious and secular rituals.
analyze different local lifestyles and their interaction with the changing environment, as well as the role of tradition and globalization.
identify and explicate aspects of the unity and diversity of culture in Hong Kong, and the processes that mold and shape cultural identity.
formulate research design on topics concerning Hong Kong, engage in cultural data collection, and present and communicate research results.

courses.title: Government of Hong Kong
courses.description: (UGEC1885 is double-coded with GPAD1050.)  This is an introductory course in government and politics of Hong Kong. It examines the following major issues: political institutions and processes; the various theoretical approaches to understand Hong Kong politics; the Basic Law and the principle of “one country, two systems”; the performance of the SAR Government since the return of sovereignty ; political culture; political parties and elections; and public administration and public policy. Emphasis is placed on recent changes and development, and the prospects for democratization.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Experiencing the City Through Walking
courses.description: The course introduces students to interdisciplinary studies on urban walks, urban encounters, cultural responses to urban walking experiences and creative interventions reacting to the urban built environment. Since the second half of the 19th century, ways of encountering the city at the street level and various means for capturing and making sense of urban encounters have continuously evolved, the course’s first aim is to introduce to students the history and shifting paradigms for understanding urban experiences in relation to walking. Secondly, the Covid-19 pandemic has substantively revived global interests in urban walks, the second aim of the course is to examine the latest ideas concerning rediscovering the city through different modes of walks. Thirdly, students will learn connecting theories to practices, they will learn to become active “users” of the city and adopt different forms to create new walking experiences and articulate urban experiences.More specifically, the course will focus on how ‘walking in the city’ has become an activity in its own right, and the cultural and social potentials of ‘non-functional’ urban walks. Wandering in the city has its own evolving knowledge and practices, the academic discussion accumulated through the years will be introduced. As such, through urban walks one can encounter the heterogeneity and complexity of cities including but not limited to its built environment, symbolic dimension, flows, natural elements and publicness. The heterogeneity and complexity of the city will be primarily addressed, especially through various schools of thought which have influenced how urban walks have been undertaken. The Sustainable Development Goal 3 ‘Good-Health and Wellbeing’ & Goal 11 ‘Sustainable Cities and Communities’ will be covered by the course, as urban walks have been seen as key to achieving wellbeing in recent years and it is also a means for the community to enhance their bonding by sharing local knowledge through walks. Goal 4 ‘Quality Education’ is also covered as walking is increasingly seen as a medium for innovative education and a form of life-long learning outside of the classroom.

Not for Urban Studies Majors.
Co-requisite: Any course with "UGFH" or "UGFN" as prefix (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)

SDG-GE #3 Good Health and Well-being
SDG-GE #4 Quality Education
SDG-GE #11 Sustainable Cities and Communities
Experiential Learning Course
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. 
To contrast and evaluate the evolving discourses and transforming practices of urban walks emerged in different eras since the 19th Century
2. 
To differentiate and analyse different ways of seeing and approaches of observations when one undertakes urban walks (connecting to SDG 11)
3. 
To formulate and arrange one’s own style of urban walk in order to obtain a particular type of urban experience (connecting to SDG 3)
4. 
To synthesize and produce forms of expressions that capture urban experiences and urban encounters obtained from consciously designed urban walks (connecting to SDG 4)
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1
Introduction: The renewed interests in urban walks
In the first week the overall problem will be introduced, namely how there has been a resurgence of interests in urban walks and its proliferating diversity. In the first week, the introduction aims at demonstrating the interdisciplinary nature of the issue and the many dimensions of urban walk as an issue.
Week 2
The idea of walking and conceptualizing urban walks
Before discussing urban walk specifically, in week 2 the literature on walking as a human behavior will be outlined, some of the key and foundational texts will be discussed.
The early attempts to conceptualize urban walks in the 19
th
century will also be introduced, in particular, the idea of the Flaneur and Charles Baudelaire’s contribution will be outlined. The discussion on Flaneur will be followed by interventions made by the Surrealist, Walter Benjamin and others in the first half of second century.
Week 3
Innovating urban walks in the 20
th
Century
Postwar interventions such as the Situationist International and Guy Debord’s thoughts on creative urban walks will be introduced, together with other modern artists and architectural theorists’ initial detour into the realm of experimental walks. The discussion will be put in contrast with Jane Jacobs’ ideas with more focus on urban planning and community.
Week 4
A Japanese school of walk: Modernology and ‘Street Observations Studies’
While week 3 and week 4 largely focus on Anglo-European ideas, the substantial contribution made by Japanese artists and urban theorists will be introduced. In this week, students will practice ‘street observation’ on campus, as the initial attempt to put theory into practice.
Week 5
Walkscapes: Contemporary art and the aesthetical turn
More artistic attempts to reinvent the practice of urban walks will be introduced in this week, in the lecture the ideas from performance studies will also be discussed to support the debates on aesthetical dimension of urban walks.
Week 6
Walkability, well-being and the body
Functional dimensions of urban walks and policy related concerns will be discussed in this lecture. The lecture will also briefly introduce ideas about corporeal geography and non-representational theory, as the theoretical discussion will bring up the non-cognitive aspects of walk.
(Addressing SDG goal 3)
Week 7
Field trip 1: Walks about capturing urban experiences and experimental walks
The field trip will be about more ‘conventional’ approach to urban walk as an aesthetic practice, it will be about how heterogeneous urban experiences and observations could be gained.
(Addressing SDG goal 4)
Week 8
Heterogeneous urban experiences: Sensory and visual
The lecture will focus on the types of sensory and visual data could be gained from urban walks, the literature analyzing and conceptualizing these data and experiences will be outlined.
Week 9
Cataloguing and expressing urban experiences: The idea of forms
The lecture will focus on how various forms are employed to catalogue and reorganize the urban experiences gained from urban walks. The forms include moving images, still images, literary experimentation, and research projects.
Week 10
Field trip 2: Walk design and the idea of journey design
The field trip will be a practical guidance discussing how various forms of walks, guided tours and journey are designed and created. It will be followed by a more conceptual discussion on the experience economy and experiential cultural consumption.
(Addressing SDG goal 11)
Week 11
Walking in Hong Kong
The lecture will explore how the idea of urban walk has been picked up and discussed in the context of Hong Kong. The initial idea of Hong Kong as a ‘City of Walk’ will be discussed.
(Addressing SDG goal 11)
Week 12
Workshop: Presenting a walk design project (1)
The workshop will be an interactive session for students to showcase their creative ‘walk-design’ projects, the lecturer will give substantial feedback and moderate dialogues in order to foster imagination and creativity for creating potential cultural projects concerning urban walk and urban experiences
(Addressing SDG goal 4)
Week 13
Workshop: Presenting a walk design project (2) & Conclusion
The workshop will be an interactive session for students to showcase their creative ‘walk-design’ projects, the lecturer will give substantial feedback and moderate dialogues in order to foster imagination and creativity for creating potential cultural projects concerning urban walk and urban experiences
The conclusion will point to recent discussion on the future role of urban walks and cities that empower the community
(Addressing SDG goal 4)

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Foundations in Public Health
courses.description: (UGEC1920 is double-coded with PHPC1001.)  This course will introduce undergraduate students to the discipline of public health and its basic academic framework, concept and methodology. The objective of the course is to provide a broad intellectual perspective of public health and presents both local and global public health challenges that are facing our society in the 21st century. The various academic disciplines within the domains of public health that include environmental health sciences, health policy and management, social and behavioral sciences and basic science will be introduced and discussed. The impact of these public health problems in relation to our society and our everyday lives will be emphasized. An analytic public health problem solving framework will be used to enable students to appreciate and learn the problem solving methodology in evaluating and appraising various public health problems.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEC1920 is double-coded with PHPC1001. 
Not for MBChB; Public Health Majors; and students who have taken MEDF1021, 1120, PHPC1001 or UGEC2930.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, the students should be able to:
1. Define public health, identify its major domains, functions, and disciplines, and explain its historical development and contemporary achievements.
2. Describe the concepts of transitions, and analyze the impact, challenges, and strategies for controlling infectious and non-communicable diseases.
3. Examine the impact of physical activity and sedentary behavior on fall risks in older adults and assess interventions promoting physical activity and health among school-aged children.
4. Describe the ethical principles in health and healthcare, including social and distributive justice
5. Analyze the social determinants of health and health equity, and evaluate population health and high-risk intervention strategies.
6. Describe the basic concepts of health demography and analyze the associations between population attributes and population health

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Wine Culture and Appreciation: Enhancing Quality of Life
courses.description: Wine weaves in with human history from its very beginnings and has developed into one of the foremost products of civilization. Wine has its roots in the customs, traditions and history and it occupies an important place in the culture and life of the people worldwide. The purpose of this course is to lead students on a cultural journey around the world and introduce them to a historical perspective on wine and its place in society. It is a course addressing the science of wine, the world wine regions, and the role of wine in human culture. Specifically, the course is designed to increase students’ understanding of essential wine knowledge and culture and help them build a strong base for lifelong wine appreciation and enhance their quality of life. The topics include cultural history of wine, the identification of grape varieties, the methods of viticulture (grape cultivation) and the techniques of vinification (wine making). The impact of alcoholic beverages on society and human physiology will be emphasized. Comparative tasting methods will be introduced through sensory evaluations training.

courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students will have attained the knowledge necessary to appreciate, select, and taste wines with confidence. In particular, the students should be able to:
Address the role of wine in society, history and civilization
Examine the impact of alcohol consumption on health and social issues raised by alcohol abuse
Discuss tradition, diversity and geographical characteristics of wines and different systems of denoting wine quality in the social, historical and cultural context.
Develop senses of sight, smell and taste in appreciating different types of wines for sensory attributes, varietal character, and terroir
Recognize the impact of globalization on wine trade and the economy, using Hong Kong as the regional wine hub as an example.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: History of Macau: The Encounter of Eastern and Western Cultures
courses.description: Macau is renowned for its gaming industry, yet it is also the place where East meets West. After more than three centuries of social evolution and cultural exchange, which attributes to Macau’s social diversity and valuable cultural heritage. This course will be divided into two parts. Part I traces and examines the development of Macau from a historical perspective, foster students an understanding of the contexts that shape the society and culture of the city from the past to the present, and how these contexts served as obstacles or opportunities in achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Part II exposes students to selected themes, including ethnic relations, economic activities, religious and cultural exchange, heritage conservation, etc., exploring Macau’s social diversity and cultural inclusiveness, and examine their relevance to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), including SDG#8 Decent Work and Economic Growth, SDG#10 Reducing Inequality and SDG#11 Sustainable Cities and Communities.

Recognize and critically analyze how and why various contexts shaping the culture and society of Macau, and how these contexts served as obstacles or opportunities in reducing social inequality (SDG#10 Reducing Inequality) and promoting economic growth (SDG#8 Decent Work and Economic Growth).
Appreciate Macau’s cultural diversity and cultural heritage.
Evaluate and reflect on selected issues (e.g. economic development versus heritage conservation, challenges of preserving Macanese cultures in a Chinese city, etc.) concerning the sustainable development of Macau and its community (SDG#11 Sustainable Cities and Communities).

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: The Effectiveness of the Law Intended to Safeguard Cultural Heritage in Hong Kong
courses.description: Surprisingly, as one of the world’s most modern cities, often thought of as a city of skyscrapers, Hong Kong has an incredibly rich and diverse cultural heritage. This is reflected in its wide diversity of buildings and monuments; including ancient temples, walled villages, and legacies of its colonial period including Tai Kwun, Heritage 1881, and more recent glass and steel structures such as Norman Foster’s HSBC Building. Hong Kong also has many museums and galleries containing important representations of Chinese and other cultures which were important in the development of modern Hong Kong. These range from works of art, through to the seemingly more mundane legacy of Hong Kong’s colonial history, and evidence its pre and post-colonial heritage. This course considers the issues which face this heritage, and the legal framework and other protection affecting cultural heritage in Hong Kong. Among other topics, the course will consider: the law and policy intended to safeguard built heritage in Hong Kong; the law and policy affecting antiquities and other forms of portable heritage including private and public collections in Hong Kong; the law and policy affecting street art and public expressions of Chinese culture; the history of looted heritage including Hong Kong’s looted heritage and Hong Kong’s role in the illicit trafficking of looted heritage from China, and the law which is intended to prevent this illicit trade; the law and policy intended to safeguard Hong Kong’s water heritage including shipwrecks, and treasure hunting; and, the law and policy intended to safeguard the newest and richest recognised form of cultural heritage- intangible cultural heritage, including Cantonese opera, dragon-boat racing, bamboo scaffolding, neon signs and milk tea.This course will consider the threats that Hong Kong’s cultural heritage faces and the law and other safeguarding measures that have been implemented and may be introduced to promote Sustainable Development Goals including, among others, Life on Land (SDG 15), Life Below water (SDG 14), Climate Action (SDG 13), and Sustainable Cities and Communities (SDG 11).
