SDG-GE #11 Sustainable Cities and Communities
SDG-GE #13 Climate Action
SDG-GE #14 Life Below Water
SDG-GE #15 Life On Land
courses.course_syllabus:
1
Introduction.
What is cultural heritage? What is culture heritage law? Cultural heritage in Hong Kong. Issues facing cultural heritage in Hong Kong. The development of international and domestic law to protect cultural heritage. Other measures intended to safeguard cultural heritage.
2
Safeguarding Built Heritage in Hong Kong.
Problems with built heritage in Hong Kong in the colonial period. The development of law to safeguard built heritage in Hong Kong.
3
Safeguarding Built heritage in Hong Kong since 1997.
2006-7: the year of heritage social unrest. The legal framework of public and private measures safeguarding built heritage in Hong Kong today.
4
Portable Heritage.
What is portable heritage? What laws affect the ownership, sale, gift and loss of cultural heritage in Hong Kong? Public and private ownership of portable heritage. The role of museums and archaeology in safeguarding portable heritage.
5
Private ownership of portable heritage in Hong Kong.
What legal issues may arise in the buying and selling of Chinese antiquities in Hong Kong?
6
The Dead as Cultural Heritage.
The law and the dead. Can we own the dead? Exhuming, selling, displaying and repatriating the dead
7
Creating Portable Heritage in Hong Kong.
Streets and graffiti artists and their legal rights. Street art and graffiti as cultural heritage in Hong Kong. The “King of Kowloon”. Can you own graffiti?
The multiple choice (MC) test will be administered in week 7, as a mid-term assessment with 20 questions. The results will be provided to students within one week of taking the test to allow them to consider their engagement and progress in the course.
8
Cultural Heritage and Digital Technology.
The use of blockchain tokenisation and artificial intelligence in the creation and safeguarding of culture heritage in Hong Kong. The issues with and law affecting digital technology and cultural heritage including owning buying, selling and giving tokens of real and virtual art, and intellectual property law issues for art generated by artificial intelligence.
9
Hong Kong’s Part in the Illicit Trade in Antiquities from China.
The legal framework affecting antiquities in China- focus on the Greater Bay Area (GBA) and possible harmonization of the law to safeguard China’s cultural heritage from illicit excavation and trafficking.
10
Hong Kong’s Water Heritage.
The law affecting searching for, owning, buying and selling shipwrecks and treasure. The legal safeguarding framework for Hong Kong’s water heritage
11
What is Intangible Cultural Heritage?
International and domestic laws affecting intangible cultural heritage. The Convention for Safeguarding of the Intangible Cultural Heritage (2003). China’s championing of intangible cultural heritage. China’s rich and varied intangible cultural heritage.
12
Safeguarding Intangible Cultural Heritage in Hong Kong.
2008 and Hong Kong’s adoption of intangible culture heritage. The legal recognition and safeguarding of intangible cultural heritage in Hong Kong. Hong Kong’s officially recognised intangible cultural heritage: fire dragons, Chinese medicine, Cantonese opera, bamboo theatres, sek pun (basin feast) and milk tea. Hong Kong’s unofficial intangible culture heritage.
Issues with intangible cultural heritage including cultural appropriation.
13
Review and Conclusions.
The future for safeguarding cultural heritage in Hong Kong. Possible devleopemsnt in domestic laws in Hong Kong which may affect cultural heritage, and the extension of international legal measures to Hong Kong.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Challenges of World Population
courses.description: This course provides an overview of the key challenges of the world population [in the 21st century]. For example, aging or overpopulation in urban cities, environmental degradation, food and water resource crisis, large-scale voluntary and involuntary migration, and spread of communicable disease. A key goal of the course is to map out the linkages between population patterns, trends, and some of the socio-economic issues that occur locally, nationally, and at the global level which bring great challenges to our society. You will learn the concepts, theories, and data essential in the scientific study of the size, composition, and spatial distribution of human populations; and the changes that occur in these phenomena through the processes of fertility, mortality, and migration. You will gain an understanding of the roots of population structures, processes, and the consequences for individuals, family, and societies, and how it will affect and be affected by natural resources availability or depletion and health care system. Students will acquire the basic ability to analyze, explain and present the potential crisis facing the population system. In particular, this course will stimulate students’ interest in understanding how the population could be linked to sustainable development, and reflect on the relationship between population growth and availability of resources, as well as the relationship between population and social institutional arrangements such as child and old care support, job supply and public asset distribution. In the end, students will learn to apply their skill and knowledge in proposing solutions for solving population-related challenges for achieving Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), for example, zero hunger and no poverty, good health and well-being, reducing social inequality including gender inequality, maintaining decent work and economic development while developing more sustainable cities and communities.

courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To stimulate students’ interest in understand how population could be linked to sustainable development. In particular, the relationship between population growth the and availability of resources, as well as the relationship between population and social institutional arrangement such as child and old care support, job supply as well as public asset distribution.
2. To learn the basic demographic indices and techniques to understand the trend and pattern of population development.
3. To stimulate and investigate the potential solutions for solving population related challenges for sustainable development such as the constraint in the natural resources, the benefits and limitation of urbanization and social inequality in facing population challenges.
4. To evaluate the barriers to the implementation of the solutions such political struggling among different stakeholders.
5. To help students be prepared for a lifetime of reflective study of changes impact on their own life.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topic 1: Introduction: Overview of World Population:
Basic concepts of the population studies
Some basic concepts of social research and research methods.
Topic 2: World Population Growth and Demographic Transition:
History, trends and reason of world population growth and transition
Relationship between population changes and resources.
Topic 3: Demographic Data:
Where to obtain demographic data
Topic 4: High Fertility, Low Fertility and the Challenges face by Countries:
Technique of measuring the fertility, the fertility trends and future directions
The reasons why fertility have been changing and how it will change in the future (SDG1, 2, 11).
Topic 5: Mortality, Health and Epidemiological/Health Transition and the Social Consequences:
Technique of measuring the mortality, the mortality trends and future directions
The reasons why mortality have been changing and how it will change in the future (SDG2, 3).
Topic 6: Causes and Consequences of Migration and Immigration:
Technique of measuring the migration and immigration, the migration trends and future directions.
The reasons why migration have been changing and how it will change in the future (SDG8, 10, 11).
Topic 7: Age and Sex Structure of Population: Population Aging and Sex Ratio and the Problems:
Age and sex as the most important two characteristics of population
Age and sex structure and how it is related to resources (SDG1, 2, 5, 10, 11)
Topic 8: Are Family in Decline? The Challenges of Family System:
Family changes and how they are related to sustainable development (SDG1, 2, 3, 5)
Topic 9: Urbanization: Benefits and Problems:
Family changes in the process of urbanization
How these family changes are related to sustainable development (SDG5, 8, 10, 11)?
Topic10: Population Policy:
Population Policy and its relation sustainable development goals (SDG 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 11, 11, 16).

courses.title: History of Women in Modern China
courses.description: Gender inequalities often stem from distinctions either empirically grounded or socially constructed. “History” is of essential importance in understanding how these inequalities are constructed in different periods and different contexts. This course traces and examines the history of women in China from the late Qing period to the present. Discover and analyze the sex roles, sexual politics and sexual symbolism in the course of modernization and nation building, how they are related to economic development, ideological shifts and colonialism, and to find out how they functioned to reduce gender distinctions (SDG#10 Reduced Inequalities), how they affected the formulation and changes of women policy (SDG#16 Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions), and how they promoted woman’s rights and social changes (SDG#5 Gender Equality).

courses.learning_outcomes:
Have a better understanding of the history of modern China in a gendered perspective.
Develop deeper understanding of women’s rights movement in modern China, and the roles and contributions of women in the evolution and development of Chinese society.
Understanding how the women policy in modern China is formulated (SDG#16 Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions) and changed over times in promoting the rights of women (SDG#10 Reduced Inequalities)
Recognize and critically analyze how and why various contexts shaping the lives and experience of women in modern China.
Cultivate sensitivity and fair evaluation to issues related to sexuality and gender.
Evaluate and reflect on how to promote gender equality (SDG#5 Gender Equality) based on the experience of the past.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Modernity and Urban Culture
courses.description: (UGEC2042 is double-coded with CURE2016.)   This course is an introduction to the formation of modernity in relation to various aspects of urban culture. Tracing the development of cities and the urban cultures evolved within the new urban development since the 19th Century, cities such as Paris, London, New York will serve as 'texts' for analysis. Architecture, urban planning, artistic and intellectual movements as well as modes of everyday life in urban living are studied to demonstrate how the modern ways of thinking, seeing and living come into being. The course will also focus on the specificity of Hong Kong's experience in urban development and its adaptation of 'modernity' during a process of urbanization. The course will employ a wide range of visual images and audio-visual materials to explain the dynamism between modernity and urban culture.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Cities of the World: A Cultural and Historical Exploration of Urban Development
courses.description: This course is designed to offer an exhaustive and nuanced exploration of the intricate patterns and rich historical tapestries of urban development worldwide, viewed through a geographic lens. Throughout this course, students will be introduced to a wide range of theories and concepts that are intricately linked to the social and economic evolution of cities across different world regions. These theories and concepts include colonialism, postcolonialism, capitalism, neoliberalism, globalization, post-industrial development, urbanization, and urban sprawl. By exploring these theories and concepts, students will gain a comprehensive understanding of urban development within diverse geographic contexts and with varying historical backgrounds. This course is relevant to SDGs 10 (Reduced Inequalities) and 11 (Sustainable Cities and Communities). It will provide students with the knowledge and tools to identify inequalities in urban development and analyze the challenges and opportunities in achieving sustainable cities and communities. The curriculum is thoughtfully divided into five key sections, each providing an in-depth analysis of urban development in different regions – Europe, America, Sub-Saharan Africa, the Greater Middle East, and Asia. These sections are carefully curated to help students gain a profound understanding of the diverse economic, political, cultural, and historical influences that have shaped and continue to shape urban landscapes in these varied regions. Students will engage with diverse learning methodologies. This includes detailed case studies that provide real-world examples of urban development, scholarly readings that offer academic perspectives, visual aids that illustrate key concepts, and interactive discussions that encourage critical thinking and collaborative learning. Ideal for students with a passion for urban studies, geography, history, sociology, or related disciplines, this course offers a unique opportunity to explore the world of urban development in a global context, preparing them to become informed and engaged global citizens.
courses.enrollment_requirement:

Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #10 Reducing Inequality
SDG-GE #11 Sustainable Cities and Communities
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to delve deeply into the multifaceted histories and cultures of cities around the world in this course. This academic journey equips them with the skills to analyze the impact of economic, political, cultural, and historical influences on urban development. They will learn to compare and contrast the unique paths and common patterns in the development of different cities, enhancing their understanding of global urban evolution. The course aims not just to impart knowledge, but also to sharpen critical thinking and research skills, fostering a deep appreciation for the intricate and diverse nature of cities. After completing the course, students will be able to:
Explore the diverse historical and cultural narratives of major world cities.
Investigate the impact of significant historical events and cultural and religious movements on urban development.
Compare and contrast the unique characteristics, urban patterns, and challenges of various cities.
Analyze the role of urban planning in shaping city identities.
Develop critical thinking skills through a geographic lens.
Foster a global perspective by understanding the interconnectedness of cities worldwide.
Understand contemporary issues, challenges, and opportunities in achieving equal and sustainable cities and communities.
courses.course_syllabus:
As shown below, the course contents will be divided into 5 parts and 12 topics.
Part I: World urban development (1 lecture)
The course begins with a singular, foundational lecture that sets the stage for understanding global urban development. It introduces key concepts, trends, and the factors driving urbanization worldwide, providing a global context for the more detailed regional studies that follow.
1. World urban development
世界城市發展
Part II: Europe (3 lectures)
The European segment consists of three lectures. The first lecture focuses on the development of European cities from ancient times to modernity, highlighting the impacts of technological, social, and economic development on the evolution of urban landscapes and patterns. The second lecture takes students on a journey to explore distinctive cities across Europe, examining the unique characteristics that define them. In particular, we will discuss the issue of camera surveillance in London, the refugee crisis in Paris, post-socialist development in Berlin, and superblocks and walkability in Barcelona. The final lecture in this section shifts focus to Russia, discussing both historical and contemporary aspects of Russian urban development, and offering insights into the evolution of its cities amidst political and social changes. Students will learn about the unique urban landscape of Russian cities inherited from their imperial and Soviet histories and discuss issues such as the environmental crisis of Norilsk and the problem of street children in post-Soviet cities.
2. Historical perspectives on urban development in Europe
歐洲城市發展的歷史觀察
3. Exploring distinctive cities in Europe
探索歐洲特色城市
4. Historical and contemporary Russian cities
俄羅斯城市的歷史與現狀
Part III: America (3 lectures)
This section, also encompassing three lectures, begins by delving into the history of urban development in Latin America. It examines the colonial impact, post-colonial developments, and contemporary challenges. The subsequent lecture takes students on a virtual tour of unique Latin American cities, exploring their cultural, architectural, and social nuances. We will discuss the issues of favelas in Rio de Janeiro, the impact of modernism on urban design and architecture in Brasilia, and gated communities in Buenos Aires. The last lecture of this section examines North American cities, discussing issues such as racial and social segregation in New York City, the development of shared mobility and sustainable transportation systems in Portland, auto dependence and urban sprawl in Los Angeles, and post-industrial development and gentrification in Toronto.
5. Understanding the history of Latin American urban development
解讀拉丁美洲城市發展的歷史
6. A journey to unique Latin American cities
造訪獨特的拉丁美洲城市
7. Historical overview and distinctive cities in the United States and Canada
美國和加拿大的歷史概述與獨特城市
Part IV: Sub-Saharan Africa and the Greater Middle East (3 lectures)
Three lectures are devoted to these regions. The first concerns urban development in Sub-Saharan Africa, discussing issues like post-colonial race and class segregation in Johannesburg, squatter settlements in Nairobi, and inequality in Lagos. The second lecture turns to the Greater Middle East, exploring the historical evolution of cities under the influence of Islamic culture, colonial history, the independence movement, and contemporary conflicts. The third lecture invites students to virtually visit distinctive cities in the Greater Middle East, investigating issues such as the city of the dead and the informal economy in Cairo, religious tourism in Mecca, green infrastructure in Dubai, and Palestinian-Israeli conflict in Jerusalem.
8. Urban development and distinctive cities in Sub-Saharan Africa
撒哈拉以南非洲的城市發展與獨特城市
9. Historical evolution of urban development in the Greater Middle East
大中東地區城市發展的歷史演變
10. Visiting distinctive cities in the Greater Middle East
探訪大中東地區特色城市
Part V: Asia (2 lectures)
The course concludes with two lectures on Asia. The first examines the historical geography of urban development in South and Southeast Asia, focusing on the influences of colonialism, religious and ethnic conflicts, and territorial disputes. This lecture will examine issues such as air pollution in Delhi, the climate migration crisis in Dhaka, and Singapore’s strategies for smart city development and public housing management. The final lecture focuses on East Asian cities, analyzing their past and present, and how traditions and modernity coexist and interact in these urban centers. Issues that will be discussed in this lecture include urban congestion in Beijing, population aging in Tokyo, and the influence of the declining birthrate and pop culture on urban fabrics in Seoul.
11. Historical geography of urban development in South and Southeast Asia
南亞和東南亞城市發展的歷史地理
12. The past and present of East Asian cities
東亞城市的過去與現在

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Decolonizing Classical Music
courses.description: The universal appeal of classical music is masked by a troubled past. It is a complex story of white colonization by European powers, spanning centuries and continents. Classical music has its own colonial baggage, too, with links to slavery profits and other problematic phenomena, whether in the gendered tradition of the “great composers,” or in a thriving piano industry of the early 20th century, which resulted in forced labor and countless deaths in the colonial ivory trade, or in the transnational circulation of opera in and beyond the 19th century, which would not have been possible without the port city networks of rapidly expanding empires. Importantly, such legacies have led to new forms of advocacy aimed at decolonizing classical music today. This SDG-GE course will examine how current practices around the world, on the back of complex and violent histories, attempt to democratize classical music in lockstep with the needs and concerns of contemporary society. What does it mean to decolonize musically in the 21st century, recenter marginalized individuals and groups in classical music, and make classical music more sustainable and reflective of a fair society? These questions run through the three themed sections of the syllabus: i) gender and representation, ii) equality, diversity, inclusion, iii) institutions and justice. We will explore related ideas and concepts, in connection with past contexts and present practices, including orchestras, opera companies, community projects, and social enterprises. By drawing on a variety of perspectives, we will discuss how and why decolonizing classical music matters, to whom, along with its ongoing challenges for improving and enhancing equity.  This course engages directly with SDGs 5, 10, and 16. Through the three themed sections, we will assess how classical music practices today can be observed to respond to the identified SDGs, particularly in terms of further empowering indigenous women musicians, reducing age-old inequalities, and promoting greater social justice from within institutions that can better reflect the untold tales and human experiences of classical music.  Neither score-reading nor prior musical knowledge is required for this course.

courses.course_syllabus:
Course objective: To develop an enriched understanding of decolonizing classical music today, by examining how current practices around the world, on the back of complex and violent histories, attempt to democratize classical music in lockstep with the needs and concerns of contemporary society.
I: Gender and representation
The first section of the course engages with SDG 5. Students will explore the topic of representation and related contexts and practices in decolonizing classical music, as well as efforts to address issues of gender and race, visibility, and difference through new forms of advocacy.
“The white-male canon”: decolonizing musically in the 21
st
century
Session goal: To introduce the idea of decolonization, together with the phenomenon of a gendered and racialized musical canon, both in the historical contexts of European colonization around the world, and in dialogue with decolonizing classical music today across university education and the performing arts.
Indigenous women in classical music, then and now
Session goal: To consider the visibility of indigenous women in classical music, by examining the impact of colonial oppression on their prospects and mobility, along with present challenges and opportunities for their artistic and social empowerment.
Difference
Session goal: To explore the work of queer and non-binary musicians and organizations today, and its significance for articulating difference in classical music and moving on from its colonial past.
II: Equality, diversity, inclusion (EDI)
The second section of the course engages with SDG 10. Students will explore the topic of EDI and related contexts and practices in decolonizing classical music, as well as efforts to reduce systemic, distributive, and discriminatory inequalities through new forms of advocacy.
EDI in classical music: recentering the marginalized
Session goal: To examine the role marginalized voices play in advancing new community projects, social enterprises, and other grassroot initiatives in the decolonization of classical music, with a focus on systemic inequalities stemming from the legacies of music and empire.
EDI in classical music: “de-westernization”
Session goal: To explore the function of regional and local identities in the decolonization and “de-westernization” of classical music, with a focus on distributive inequalities tied to age-old perceptions of “the West and the rest.”
EDI in classical music: creative disability
Session goal: To understand how disabled artists, disability service organizations, and adaptive technologies contribute to creativity disability in the decolonization of classical music, and against an historical backdrop of discriminate inequalities, shaped by Victorian pathological distinctions of “normal” and “abnormal.”
III: Institutions and justice
The third and final section of the course engages with SDG 16. Students will explore the topic of social justice and related contexts and practices in decolonizing classical music, as well as institutional efforts at making classical music more sustainable and reflective of a fair society.
Orchestras in the 21
st
century
Session goal: To explore the orchestra as a decolonising force and public institution, particularly the ways and the extent to which it augments social justice and participation through classical music of the 21
st
century.
Opera companies in the 21
st
century
Session goal: To explore the opera company as a decolonising force and public institution, particularly the ways and the extent to which it augments social justice and participation through classical music of the 21
st
century.

courses.description: (UGEC2171 is double-coded with GRMD2401.)  Sustainable development is a global vision for the future. This approach to development should not only generate economic growth, but also distribute its benefits equitably, regenerate the environment rather than destroy it, as well as empower people rather than marginalize them. The UN 2030 Agenda came into effect in 2015 promising to “interlink and integrate” Sustainable Development Goals in an attempt to implement solutions facing humanity. Sustainable development goals are an all-inclusive invitation to act to end poverty, secure the planet and ensure that all people appreciate peace and prosperity.This course introduces the concept of sustainable development, the evolution of models and the implicit assumptions they make, as well as their contradictions. It also traces the advent of the SDGs and the extent that they support the principles of sustainable development. We examine the emergence of environmental problems and critically review the institutional responses to these problems since the late 1960s. We then consider in detail the increasingly popular idea of efforts in the pursuit of the SDGs from different perspectives that centres around people, planet, prosperity, peace and the partnerships involved in achieving the goals. The lectures will explore how achieving sustainable development goals will depends much on effective planning and good governance. Examples from different parts of the world will be used to underline the tight inter-connections between processes in different regions and across geographical scales in the context of sustainable development.

courses.title: Hong Kong English and its Culture
courses.description: (UGEC2188 is double-coded with ENGE2530.) The objective of this course is to give students an overview of the status, features, and use of Hong Kong English (HKE), the variety of English commonly used in Hong Kong. In the first part of the course, students will be introduced to the concept of ‘world Englishes’ and examine different theoretical frameworks for conceptualizing the evolution of new varieties of English. The course then examines relationship between Hong Kong English and Hong Kong culture from cultural, social, historical, and educational perspectives, particularly in relation to and juxtaposition from Cantonese and Putonghua. The second part of the course examines both spoken and written features of HKE, including grammar, discourse particles, vocabulary, and pronunciation, as well as the practices of code-mixing and code-switching. This section of the course also focuses on the social impact of the use of these features in Hong Kong culture. In the third part of the course, language attitudes and ideologies towards ‘standard’ language varieties (for example American and British English) in relation to HKE will be explored. The course will also examine the relationship between use of HKE and social identity as well as gender in Hong Kong culture.

courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1
• Introduction: syllabus, reading material, teaching method
The first week will introduce students to the course and the course syllabus.
• No reading
Week 2
• Topic: New varieties of English
In week 2, the ‘how’ of Hong Kong English will be discussed, and key frameworks to analyze the evolution of new Englishes will be examined.
•
Reading: Hansen Edwards 2018 Chapter 2
Week 3
• Topic: A social and linguistic history of English in Hong Kong
In week 3, the ‘how’ of Hong Kong English will continued to be examined through the presentation of a social, cultural, and linguistic history of Hong Kong, which emphasizes the history and status of English in Hong Kong society in juxtaposition to both Cantonese and Putonghua.
•
Reading: Hansen Edwards 2018 Chapter 1; Chan, 2002; Evans, 2017
Week 4
• Topic: What’s in a name? Chinglish, Kongish, and Hong Kong English
In week 4, the course will focus on the ‘what’ of Hong Kong English. It will examine and differentiate among three terms often used to describe the English of Hong Kong: Kongish, Chinglish, and Hong Kong English, particular in terms of the social meanings of these terms in Hong Kong culture. These terms will be explored against the frameworks discussed in week 2.
•
Reading: Bolton, 2002; Leung, 2015
Week 5
• Topic: Features of HKE – Pronunciation
Week 5 continues the focus on the ‘what’ of HKE through a discussion of the pronunciation features of HKE. This week also explores the social impact of use of these features in Hong Kong society.
•
Reading: Hansen Edwards 2018 Chapter 7; Deterding, Wong, and Kirkpatrick, 2008
Week 6
• Topic: Features of HKE – Grammar
Week 6 continues the examination of features of Hong Kong English by examining the grammar of HKE. This week also explores the social impact of use of these features in Hong Kong society.
•
Reading: Hansen Edwards 2018 Chapter 7; Sung, 2015
Week 7
• Topic: Features of HKE – Vocabulary
Week 7 focuses on the vocabulary (including discourse particles) of HKE. This week also explores the social impact of use of these features in Hong Kong society.
• Reading: Hansen Edwards 2018 Chapter 7;
New Hong Kong English Words (OED)
Week 8
• Topic: Written and spoken HKE
In week 8, the ‘when’ of HKE will be explored, particularly in relation to spoken vs. written language as well as code-mixing and code-switching. This week also explores the social meaning of code-switching and code-mixing in Hong Kong culture.
•
Reading: Li, 2000; Sung, 2015
Week 9
• Topic: Attitudes towards HKE
In week 9, students will first be introduced to the concepts of ‘language attitudes’ and ‘standard language ideologies’. Attitudes towards HKE both locally and globally will then be examined, particularly in relation to ‘standard’ varieties of English such as American and British English. This essentially explores the ‘why’ of HKE.
•Reading: Hansen Edwards 2018 Chapters 2, 5, 6; Chan, 2016
Week 10
• Topic: HKE and social identity
In week 10, the ‘who’ of HKE will be explored as the discussion focuses on the use of HKE as a social identity marker.
•
Reading: Hansen Edwards 2018 Chapters 3 & 6
Week 11
• Topic: HKE and gender
Week 11 continues the exploration of the ‘who’ of HKE through the examination of gender and HKE.
•
Reading: Hansen Edwards 2018 Chapter 6
Week 12
• Topic: HKE in social media
In week 12, the use of Hong Kong English in social media, including on Facebook and YouTube and by artists such as GYOBN, will be explored. This discussion will also revisit the use of the terms Kongish and Chinglish, and their use by social media in relation to HKE.
•
Reading: Chan, 2015; Li, 2015; Yau, 2016
Week 12
• Topic: Conclusions and revisions
In the final week of the course, a revision of the course content will conducted and final conclusions will be drawn about Hong Kong English.
•
No reading

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: World Englishes and Their Cultures
courses.description: (UGEC2189 is double-coded with ENGE2600.) Although English has long spread around the world, the consequences of this spread are only now beginning to be appreciated by speakers in diverse cultures and societies. English has changed the world, impacting specific local cultures in both positive and negative ways. But English has also been localized and acculturated, made to express the realities of diverse cultures and societies, and so the language has been changed in turn. The discourse of world Englishes aims to re-imagine our understanding of the language. The difference between error and innovation can no longer be decided by reference to ‘ownership’ of the language. Additionally, the language is beginning to be a medium of the expression of identity for more and more people in very different social and cultural contexts. World English must be pluralized, which is why we think in terms of world Englishes. This course is split into two sections. The first section will introduce you to issues in the discourse of world Englishes: innovation, variety, creativity, globalization, etc. The second section will look at specific case studies in different cultures and societies, and will focus on Asian Englishes, e.g. English in Singapore, China, and Japan. Different Asian cultures have distinct historical experiences with English, leading to different levels of cultural penetration (e.g. in popular culture) and depth of function (e.g. in business and law). The second section looks at different examples to explore their specific cultural engagements with the English language, but also to identify what they have in common: Japan English and Singlish develop in very different cultures, but the course with emphasis comparison as well as contrast.

courses.course_syllabus:
introduces popular ideas and linguistic theories about World Englishes;
contextualizes examples of World Englishes, especially in Asian cultures and societies;
builds vocabulary and demonstrates different methods for study in linguistics and culture;
develops a range of study skills relevant to further undergraduate studies in general.
The main topics and regions to be covered are as follows, along with required reading and issues raised:
Introduction:
McWhorter, ‘The cosmopolitan tongue’,
World Affairs Journal
Vol. 172, No. 2 (2009), pp.61-68.
In this week the course will raise general questions about the utility and desirability of a global language. Many have celebrated English as a global language, and the course will consider both positive and negative possibilities that will be investigated using specific examples later in the term.
Histories of English:
Crystal, ‘Why a Global Language?’, from
English as a Global Language
(Cambridge University Press, 2003), pp.1-27.
This week looks back to some of the important histories of how English became a global language, particularly the connections with capitalism and colonialism. It will explore the charge that English today is a form of linguistic imperialism.
Mistakes and Creativity:
Quirk, ‘Language varieties and standard language’,
English Today
21 (1990), pp.3-10.
What do people look for when learning a language? This week wonders why, if we would never imagine World Russians or World Chineses, it seems important to accept World Englishes. We will ask if English still has clearly defined centres of authority, or whether it is now dispersed and plural.
Standards:
Modiano, ‘International English in the Global Village’,
English Today
58 (1999), pp.22-27.
This week’s discussion will focus on the need for standards, and question whether our standards should come from native speakers. Many aspects of international life (scientific discourse, aviation) currently depend on English, but perhaps native speakers are not well placed to help develop these standards. We will think about why that might be true, and how we should test Englishes in future.
English in Asia:
Kachru, ‘English as an Asian Language’,
Links and Letters
5 (1998), pp.89-108.
The focus of the course shifts this week to Asia as a specific example (or series of examples) of the World Englishes. In some ways, English does not appear to belong in Asia, and yet it has clearly been accepted, and we will explore the different ways English functions and has penetrated cultural life.
Singapore:
Ho, ‘“I’m not west. I’m not east. So how leh?”’,
English Today
87 (2006), pp.17-24.
Singapore allows us to think about the general issues clearly because it is a restricted example. Everyone is familiar with Singlish, but what exactly does Singlish show us about the cultural life and social development of this relatively young city-state? The week examines different and sometimes contradictory aspects of English in Singapore.
Japan:
Stanlaw, ‘The dynamics of English words in contemporary Japanese’, from
Japan English
(Hong Kong University Press, 2004), pp.11-37.
Shifting attention from former British colonies, this week explores Japan as an example where English seems to depend on another native speaker country, the United States. However, if we ask how Japanese society and culture actually uses English, far from being dependent on native speaker standards, we see independent creativity.
China:
Hu, ‘Why China English should stand alongside British, American, and the other “World Englishes”’,
English Today
78 (2004), pp.26-33.
Given the rise of China, it is obvious to ask, does China even need English? And does it need a specific China English? Exploring varied examples, this week considers the long history of English in China and some possible futures, in particular of Putonghua alongside English.

courses.description: (UGEC2192 is double-coded with GRMD2292.) The first part of the course will cover the general introductory concepts and provide students with theoretical and historical background of the discipline. This will be followed by in-depth study of specific environmental settings and resource issues that will complement our understanding of ecotourism. Hong Kong is the main focus of discussion though examples or cases in Mainland China and around the world are also provided throughout the course. Critical issues in ecotourism such as its multi-dimensional impacts, governance, planning, and resource and visitor management will also be covered. Lastly, students will be exposed to the relation of the phenomenon of ecotourism and the concept of sustainable tourism. Some of the lectures will address SDGs, for example, Goals 12, 16 and 17 embrace the knowledge and evolution of environmentalism and nature-human relationship; Goals 14 and 15 connect with the concept of protected areas and environmental conservation; Goals 1, 3, 5, 8, 11, 12 and 13 cover multi-dimensional tourism impacts and, more importantly, climate change issue. The concept of sustainable development will frame and conclude the entire course since the concepts has played an indispensable role in tourism development nowadays.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Pursuit of Ideal Living Environment
courses.description: The pursuit of ideal living environment has long been a human undertaking throughout history. Because of environmental variations, some places are definitely better than the others for living and development. In ancient time, man strived for searching a nice place for settlement where could provide a better resource base. Nowadays, man acquires sciences and technologies to change or even create the environment that makes living pleasant and comfortable. Those human settlements which develop an integrated and sustainable approach to the environmental, economic and social challenges will have more chance to grow and prosper.Ideal living environment is closely related with several Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), particularly SDG11 and SDG13 with topics covered in this course. Sustainable cities and communities (SDG 11) directly address the need for safe, inclusive, and resilient living environments. It includes targets for affordable housing, sustainable urban planning, and access to green and public spaces, resilient building. Climate Action (SDG 13) mitigates climate change impacts through sustainable practices which helps protect living environments from extreme weather events and environmental degradation. By focusing on these related SDGs, students can create their ideal living environments by promoting sustainability, enhancing quality of life and addressing climate change challenges that not only meet the needs of current communities that are inclusive, resilient and environmentally friendly, but also ensure sustainability for future generations.This course provides students with the insights needed to gain an understanding of ideal environment for living from the perspective of a geographer. Key themes include searching for the best location, the rise of city, forms of human settlement, ideal living and quality of life. As the course examines the understanding of ideal environment for living from different angles, students will not only gain objective geographical knowledge about the relationship between man and environment, but also learn how some urban challenges and issues are tackled. Ecological civilisation, landscape cities and sustainable development of ideal living environment will also be explored. While the coverage will be broad and pluralistic, examples and cases of Hong Kong, mainland China, and other parts of the world will be emphasized. In order to enhance the learning experience, an interactive teaching mode will be adopted in the lectures so that the instructor can guide students to analyse the cases and issues through discussions.

courses.course_syllabus:
This course portraits an image of ideal living environment from a geographical perspective. Specifically, the following topics under four themes are covered:
THEME 1: SEARCHING FOR THE BEST LOCATION
1. What is an ideal living environment?
This lecture explores where the best living place is on Earth, why is there uneven population and the criteria of an “ideal living environment”.
2. A history of human settlements
This lecture explores how early humans lived, when and where did human migration begin, how were human settlements evolved, why cities emerged and the history of human settlement in Hong Kong.
3. Environmental perception: Components of an “ideal” environment
This lecture explores what is civilisation, where did civilisation take place and why, what were the favourable geographical settings of the ancient capitals and the effectiveness of ‘
Feng shui
’.
THEME 2: THE RISE OF CITY
4. Cities in the world, urbanization and cityscape
This lecture explores the concepts of city and urbanisation, the benefits and problems of cities and their identity.
5. A sustainable city? Climate adaptation and future-proofing a city
This lecture explores the concepts of sustainable development, sustainable cities, climate change and how to live with it.
6. Urban planning and land use: A geographical approach
This lecture explores the basics and rationales of urban planning, and how to plan sustainable cities with case studies.
THEME 3: FORMS OF HUMAN SETTLEMENT
7. Architecture: The interface between man and environment
This lecture explores the basics of architecture, the styles of architecture, the differences between western and Chinese architecture.
8. Interior design: Home sweet home
This lecture explores the basics of interior design, the decision-making process, the elements and principles of interior design and the popular design styles.
9. Garden: A simulation of natural environment
This lecture explores the main types and systems of gardens in the world, the development of Chinese-style gardens, and modern-style gardens.
10. Grave: Home for afterlife
This lecture explores the definition of death, afterlife, rituals and graves as home for afterlife.
THEME 4: IDEAL LIVING AND QUALITY OF LIFE
11. Ideal living and quality of life in Chinese context
This lecture introduces the sciences of human settlements in Chinese context, the five key elements of living environment, and the four stages of city development perspective.
12. Liveability and migration intention
This lecture discusses the most liveable city on Earth, the latest findings of liveable city and sharing experience of overseas living.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Food and Hunger
courses.description: Food is essential for life by providing energy and nutrition and achieving zero hunger is one of 17 Sustainable Development Goals in the United Nations’ 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. The course adopts a multidisciplinary approach to examine the different issues of food and hunger, and how they change over time. The causes of world hunger will be analyzed with special emphasis on food production systems, bearing in mind there is no single solution to the problem. Moreover, the course delves into the economic, social, and environmental dimensions of hunger, examining how issues such as poverty, food insecurity, and climate change intersect to exacerbate the problem. Towards the end of the course, students will gain a deeper understanding of Sustainable Development Goal 2 (Zero Hunger) through an exploration of sustainable agricultural practices and strategies to address global hunger challenges in the 21st century. Lectures will be supplemented with case studies, videos and slides.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Discovering Africa: Environment, Society and Prospects
courses.description: Popular representations of the African continent produced in global discussions are marked by a stereotyped image of Africa, its culture, environment and development. The purpose of this course is to critically examine the common framing of Africa as a continent of conflict, disasters, poverty and a region that is perpetually in need of external intervention. In addition to the myth that surrounds Africa, there is a growing dynamics of activities resulting into the current interest on the continent. Earlier, the UN settled on the Agenda 2030 as a plan of action for people, planet and prosperity for the whole world. This plan dovetails very well with the Africa’s Agenda 2063. This therefore provides an opportunity to identify where Africa situates on SDG issues that include its people, its environment and its economic development.The course will therefore present to students the context of Africa relating to its geography, environment, culture as well as contemporary development issues shaping the destiny of Africa. Through lectures, guest speakers, videos and possibly field studies, students will be able to critically evaluate the stereotypical notion of Africa as a continent rather than as a country as is quite often misconstrued. The course will provide an intellectual platform to understand and analyze issues from a multi-disciplinary perspective as they relate to Africa and humanity. The students will be able to interpret and explain in broad terms, the contemporary position of Africa as it relates to other parts of the world with special attention to its relationship with Asia and China in particular.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Decoding Cities
courses.description: Cities have always been magnets attracting a growing number of citizens. The unprecedented pace of urbanization has recently witnessed a historic shift of human population with the majority now living in cities. The growth of cities in this age of globalization raises many opportunities and challenges, concerning the quality of life, poverty, sustainability, environmental degradation and urban competitiveness. All of which deserve our attention.This course offers students a comprehensive understanding of cities and urban challenges from the perspective of sustainable development. It examines the historical, social, economic, cultural and environmental dimensions of cities. As the course focuses on urban issues at global, regional and local levels, students will not only gain knowledge about the causes and impacts of urban problems, but also learn how different stakeholders can help achieve sustainable liveable cities in the age of globalization. By adopting an issue-based approach, different SDGs such as no poverty (SDG 1), industry, innovation and infrastructure (SDG 9), reduced inequality (SDG 10) and sustainable cities and communities (SDG 11), will be included in a variety of topics ranging from socio-economic to environmental aspects in the course. Different cities will be chosen as case studies for understanding various urban challenges and solutions. Apart from lectures, students will develop critical thinking on various urban challenges that affect their daily lives through video discussion, group projects and presentation in the discussion forums.

courses.learning_outcomes:
This course will offer students a comprehensive understanding of cities and urban challenges. As the course focuses on urban issues from global, regional and local perspectives, students will not only gain basic knowledge of the urban development process, but also learn how urban problems arise. This will be achieved by analysing the complex interaction between the physical environment and human society from the perspective of sustainable development. Parallel to the enrichment of knowledge, students should be able to improve their critical thinking and analytical capability through an issue-based approach in the teaching of this course.
After completing this course, students are expected to:
· be capable of understanding different urban challenges encountered by cities in the age of globalization
· be critical in interpreting sustainable/unsustainable development practices of different cities
· have increased exposure to different SDGs and solutions to urban challenges.
courses.course_syllabus:
By analysing the complex interaction between the physical environment and human society at different levels, students will learn and interpret different urban issues in relation to SDGs in different lectures. The issue of balancing economic growth and development of sustainable cities for all is the main theme that links various lectures.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Hong Kong Cinema
courses.description: (UGEC2241 is double-coded with CURE2030.)  This course is a survey of Hong Kong cinema, with emphasis on its contemporary development. This course will cover both textual and contextual analyses: we treat Hong Kong cinema as an art form and introduce different ways to appreciate them and criticize them; we also read these films as commercial cultural products to investigate links between movies and society at-large. The course will introduce basic film theories and film languages. It helps students to reflect on their own relationship with these Hong Kong movies they grow up with, as well as help elucidate the complex relationship between Hong Kong cinema and Hong Kong identity.
courses.enrollment_requirement:

Not for Cultural Studies; Public Humanities, Religious Studies Majors; and students who have taken CURE2030 or UGEC2774.

courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to acquire a general understanding of basic film languages, and to develop basic skill in film appreciation and film criticism. After the course students should be able to understand Hong Kong history and
Hong Kong
society from the perspective of cinema, with critical awareness of related issues pertaining to gender, class, and cultural identity. They are also expected to understand the intimate relationship between film production and film consumption, as well as the differences and connections between art and commerce in the domain of
Hong Kong
cinema.
courses.course_syllabus:
The lectures are organized historically, allowing students to gain a full picture of not only Hong Kong cinema’s history but also the history of Hong Kong. Students will also learn the basic techniques of film appreciation and film criticism through the various examples introduced. Lectures are composed of lecturer’s presentation and close analysis of selected film clips, through which students will be called attentions to specific stylistic, thematic, and theoretical issues. Combining the lectures and film analysis, students will learn both specific issues about Hong Kong cinema and acquire basic training of film analysis.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Living in the Anthropocene: Nature, Culture and Power
courses.description: (UGEC2243 is double-coded with CURE2018.)  Human have altered the environment in ways that have no precedence in human history. Ecological crisis, environmental degradation, and extreme weathers have become the watchwords of contemporary politics. The conventional boundaries between “nature” and “culture” are now being questioned. How do nature, culture and power intersect in our everyday life? How do we get to understand issues of sustainability and environmental crisis from a broad historical perspective and global activism angle? How are gender, class and race interact with technology, damaged environment, animal and plant species? This course explores these questions and the rich debates in the emerging field of environmental humanity and literature of the Anthropocene.Class topics are organized on major global green movements that resisted oil pollution, toxic factories, logging companies, dam constructions and nuclear plant building. Students get to learn the historical developments of major environmental activism in the West and the global south. How was the Greenpeace founded? What is the Narmada Dam Movement in India? Do you know Ken Saro-Wiwa, an environmental activist against Shell oil pollution in Nigeria? In each class we examine historical texts, visual materials and theoretical debates to explore how environmental justice has been intertwined with histories of colonialism, neoliberalism, and questions of gender, race, poverty and class. Together the class explores the problem of the Anthropocene (Nature) in the context of colonial history, grass root struggles (Culture) and corporation greed (Power).This course addresses many of the 17 United Nation Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs): Climate Actions (13), Life on Land (15), Life below Water (14), Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions (16), Clean Energy (7), Reduced Inequalities (10), and Gender Inequality (5). Students are able to identify the weekly course content aligned with specific SDGs and be able to understand these goals in both historical and contemporary contexts.

Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:
Acquire knowledge on major environmental struggles and movements in the West and the Global South
Comprehend the historical relationships between ecological crisis, colonialism and corporate politics
Analyze the current ecological crisis using the concept of slow violence
Evaluate the scientific debates of the Anthropocene with knowledge and analysis from the field of environmental humanities.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Celebrity, Stardom, and Hong Kong Popular Culture
courses.description: (UGEC2245 is double-coded with CURE2007.) Celebrity culture is generally understood as a cult full of short-lived trends and inconsequential fan behaviour. We seldom consider, however, the powerful influence it has over our cultural identities. This course examines how the interplay between celebrity culture and the cultural industry shapes cultural identity with case studies from Hong Kong as the major scope of study. Starting with a brief history of Hong Kong celebrity culture from the 1980s to the present day, the course offers an entry point for students to understand the intricate relationship between the media and celebrity culture, encompassing a wide range of cultural icons and phenomena such as action film actors, cross-media megastars, and YouTube micro-celebrities. Each case study will engage with key concepts in celebrity culture, such as star-text, commodification, authenticity, extratextual reading, and participatory reading. The course proceeds by introducing the critical perspective of cultural studies in making sense of representation politics, public culture, fandom studies, and the diverse modes of intimacy in the digital age. Overall, students will gain an understanding of celebrity culture and how identities are thus produced, promoted, and commodified in the wider arena of media and popular culture.

courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the subject, students will be able to:
Define and explain
the connotation of celebrity culture, stardom, and popular culture in contemporary society, and the genealogy of discourses development of Hong Kong popular culture over time.
Understand
on how cultural identities are shaped by the interplay between celebrity culture and the popular culture industry.
Employ
a selected range of methods to study the development and formation of celebrity culture and infer the meaning of such process in the Hong Kong context.
Reflect
on the impact of celebrity culture on the formation of cultural identities.
Demonstrate
the intersectionality of celebrity culture and the formation of cultural identities locally and globally.
courses.course_syllabus:
Class 1 Introduction: Why Does Celebrity Culture Matter?
Introducing the basics of celebrity culture and the importance of studying celebrity and stardom
Outlining the development timeline of Hong Kong celebrity culture from the 1980s to the 2020s
Class 2 Star Image and Star Text: Bruce Lee
Analysing the production and consumption of film stars and their star image
Synthesizing the critical concepts of ‘star-text’ in celebrity studies and ‘textual analysis’ in cultural studies
Assessing Bruce Lee as a star text in relation to the concept of ‘representation’
Integrating the case of Bruce Lee with the identity formation of Hong Kongers as modern citizens
Class 3 The Social Phenomenon of Stars: Leslie Cheung
Discussing the critical concept of ‘extratextual reading’ in celebrity studies
Assessing Leslie Cheung as a star text in relation to the concept of queer stardom and posthumous fame.
Integrating the case of Leslie Cheung with the identity formation of Hong Kongers as cosmopolitan
Class 4 Discussion Panel (I)
Students will work in groups to create a presentation about their favourite Hong Kong film star. Presentations should be submitted online via Blackboard.
Each group will then be assigned to review another group’s presentation. They will analyze the assigned work and apply
one concept
from Class 1-3 in their critique.
Class 5 Cross-media Megastar (1): Anita Mui
Interpreting the concept of ‘commodification’ in cultural studies in relation to Anita Mui's on-screen persona.
Demonstrating the influence of popular music on stardom and celebrity culture
Class 6 Cross-media Megastar (2): Twins
Theorizing ‘celebrity-commodity’ in celebrity studies and mapping the culture industry in the 2000s
Examining how the industry of popular culture in Hong Kong gives rise to cross-media megastars
Evaluating ways in which the stardom of the cross-media megastar influences the formation of Hong Kong cultural identity
Class 7 On the Politics of Authenticity: ‘Real’ Celebrity and Reality Shows
Discussing the concept of ‘authenticity’ in celebrity studies and media studies.
Critiquing how television channels have produced stars and singers via talent shows and reality shows from 2000s to 2010s
Comparing two local TV shows, Minutes to Fame (殘酷一叮) and Good Night Show – King Maker (全民造星) in their creation of ‘ordinary celebrities’
Class 8 Discussion Panel (II)
Students will work in groups to create a presentation about their favourite Hong Kong singer. Presentations should be submitted online via Blackboard.
Each group will then be assigned to review another group’s presentation. They will analyze the assigned work and apply
one concept
from Class 5-7 in their critique.
Class 9 Stars, Consumption, and Public Culture (1): Anthony Wong, Anson Lo, and Jeremy Lee
Discussing the concepts of ‘celebrity consumption’ and ‘participatory reading’
Examining the ‘campness’ of the star image of Anthony Wong, Anson Lo, and Jeremy Lee
Integrating the practice of ‘queer reading’ to complicate concepts of celebrity culture
Class 10 Stars, Consumption, and Public Culture (2): Denise Ho, Kay Tse, and Charmaine Fong
Demonstrating celebrity consumption as a fundamental part of public culture
Exploring how celebrities engage with fans in the public arena
Assessing the star text and fandom of Denise Ho, Kay Tse, and Charmaine Fong in relation to the identity formation of Hong Kongers from 2010s to 2020s.
Class 11
Stars in the Era of Platform Culture
Examining the availability of media platforms (e.g. Instagram, YouTube) and convergence media culture
Evaluating changes in the celebrity culture alongside convergence culture
Reflect on how convergence culture influences the formation of Hong Kong identity
Case study: Serrin/ Leung Ka-yan (梁嘉茵) and Trial & Error (試當真)
Class 12 Discussion Panel (III)
Students will work in groups to create a presentation about their favourite Hong Kong micro-celebrity. Presentations should be submitted online via Blackboard.
Each group will then be assigned to review another group’s presentation. They will analyze the assigned work and apply
one concept
from Class 9-11 in their critique.
Class 13 The Trans-Asian Influence of J-pop and K-pop Culture to Hong Kong
Evaluating the trans-Asian influence of J-pop and K-pop on Hong Kong celebrity culture in terms of industry, star images, and styles.
Case study: Cookies and Mirror

courses.title: Feminisms: Thoughts and Movements
courses.description: (UGEC2273 is double-coded with CURE2022.)  A long-lasting struggle of gender equity was triggered by the women’s movements in England and U.S in the end of 19th century. Feminists fight for equality by publications, demonstrations and organizations. In 20th century, the feminist movement matured. Feminists have been more sensitive to the differences among women of different race, class, culture, religion and circumstances and noticed the importance of differences in unity. This course will introduce the strategies and main arguments of various kinds of feminism. Through learning from others’ experience, history and our daily life, we will understand the development of diversity in feminisms. We can have more understanding of feminists fighting for the right of disadvantage groups by self-review and mutual criticism in different times and culture.

courses.title: Xiqu and Culture
courses.description: (UGEC2294 is double-coded with CURE2042.)  The course introduces the student a basic knowledge of Xiqu (Chinese Opera), including its artistic features as a performing art, and the characteristics of different kinds of local Xiqu, such as Beijing Opera, Kunqu, Shanghai Opera and Cantonese Opera. Based on the basic knowledge of the art-form, we will discuss the cultural issues reflecting in the plays and performances. Through the textual analysis of scripts and performances, students will be introduced different topics of Xiqu related to cultural studies.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Lingnan: History and Society
courses.description: Lingnan is located in the south of the Five Ridges, the mountain areas running from east to west that serve as a clear geographical and cultural demarcation between South and Central China. Lingnan plays a significant role in the historical development of Modern China. This course aims to overview 500 years of interweaving between Lingnan region, state and the world from the perspective of business, migration, knowledge and culture in the long-term history to understand Lingnan and enhance cultural recognition. At the same time, this course combines archival studies and fieldtrips. Besides discovering history through archive material, we will also visit museums, villages, temples, communities, and enterprises. Through contact with cultural and historical sites, students can deepen their understanding and perception of the social and cultural history of Lingnan. Students from the Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK) and the Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen (CUHKSZ) will jointly enroll in this course to promote cultural exchange and enhance mutual understanding. The course assessment methods will consist of individual assignments and group projects.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for History Majors.
Co-requisite: UGFH1000 or UGFN1000 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Develop a basic command of Lingnan history and deepen their understandings of Lingnan.
Acquire an understanding of the relations between Lingnan, China and the world and examine the openness and inclusiveness of Lingnan from historical perspectives.
Become familiar with some historical research methods and understand the opportunities and challenges in Greater Bay Area.

courses.course_syllabus:
1. Course in Shenzhen (3 days)
1. 1 【1
st
day morning】L01: 導論 (lecture: 3 hours)
主要內容：
嶺南的自然環境、歷史地理、人口民系等基本情況
歷史上中央王朝在嶺南地區的行政管理
明清嶺南的土地開發與宗族建構
議題：
嶺南在哪裡？
國家與嶺南的關係是什麼？
嶺南地區為何在明清時期進入快速發展時期？
1. 2 【1
st
day afternoon】L02: 世界貿易中的嶺南 (lecture: 3 hours)
主要內容：
朝貢貿易
16至18世紀的海上貿易
廣州制度（一口通商）
議題：
大航海時代之前嶺南與世界的貿易關係是怎樣的？
大航海時代對嶺南與世界的貿易網絡產生了什麼影響？
1. 3 【2
nd
day morning】L03: 全球化與嶺南移民 (lecture: 3 hours)
主要內容：
十九、二十世紀的嶺南移民：華商、華工與留學生
個案：深圳的海外移民、故事與記憶
議題：
深圳移民與嶺南、中國及世界的關係
1. 4 【2
nd
day afternoon】L04: 走向世界的「廣東文化」(lecture: 3 hours)
主要內容：
「廣東文化」的歷史建構過程
唐人街中的廣東元素
粵菜、粵劇的海外舞台
議題：
何謂「廣東文化」？
海外移民帶出去了哪些廣東文化？
如何認識廣東文化在海外的塑造與傳播？
1. 5 【3
rd
day morning】L05: 移民社會的包容與認同：改革開放的深圳經驗 (lecture: 3 hours)
主要內容：
深圳改革開放的人口變遷與移民政策
深圳城中村發展與城鄉身份轉型
深圳移民的個體經驗與口述歷史
議題：
誰是深圳人？
如何做一名深圳人？
1. 6 【3
rd
day afternoon】延伸討論：深圳田野考察 (4 hours)
主要內容：
理解小歷史與大歷史之間的關係
認識嶺南鄉村的族群、移民、經濟與文化等議題
認識深圳改革開放的歷史成就等
議題：
考察對象如何體現了嶺南地區與世界的聯繫？
如何從微觀史視角認識嶺南歷史？

courses.title: History of Western Comics
courses.description: (UGEC2317 is double-coded with FAAS2116.) This course traces the history of comics and graphic novels in Western Europe and North America. Beginning with an introduction presenting the main characteristics of this medium, this course will trace its development, from the beginnings of storytelling with images in Antiquity to the latest innovations. Even though they have retained their own characteristics over the last two centuries, Western European and North American comics have also developed in close proximity. Following the development of the press and book industry, as well as other media like cinema, comics and graphic novels have a rich history that can only be understood in their cultural context. This course is designed to allow students to understand how this medium has shaped and been shaped by many aspects of the history and cultures of these places.

courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction: What is Sequential Art
How to identify the characteristics of the medium know as ‘comics’
Why the concept of ‘sequential art’ is a more comprehensive way to define the medium of ‘comics’
How academic authors understand the notion of sequential art
Historical Precedents of Sequential Storytelling
How comics in their modern form emerged from other art forms from the past
Origins of sequential story telling from Antiquity to the early 19
th
century
European Precursors
How European precursors redefined sequential storytelling
Europe until the late 19
th
century: the main source of original comics
first full-fledged practitioner of this medium, Rodolphe Töpffer (1840-1846)
influence of other media on comics (in particular new printing technology and cinema)
North American Early Comics
How full-fledged comics emerged in North America
Emigration of many artists to North America in the late 19
th
century
The comics strip in commercial context of the mass media (newspapers)
European Early Comics
How comics became mainstream in Western Europe, from the beginning of the 20
th
century to the inter-war period.
Thriving publication industry that grew through specialization
Specialized for children and young persons
A few exceptions of more adult-oriented comics
North American Golden Age
How comics grew to become a thriving global industry
The new superpower status of the United States gave to American comics a global reach
Mickey Mouse, Popeye the sailor become world-wide influences
The period sees the creation of an entire culture of superheroes symbolizing American global dominance in the realm of popular culture
European Golden Age
Less globally influential at first, European comics also become globally significant
New European comics under the influence of North American culture
Other European comics developed as original creations that also enjoyed a global readership
Growth of a comics industry geared towards an adult readershop
North American Renaissance: Underground Comix
How the North American counterculture redefined the medium of comics
End of the censorship on comics imposed in the 1950s
Expansion of the possibilities and public of the medium
Influence on the present
European Renaissance: the 1970s and beyond
How both mainstream and counterculture began to expand the field of comics
More gradually than in North America, comics became a medium for an adult readership
Creation of many independent comics publishers and magazines
Growing literary ambitions of comics creators
Comics become an accepted field of academic research
Reshaping the Medium
How the new directions initiated after the 1970s became a global explorations of new forms and contents
Comics become a highly literate field of artistic creation: the advent of the graphic novel
The influence of academic research on the medium
The influence of new technologies on comics creation

courses.title: Globalization, Cultures and Societies
courses.description: (UGEC2351 is double-coded with GLSD2201.) Culture is in the air that we breathe and it is inevitable that people construct reality through their own 'cultural lens'. However, in this globalization era, people often have many cultural lenses. Through understanding the impact of globalization on cultures and societies, we will have nuanced understanding of how people from different cultures construct reality. Many scholars and activists argue that globalization will lead to a worldwide homogenized consumer culture dominated by Western values. Others believe that globalization can lead to the clashes of incorrigible cultures. Meanwhile, globalization has catalyzed formation of new hybrid cultures and fostered the blooming of creative cultural industries. In this course, we will explore the above topics through understanding the effects of globalization on personal identities, the economy, consumerism, and communication, etc. in the immediate and distal environment.

courses.title: Global Politics
courses.description: (UGEC2352 is double-coded with GLSD2301.) This course aims to provide a comprehensive introduction to global politics, focusing in particular on its origins and historical evolution, its key concepts, major theoretical frameworks, main actors and institutions, the global architecture of power, and its dynamic nature in the process of globalization. It aims to offer students with the basic knowledge and analytical tools for making sense of current issues in global politics. It adopts a multi-disciplinary approach that integrates theoretical issues with regional case studies. The course will first offer a general survey of the key concepts and major theoretical perspectives in the study of Global Politics (Liberalism, Realism, Social Constructivism and Marxist theory, etc.). It then proceeds to cover selected topics of global politics in the areas of War and Peace and the Clash of Civilization. It focuses on how world politics is transformed by globalization, with a particular focus on its impacts on issues concerning the identity and national pride, balance of power, peace and conflicts, borders and security, etc. Finally, the course will be concluded with the discussion of latest trends of global governance, with a particular focus on the emergency of international and regional organizations. Relevant real world examples and case studies will be adopted to illustrate the big ideas and key concepts of global politics.This course intends to promote students’ appreciation of the role of ‘power’, ‘security’ and ‘justice’ in shaping the global political order nowadays. Students will gain deeper insights into not only latest developments in global political affairs, but also concepts and theories useful for further studies in politics, international relations, and global political economy. The course is designed to introduce essential concepts, major theoretical perspectives and basic mechanisms of global political order, allowing students to communicate issues in world politics effectively in group work and individually, in oral as well as written forms.

courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:
1. 
Describe the evolution of the global political order and identify how power relations is related to the peace and security of world politics;
2. 
Understand and apply the basic concepts, theories and analytical approaches of global politics in understanding the interactions between states as well as the dynamics of the competition among great powers;
3. 
Critically analyze the basic characteristics, process and institutions of global political order in
national, regional and international
levels;
4. 
Describe and analyze the roles and functions of major international institutions and organizations, such as United Nations, in maintaining global peace and security;
5. 
Analyze the role of the nation-states in the context of the globalized world
6. 
Engage in debates on controversial world issues and reflect critically on different viewpoints
; and
7. 
Develop better cross-cultural and geopolitical awareness necessary for a global citizen.
If possible, seminar by invited guest will be arranged to provide students with insights into the debates and controversies in contemporary global political order.

courses.title: World Economic Order
courses.description: (UGEC2353 is double-coded with GLSD2501.) This course aims to provide students the foundational knowledge on the operation of world economy and examine how social, political and institutional factors contribute to the creation of global economic order. It examines the intertwining and interaction of economics (wealth creation) and politics (political power) in global affairs.The course will first offer a general survey of the key concepts and major theoretical perspectives in the study of Global Political Economy (GPE) (Liberalism, Mercantilism, and Marxist theory, etc.). In the second part, we cover substantive policy issues including international trade and monetary system, foreign investment and multi-national corporations, etc.. It focuses on how the world economy is transformed by globalization, with a particular focus on the development of various international and regional institutions that govern the current economic order. Finally, the course will be concluded with the discussion of latest trends of global economic governance, with a particular focus on the transforming role of national states and the endeavors of international development on poverty and inequality reduction. Relevant country experiences will be adopted to illustrate the dynamics of economic growth and stability. GLSD2501 intends to promote students’ appreciation of the role of institutions and politics in the operation of global economic order. Students are not required to have any background in the discipline for the course is designed to introduce essential concepts, major theoretical perspectives and basic operations of modern world economy, allowing students to communicate issues in world economic order effectively in group work and individually, in oral as well as written forms.

courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:
1. 
Describe the evolution of the world economic order and identify how different factors contribute to the growth and stability of world economy;
2. 
Understand the basic concepts, theories and analytical approaches in understanding the power relations that underlie world economic order;
3. 
Critically analyze the basic characteristics, process and operation of modern world economy and its interaction with
national, regional and international
politics and institutions
;
4. 
Describe and analyze the roles and functions of major international institutions and organizations, such as IMF, WTO, and World Bank, etc.;
5. 
Analyze the role of the nation-states in the context of the globalized economy; and
6. 
Critically reflect the role and impacts of global capitalism on human society, less developed countries and socio-economic development;
If possible, seminar by invited guest will be arranged to provide students with insights into the debates and controversies in contemporary world economy.

courses.recommended_readings:
FOUR Basic Reference Texts are selected for this course. TWO textbooks are chosen to provide theoretical basis for analysis on global political economy respectively; while the remaining are more advanced textbooks on the economic analysis of global politics [The textbook is available in library (semi-close reserve) and university bookstore.].
1. 
* Ravenhill, J. (2012). Global Political Economy. N.Y.: Oxford University Press.
2. 
* O'Brien, R. & M. Williams (2016). Global Political Economy: Evolution & Dynamics. London: Palgrave.
3. 
Cohn, T. H. (2016). Global Political Economy: Theory and Practice. 7th Edition. London: Routledge.
4. 
Rochon, L-P. and S. Rossi (2016). An Introduction to Macroeconomics: a Heterodox Approach to Economic Analysis. Cheltenham: Edward Elgar Publishing
5. 
Gilpin, R. (2001). Global Political Economy: Understanding the International Economic Order. Princeton, N. J.: Princeton University Press.
The first two textbooks have provided broadly based introduction to global political economy. They examine almost all of the general ideas covered in the lectures and thereby are widely adopted by tertiary institutions as teaching textbooks. However, a notable limitation of them is that they draw most examples from America and Europe when explaining those concepts and thus the students who are not familiar with American and European political economy may be frustrated by their description. To balance this, the instructor will provide Asian examples in the lecture materials.
