courses.required_readings:
Working Class I: Gender in the Global Factory
Work-places are social institutions that reproduce various relationships of society. By analyzing international technology hardware-production in Mexico, we will see how different ways of task organization, hiring practices, and promotion regimes shape gendered production as much as class and gender relations beyond the factory.
Salzinger, Leslie. 2003. "Chapter 1: Ways of Seeing", "Chapter 4: Bringing Fantasies to Life: Panoptimex" + "Chapter 5: Re-formulating the 'Traditional Mexican Woman': Particimex". In: Genders in Production: Making Workers in Mexico's Global Factories. Berkeley: University of California Press.
Working Class II: Race in Migration
Following high-skilled IT-workers from India to Berlin this ethnography explores how immaterial work in an office can be embodied and ascribed to race rather than skill. Understanding work and its hierarchies within transnational and local class aspirations and shifting racial stereotypes, we will explore the experience of work as both empowering and discriminatory.
Amrute, Sareeta. 2016. "Introduction: Cognitive Bodies, Cognitive Work (until p. 18)", "Chapter 2: The Postracial Body". In: Encoding Race, Encoding Class. Indian IT Workers in Berlin. Durham: Duke University Press.
Working Place and Space
All work-places exist in multiples spaces from global markets, supply chains, nation-states, to cities. Through the case of women working the night shift in Mumbai's call-center industry, we will see how social mobility and the roles of women in relations of work, leisure, family, and self are impacted by social norms of who should work at night.
Patel, Reena. 2010. "Introduction (until p. 18)", "Chapter 4: Traveling at Night". In: Working the Night Shift: Women in India's Call Center Industry. Stanford: Stanford University Press.
Working Time
Time is crucial for structuring work and pay. Contemporary work often reorganizes time and new, flexible time regimes revolutionize our understanding of the work day. This week explores, on the one hand, time as valuable or wasted in the contemporary NGO-industry. On the other hand, we will look at time in terms of flexibility, autonomy, but also as source of anxiety for independent taxi drivers in New York.
Sheldon, Zachary. 2021. "Managing the Humanitarian Workplace: Capitalist Social Time and Iraqi Refugees in the United States." In: Anthropology of Work Review 42 (1 ): 35- 46.
Occhiuto, Nicolas. 2017. "Investing in Independent Contract Work: The Significance of Schedule Control for Taxi Drivers". In: Work and Occupations 44(3): 268 - 295.
Working Self
Work is often not just a job, but a part of ourselves. But where are the boundaries between work as what we do or who we are? Through the case of sex workers in San Francisco, we will discuss themes of authenticity in customer relations, alienation, self-fulfilment, control, and abuse in service work.
Bernstein, Elizabeth. 2007. "Chapter 4: The Privatization of Public Women". In: Temporarily Yours - Intimacy, Authenticity, and the Commerce of Sex. Chicago: University of Chicago Press.
Working Service
Similar service work like taking care of people can take place in drastically different settings from someones house to a luxury hotel. While some workers perform their duties in public, others are confined to the domestic and intimate spaces of other people's living spaces. By contrasting the management of domestic helpers in Hong Kong with luxury hotel workers in San Francisco, we will think about how work discipline and evaluation influences performance, but also how the setting of work allows or prevents abuse.
Constable, Nicole. 2017. "Chapter 5: Household Rules and Relations." In: Maid to Order in Hong Kong: Stories of Migrant Workers. Ithaca: Cornell University Press.
Sherman, Rachel. 2007. "Chapter 2: Managing Autonomy." In: Class Acts- Service and Inequality in Luxury Hotels. Berkeley: University of California Press.
Working Craft
Practices and skill of work are often passed on, refined, and perfected through generations of practitioners. The skill of artisans and craft-workers has often been romanticized as traditional and pure. Through the reinvention of bartenders as highly skilled and creative makers in postindustrial New York, this week aims to understand how professions transform, become 'cool', and reinvent themselves.
Ocejo, Richard. 2017. “Introduction: A Stroll through the Market” + “Chapter 1: The Cocktail Renaissance”. In: R. Ocejo. Masters of Craft: Old Jobs in the New Urban Economy. Princeton: Princeton University Press.
Working on Demand
What is creativity? What is a copy? Exploring the world of the now famous, hand-painting makers of oil painting reproductions in Dafen village, we will see what makes an artist or a worker, as well as the shifting boundary between copyrights and copy.
Wong, Winnie. 2014. "Introduction: After the Copy (until p. 22)" + "Chapter 4: Step 18: 'Sign Vincent"'[selections]. In: Van Gogh on Demand - China and the Readymade. Chicago: University of Chicago Press.
Working Platforms
Social media platforms drastically transform employment relationships, modes of contract and payment, but also meanings of profession and occupation. Through the online communities and marketplaces of game designers and car sharing drivers, we will see how work becomes more individualized or more embedded online.
Schwartz, David. 2018. “Embedded in the Crowd: Creative Freelancers, Crowdsourced Work, and Occupational Community”. In: Work and Occupations 45 (3). Pp. 255-282.
Surie, Aditi and Jyothi Koduganti. 2016. “The Emerging Nature of Work in Platform Economy: Companies in Bengaluru, India: The Case of Uber and Ola Cab Drivers”. In: International and Comparative Labour Studies 5(3): 1 – 30.
Working for Free?
Why do we work for free? Is that even possible? By looking at seemingly 'un-worklike' activities of women and promoters in the international party circuits, we ask how we can understand work beyond traditional relations of employment or exchange.
Mears, Ashley. 2020. "Chapter 3: The Potlach" + "Chapter 4: Trafficking at Model Camp". In: Very Important People - Status and Beauty in the Global Party Circuit. Princeton: Princeton University Press.
Working Skill
Who has skills? What are skills? Understanding the complex social organization of building football stadiums in Qatar, this week explores how people know what to do if it has never been done before. We will further understand skill as embodied practice and matter of recognition.
lskander, Natasha. 2021. "Chapter 3: How Skill is Embodied ... ". In: Does Skill Make Us Human? Migrant Workers in 21st Century Qatar and Beyond. Princeton: Princeton University Press.
Working Capitalism
Is all work productive? Is all work meaningful? Through this critique of contemporary capitalism as unproductive system, we will discuss the meaning of work and how to imagine new work practices in the future.
Graeber, David. 2018. "Chapter 1: What is a Bullshit Job" + "Chapter 4: What is it like to have a Bullshit Job?". Bullshit Jobs -A Theory. New York: Anholt & Schuster. Selections.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Ethnographies of Japan
courses.description: (UGEC2657 is double-coded with ANTH2327.) This course provides an introduction to contemporary Japanese society and culture. In the popular imagination, Japan occupies a complex and often contradictory position. It is home to futuristic anime and an aging population, picturesque villages and dolphin hunts, high-end cameras and the widespread use of quaint fax machines. Engaging with anthropological literature, students will learn to analyze, discuss, and write about various issues and cultural features of Japan, including youth, popular culture, self, family, labor, medicine, and health. An overarching theme will be how Japanese culture and society is changing in the transition to a highly aged society. We will examine persistent cultural patterns as well as the emergence of new forms of social life as residents of Japan grapple with smaller families, precarity, migration, and a rising population of older people. Students will learn how to apply theoretical concepts from anthropology and think critically about Japanese culture and its portrayals in the media. The ethnographic approaches and theoretical perspectives covered in this class will be applicable to other cultural contexts. Since Hong Kong, China, and Korea are following Japan’s path of population aging, this course provides an opportunity to explore cultural issues that have a local and regional significance.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEC2657 is double-coded with ANTH2327.
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2327.
Co-requisite: Any course with "UGFH" or "UGFN" as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students will acquire a robust knowledge of contemporary Japanese society and culture. They will develop an understanding of cultural diversity within Japan and the broad shifts associated with population aging.
Students will gain the ability to apply anthropological theory to analyze Japanese society and culture. In conjunction, students will learn to critically evaluate scholarly and media portrayals of Japan. These critical faculties will also be relevant for understanding their own or other societies in daily life as well as for future anthropological studies.
Students will develop their writing skills. In addition to conventional academic essays, students will learn to write ethnographically about a specific site. Through writing, students will gain skills in communication of their own observations and perspectives on cultural features. These skills can be used for further academic study as well as personal and professional life.
courses.course_syllabus:
Part I: Foundations of Japanese Culture and Society
Week 1. What is Japanese culture?
This lesson introduces the concept of culture and gives a brief history on the sociocultural and geographical boundaries of Japan.
Week 2. Foundational Works
This lesson provides students with an introduction to early major writings about Japan, including early European and American visitors to Japan.
Week 3. Myths of Japaneseness
This session will examine of common media tropes about Japan and the pseudo-scholarly genre of writing known as
Nihonnjinron
. It explores forms of ethnocentricism, conceptions of cultural uniqueness, and nationalism in post WWII Japan.
Week 4. Traditions and Inventions
This session focuses on the ways that traditions created and how people use them to give meaning to life. Through a discussion of
bushido
, the class will illuminate the recent invention of traditions popularly considered ancient and timeless in Japan.
Week 5. Health and the Body
The session provides a conceptual overview of how people in Japan understand their bodies, health, and illness. Particular attention will be paid to longevity and issues involved in aging.
Week 6. Gift-giving and Ritual
An exploration of situational, lifecycle, and calendar-based gift-giving and ritual in contemporary Japan.
II. The Life Cycle in an Aging Japan
Week 7. Love, Marriage, and Children
This session provides an overview of romantic relationships, including non-heteronormative relationships, and reasons for low fertility in Japan. Romance in late life will also be part of the discussion.
Week 8. Childhood and Schooling
Focusing on preschool through high school, this session examines the ways children are taught to become adults in Japanese society.
Week 9. Cute and
Otaku
This class explores the origins of subcultures in Japan and how they are co-opted by the state and companies. It will highlight the ways that young people’s participation in these subcultures receives blame for low fertility.
Week 10. Labor, Precarity, and Class
This session is an examination of the changes in Japanese labor following WWII in relation to security, gender, and socioeconomic class. It will highlight how precarious working conditions lead individuals to delay or avoid marriage and having children.
Week 11. Gender
Students will learn about how gender intersects with family, work, and social roles. This session will highlight conventional roles of the male “salaryman” and the housewife, paying attention to female caregiving for older family members.
Week 12. Aging and the End of Life
This session examines the experiences of late life ideals for death .
Week 13. Atomic Radiation and the Plight of Older People after Fukushima
A broad discussion of Japan complicated relationship with radioactive decay, including atomics bombs, Godzilla, and the meltdown in Fukushima. Particular attention will be paid to case of aging survivors of the atomic bombs and older people’s communities displaced after the disasters following the earthquake on 11.3.2011.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Culture and Business
courses.description: (UGEC2662 is double-coded with ANTH2510.)  Culture is ubiquitous in every aspect of societies, including how we do business. This course will examine the role of culture in contemporary business and study work and management in industrial societies anthropologically. Students will be introduced to the cultural logics of business practices, particularly business operations, organization and management through ethnographic explorations of different cultures, locales and sociohistorical settings. The aims of the course are twofold. First, it reveals cultural aspects and the cultural mechanisms of business. It shows the significance of culture in the business world, as well as the cultural significance of business. Second, it attempts to put anthropology into business practice. It demonstrates to students how anthropological knowledge and methodologies can be applied to business operations and help to achieve business goals. By examining the themes including but not limited to the indoctrination of work ethics, labor relations, gender and racial issues in the workplace, capitalism and its discontents, and responses to and actions upon market capitalism in terms of both production and consumption, the course attends to these Sustainable Development Goals: No Poverty (SDG#1), Gender Equality (SDG#5), Decent Work and Economic Growth (SDG#8), Reduced Inequalities (SDG#10), Responsible Consumption and Production (SDG#12), and Partnerships for the Goals (SDG#17).

courses.course_syllabus:
The course is structured in three parts.
Part I Culture in Business
explores the cultural dimensions of workplaces and corporate management. We begin with an overview of the temporal and spatial reconfigurations since industrialization in order to discern modern work ethics, followed by explorations of dynamics in the workplace. Next, we will explore discourses in shaping corporate operations and management, and consider (and challenge) the ideas of economization, maximization, auditing and accountability. This part decodes life in business settings, and practices in corporations.
Part II Business Ventures in the Globalizing World
situates the discussions in current trends of capitalism. We will look into what makes us buy and spend, and how traditional values and modern business practices mingle. It raises the question of whether we are really emancipated under the fashion of decentralization by exploring the gig economy and the phenomenon of self-enterprising. We will also examine how we can build a more inclusive, diverse and equal society by finding a new way out from the existing business ideologies and practices.
Part III Anthropology and the Business World
discusses how to apply anthropology in business settings, looking into how and why anthropology and anthropologists are important to the private sector, and broadly speaking, to the modern capitalist world. The course concludes by contemplating whether business is really business.
Overall, through the examinations of how we are taught to work, produce, and buy, the imperative of gender and racial stereotypes in the workplace, turns in capitalism and the rise of new economies and the pertinent social and cultural phenomena, the course addresses the following Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs): No Poverty (SDG#1), Gender Equality (SDG#5), Decent Work and Economic Growth (SDG#8), Reduced Inequalities (SDG#10), Responsible Consumption and Production (SDG#12), and Partnerships for the Goals (SDG#17).

courses.title: Sports and Culture
courses.description: (UGEC2664 is double-coded with ANTH2390.)This course will examine the role and importance of sports in different societies and cultures, in the present and the past. Sports are often thought of as trivial, or as unimportant games to amuse young people. But in the wealthiest countries, sports represent huge portions of GDP and are important topics of daily conversation. Almost half the world watched the 2010 football/soccer World Cup. Sports have been compared to religions in their ability to unite people and to inspire fanatical devotion.The academic study of sports is interdisciplinary, with contributions from psychologists, historians, gender studies scholars, sociologists and anthropologists. This course will take an interdisciplinary approach while emphasizing anthropology’s focus on culture, on the experience of participants, and on both symbolic and political-economy aspects of sports. Topics will include Race and Performance, Sports and Rituals, Sports as Moral Education, Gender and Sexuality in Sport, Sports and Nationalism, Globalization of Sport, the Olympics, and Sports Stars and the Media. Students will be expected to do a research project for the course.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Social Media and Culture
courses.description: (UGEC2665 is double-coded with ANTH2540.) This course addresses the ways in which social media and other related interactions in cyberspace have become a central element in the everyday lives of humans across the globe in the 21st Century. Our modern lives are now largely interwoven with digital technologies that have not only changed our own cultures, but also have brought forth new cultural forms through mobile phone technologies, networked “smart”-products, and cultural groupings only possible through digital means. The course approaches the anthropology of these digital cultures through its main themes—the transformation and expansion of social media, social research online, the intermixing of our online and offline lives, critical social issues of online lives, and the question of posthumanism. These themes are addressed explicitly in the course, and are also the subtexts of the different lectures, readings, and project work. Students will learn the techniques of online fieldwork and referencing. They will explore a diverse array of new ethnographies on social media: on gender, political movements, online dating, hacking, and gaming culture. These ethnographies also serve to model online social research and provide examples of methodology and design. The social consequences of cyberspace are addressed in the topics of internet pornography, addiction, surveillance, activism, and social networking. Gender and identity issues are a continuous theme throughout the course, highlighting how online lives accentuate already existing dynamics. Hong Kong connections to these subjects will also be critically discussed, often drawing on topical themes presented on blogs and forums. Students will learn of the philosophical questions of posthumanism and the nature of technologically mediated human culture. This serves as a philosophical ballast to the course allowing students to reflect personally on their own experiences and how technology has and will continue to shape their lives. The role of anthropology in understanding and capturing human culture in this context anchors on the investigation of how technology is possibly making us ‘more’ human than previous forms of cultural life.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEC2665 is double-coded with ANTH2540. 
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2540. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course students will have learnt how to design and perform online fieldwork and manage digital referencing.
Students will know of and understand the recent history and development of the internet and key platforms such as Facebook, Twitter, eBay, iTunes, and the ways in which cyberspace has become embedded in the everyday work and social lives of over 2.4 billion internet users.
Students will be able to explain and discuss the various debates on the social consequences of online technologies with regard to the tensions between online lives and (so called) real lives, or digital dualism.
Students will be able to address and articulate issues of political and philosophical change, activism, addiction, surveillance, the body and visual culture in connection to mobile technologies.
Students will know of some philosophical discussions on the nature of humanity in this new epoch. The question of humanity, posthuman futures, and transhumanism is a key concern that runs throughout the course. Students will also come to consider social media and our changing digital cultures as deeply significant to new understandings of gender and body identity.
courses.course_syllabus:
Core Content
Online Field Work
– Exploring how researchers have performed social research online. This will equip students with a knowledge of the approaches, techniques and challenges of field work in cyberspace. Whilst being a core topic, this is also part of the weekly project work of the course. Students will start their digital research from the beginning of the course, by first developing a blog and networking with classmates.
Cultural History of Cyberspace
– How did the world go online? This topic addresses the historical and technological developments that led the world to go online. Its key concern is to highlight how this has altered and affected society, and how quickly online life has become a part of everyday life.
Social Networking Sites
– The rise of web 2.0 and how the internet has become social. How have different SNS emerged, how do they connect, isolate, liberate, and limit social activity? Online Culture is explored via the different uses of various SNS platforms, and their own identities.
Sex and Body Culture in Cyberspace
– Tackles the social consequences of online pornography in different social and cultural circumstances. Body politics, risk, and sexuality online.
Posthumanism
– This is framed in the first week as a key issue and returns as the focus of the last 2 weeks of the course.This topic looks at the impact of cyberspace on our philosophical understanding of our bodies and ourselves. How is technology changing our attitudes to gender, ethnicity, religion, and is it making us more or less human?
Online Activism
– Explores the relationship between cyberspace and participatory politics, social justice, terror, and extremist groups
Proposed weekly topics with core content highlighted.
Week 1:- Introduction: Starting Digital Research (Going Viral)
Week 2:- Cultural History of Cyberspace
Week 3:- Social Networking Sites
Week 4:- Sex and Body Culture in Cyberspace
Week 5:- Video Gaming Culture – Play & Recreation
Week 6 :- Internet Addiction
Week 7:- Online Activism
Week 8:- Cyber-Surveillance and Crime
Week 9:- Online Field Work
Week 10:- Free Software, Inclusion, and Sharing
Week 11:- Virtual, Real, and Hybrid Space
Week 12:- The Selfie, the Self and Posthumanism
Week 13:- Future Scenarios of Cyberspace
Thematics:
Online Research
is covered as part of project work throughout the course. Weekly work on blogs relate to class discussions and require students to source and reference. It is addressed as a key topic in Week 1 & Week 9.
Social Consequences
of online lives as a theme is most strongly represented in the topics of week 5, 6, 8, 10 and 11. As well, because of the salience of this topic it relates to other core topics such as 3,4,7, 11, and 12.
Posthumanism
is a philosophical theme that is introduced in Week 1 and is relevant throughout the course. It is tackled directly as a concluding theme in the final two weeks of the course (12 and 13).

courses.title: Hong Kong Education Policy and Society
courses.description: This course aims to discuss and facilitate students to reflect education issues, policies and practices in Hong Kong. By applying sociological and political concepts and theories, the course will critically analyze current education issues and its development. This course will help students to understand and reflect on the interplay between politics, society and education system and its effect. It aims at equip students with a broader and deeper understanding of Hong Kong education policies and education system.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students majoring in programmes offered by Faculty of Education; not for CLED and ELED Majors. Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course aims to equip students with knowledge and skills to assist them to review and reflect on education issues in Hong Kong. Student are expected to achieve the following objectives:
To know the basic and evolving concepts, theories, policies and issues related to Hong Kong education
To understand the development of Hong Kong education system and its socio-political context
To analyse education phenomenon and policies with sociological and political perspectives
To evaluate and appreciate the cultures and values in educational improvement.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Interpersonal Violence
courses.description: (UGEC2680 is double-coded with SOWK2200.) The purposes of this course are to provide students a basic understanding of violence that takes place in our daily life in the contexts of intimate relationship, family, school and community and to arouse their consciousness of contemporary values of equality, human rights and social justice. Various concepts and theories of violence will be introduced to explore the nature, causes, consequences and trends of violence in different aspects of life. Emphasis will be placed on the issues of interpersonal violence in contemporary societies. Social policy and provisions to prevent and eliminate interpersonal violence will also be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEC2680 is double-coded with SOWK2200. 
Not for Social Work Majors; and students who have taken SOWK2200.
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:
1. 
Critically examine the contemporary perspectives, concepts and theories on interpersonal violence.
2. Analyze causes and consequences of interpersonal violence in different contexts.
3. 
Apply and integrate interdisciplinary theories of violence to evaluate current policy and strategies on tackling violence.
4. 
Reflect on ways to combat violence and help to promote a peaceful environment.
5. 
Appreciate the contemporary values of equality, human rights and social justice.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. 
Common misunderstanding and myths of interpersonal violence.
2. 
Contemporary perspectives and theories of violence from anthropology, education, medical science, politics, psychology, sociology and social work.
3. 
Nature, causes, consequences and trends of interpersonal violence.
4. 
The needs of victims and perpetrators of interpersonal violence.
5. 
Risk and protective factors of violence at personal, family, school, community and policy levels.
6. 
Issues of violence in regard to different genders, ages, classes, sexual orientations and cultures.
7. 
Current social policy and prevention programs on interpersonal violence.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Globalization and Politics
courses.description: (UGEC2683 is double-coded with GPAD2355.)  This course introduces undergraduate students to the key concepts, theoretical frameworks, and main political discussions/reflections related to globalization. Globalization itself is introduced in a broad sense not limited by the economic aspect but a common experience of social change. For example, global environmental challenges, the common threat of nuclear crisis, the controversy between sovereignty and human rights, and the North-South divide. With both the historical and thematic perspectives, the class engages students with most recent research and debate on the topic. On the one hand, the class encourages students to relate their own experiences and observations in their own societies to digest what globalization is and what its impacts are. On the other hand, it also leads them to reflect on politics and social development in their own societies, in the context of globalization.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Social Work and Cultural Diversity
courses.description: (UGEC2684 is double-coded with SOWK2202.)  This course provides students with fundamental and systematic knowledge on issues related to ethnic and cultural diversity. Apart from introducing contemporary theories and conceptual perspectives about cultural sensitivity and cultural intelligence, this course will also highlight major discourses and challenges concerning access, equity, social inclusiveness, cultural assimilation and integration which have substantial impact on ethnic minorities as well as social harmony. Through participation in small group projects, guided community tours, and face-to-face interaction with different ethnic groups, students will be able to develop an awareness of the differences in values, beliefs, life-style and interpersonal relatedness between themselves and people of other ethnic background. Basic skills, knowledge and attitude required of cultural intelligence, equal-opportunity legislations, social policies, service provision in meeting the needs of ethnic minorities, and measures to promote mutual acceptance and social inclusiveness will be discussed.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Social Innovation and Social Change for Good
courses.description: (UGEC2686 is double-coded with SOWK2204.)  This course prepares students to learn from the emerging practices of social innovations in tackling with challenges in social, economic, cultural and political development in Hong Kong, the Greater China region and beyond. Students will acquire analysis, knowledge and strategies of social innovations, the processes of social change in creating social values. The scope of social innovations includes that of social entrepreneurs or social innovators in NGOs, communities, social movements, non-profit organizations, and business as well as the public sector. The course will examine cases of social innovations that have catalyzed important positive social change through the market, the nonprofit sector, the community, the public sector as well as the spaces among those four sectors. Experiential learning will be integrated along the course delivery, such as programmme visits, dialogue with social entrepreneurs, staff members or service users. Students are encouraged to experience these operations, so as to analyze the development issues, the social values and innovations in offering practical solutions to poverty and social inequalities, unemployment and livelihood, civic and community engagement, fair trade as well as sustainable development. The course will provide inspirations as well as know-hows for students who are concerned about the articulation of local with global and regional issues and like to develop innovative actions to change the society for good.

courses.description: (UGEC2693 is double-coded with SOWK2203.) This course introduces to students the field of mission-driven social enterprise, which aims to achieve a balance between meaningful social returns as well as sustainable or competitive financial returns through their products, services and other business practices. Through examining the best practices in social entrepreneurship, it also stimulates students to explore how social enterprise can affect policy and facilitate system change. Experiential learning elements such as visiting social enterprises and having dialogue with social entrepreneurs, staff members or service users will be arranged in order to let students experience its operation, understand its practice as well as to enable students in realizing its possibilities in offering solutions to education, healthcare, environment, workforce development, international development and other societal issues. The course is valuable to students who may want to design or lead a mission-driven social enterprise, or want to contribute time and energy to help build the social sector through this emerging field.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Youth Problem in Modern Society
courses.description: This course explores some of the major issues concerning the role of the youth and the problems confronting them in modern society. The nature of the conventional wisdom of the “youth problem” is critically examined, with the help of concepts and theories in sociology and related fields. By the end of the course, students are expected to gain more understanding of the nature of the phenomenon of problematization of youth, and to look beyond common sense or public perception on current social issues related to the youth in modern society. More importantly, youth problems can jeopardize the sustainable development of youth. [For example, education inequality (SDG4 Quality Education) and inadequate school-to-work transition (SDG8 Decent Work and Economic Growth) could impact on youth poverty (SDG1 No Poverty) as a result.] A broader and deeper understanding of various facets of problematization can inform how youth should be empowered to attain sustainable development in modern society.

Not for Sociology Majors; and students who have taken SOCI2110.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix

courses.learning_outcomes:
Students will be able to capture the extent of youth problem in modern society.
Students will be able to gain a more intellectual understanding of the nature and possible causes of youth problems.
Students will be able to critically evaluate the public perception of social issues relating to the youth.
Student will be able to reflect on their life experiences as members of a younger population and their challenges of sustainable development in modern society.
courses.course_syllabus:
The core content of the course covers five areas in the study of youth problem.
The developmental discourse and the concept of social construction are examined to illustrate the emergence and the nature of the youth concept.
Biological, psychological and sociological views on the conceptualization of youth problem are introduced and compared, so as to illustrate the role and focus of social science, sociology in particular, in the study of youth problem.
Specific youth topics such as (1) educational inequality (SDG1 No poverty, SDG4 Quality Education), (2) precarious school-to-work transition and downward mobility (SDG1 No poverty, SDG8 Decent work and economic growth), (3) youth gangs and violence (SDG3 Good health and well-being), (4) exceptionalism and gender inequality (SDG5 Gender equality), (5) dating aggression and sexual health (SDG3 Good health and well-being, SDG5 Gender equality), (6) resistance of sexual minorities (SDG5 Gender equality); (7) digital media challenges (e.g. infodemics, SDG3 Good health and well-being), and (8) normalization of risk behaviors (e.g. addictions, SDG3 Good health and well-being), are explored to scrutinize the forms and the extent of problem encountered by youth in modern society.
Sociological concepts and perspectives, such as rational choice theory, social stratification theory, feminism, subcultural theory,, media theories, and labeling perspective, are discussed to illuminate the social factors affecting the above-mentioned youth problems.
Postmodern perspectives and concepts, such as post-Fordism, post-materialism; risk society, risk assessment and individualization, are introduced to move beyond the modernity view and to offer a discussion on the recent emergence of new forms of social transformation and crisis faced by youth.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Environmentalism and Environmental Education
courses.description: (UGEC2710 is double-coded with EDUC2130.) The course is aimed at preparing students as global and future citizens who not only have critical understandings of the environmental issues, but also the capabilities and attitudes to take an active role in tackling the issues and educating for the environment. This course is structured around key issues pertaining to environmentalism and environmental education, including climate changes, sustainability, green groups and environmental curriculum and teaching at schools. Using an issue-inquiry approach, course participants will be led to critically reflect on the issues from various perspectives: philosophical, scientific, social and educational. The different approaches to environmental education in the Western and Chinese communities will be explored in the contexts of eastern and western cultures. A field trip is included to provide experiential education in the environment.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEC2710 is double-coded with EDUC2130. 
Not for students majoring in EDU; not for CLED and ELED Majors; and students who have taken EDUC2130.
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.course_syllabus:
How do people start to care about the environment - a historical understanding of environmentalism and its definition
A framework for understanding environmental issues
Is climate change a myth or hoax - understanding the science behind and its limitations
Why don’t people take climate change seriously - consequences and solutions of climate change
What’s wrong with the countries – politics and the environment
What’s wrong with our society – modern capitalism and the environment
Is sustainable development a myth?
What’s wrong with human beings – environmental ethics?
What’s wrong with the environmental advocacy groups - myths of some environmental activities?
What's wrong with our education - aims and approaches of environmental education?
How do different countries approach environmental education –Hong Kong, China, Taiwan and others
Overview of issues related to environmental problems and environmental education
Field trip to a site related to current environmental issues in Hong Kong, such as North East development farmland, EcoPark, Fung Yuen butterfly convervation centre.

courses.description: The establishment and development of Chinese Medicine have been greatly inspired by traditional Chinese culture, including the ancient Chinese philosophy, religious doctrines and history. This course will provide the opportunity for students to possess a deeper understanding of the association between traditional Chinese culture and Chinese Medicine. The difference between Chinese and Western cultures will also be discussed.

courses.learning_outcomes:
完成本科後，期望學生能夠︰
- 提高對中華民族傳統文化的認知
- 描述中華文化（
包括中國古代哲學、宗教、文學、歷史、民族、飲食）與中醫學及識別中醫學的關係
- 比較並指出中西醫學的異同
- 評價中華文化在中醫學中的地位
- 分析各種與中醫相關的文化現象與中醫學的連繫

courses.course_syllabus:
講授內容
（一）
中醫的概念﹕中醫、中藥與中國文化
概括介紹中國醫學的起源、形成、發展、學術特點及與中國傳統文化的密切關係，討論嶺南中醫藥文化以及中西醫的比較。
（二）
中醫藥與儒、釋、道家文化以及《易經》的關係
簡述中醫藥文化與儒、釋、道三家以及易經的關係：儒家的仁、禮、中庸之道與中醫藥環環相扣，相互參照；釋家「醫方明」與中醫理論相互吸收和影響；道家學說不少與中醫理論類通，同樣強調人與大自然的關係和天人相應；
《黃帝內經》對自然和人體的認識，及其辨證理論，一脈相承自《易經》。
（三）
文學與中醫
以儒通醫。古代學者如陶潛、陸游、蘇軾、羅貫中、曹雪芹等都曾經行醫或有深厚的中醫造詣。 中醫不少著作是用詩、詞、歌、賦形式撰寫的，讀者容易記憶，文學著作亦有豐富的中醫內容。本節選讀唐詩、宋詞、紅樓夢、三國演義等文學著作，欣賞其中包含的中醫宇宙觀、生命觀、並討論其中所列舉的藥物，病案。
（四）
中醫理論之應用﹕飲食、養生之中醫文化
從簡介舌診、臟腑辨證、君臣佐使組方原理，先讓學生認識中醫診治方法，再以飲食和養生兩方面闡述中華寶庫之一----中醫保健之道。食療：飲食養生，家居實用補藥，涼茶及保健湯水。養生：四季養生法，十二時辰養生法，休憩養生與七情養生。保健、養顏：按摩、穴位和藥膳。

courses.title: Applied Ethics
courses.description: A survey of major moral debates that shows how philosophical thought can be brought to bear upon contemporary issues. This course will focus on such moral problems as arising from abortion, our treatment of animals, criminal punishment, death penalty, euthanasia, and sex. Students will learn normative ethical theories and reflect on how these theories can contribute to the resolution of the above-mentioned problems. Students will also be encouraged to develop their own judgments in a critical manner,
courses.enrollment_requirement:

courses.learning_outcomes:
Understand the nature of applied ethics.
Recognize the characteristics and importance of some main problems of applied ethics.
Reflect on how to resolve these problems of applied ethics.
Understand each problem of applied ethics in its own right, and whether a particular problem must be resolved.
Identify the characteristics and value of ethical theories.
Explain and assess different moral stances in a perspicuous, non-doctrinaire way.

courses.description: (UGEC2853 is double-coded with GDRS2002.)  This course aims at an interdisciplinary approach to the study of human sexuality and culture. Three main areas will be discussed: (1) ideas of sexuality: Chinese and Western conception of sexuality, modern theories of sexuality; (2) sexuality and ethics: ethical issues of sexual relationships; and (3) sexuality and society: gender problem; issues relating to homosexuality, pornography, and AIDS.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEC2853 is double-coded with GDRS2002. 
Not for Philosophy Majors; and students who have taken GDRS2002. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Identify and recognize the ideas of sex and sexuality in Western and Chinese culture.
Discuss sexual issues openly and intellectually without any taboo.
Identify and reflect on various media representations of sex.
Appreciate the complexity of sexuality in modern society regarding homosexuality, feminism, etc.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Animals and Society : A philosophical approach
courses.description: This course examines the social issues of animal from the philosophical perspectives. What are the key differences humans and other animals? Is it ethical to raise and slaughter animals for food, conduct tests on, and buying or keeping animals as pets? How ought one to respond to unethical laws on animals? What are the social impacts of these actions? Students will develop an interdisciplinary perspective in the fields of animal studies, ethical theory, sociology and environmental philosophy by understanding how ancient and contemporary philosophers, sociologist, environmental scientists, ecologists, activists, and journalists have responded to key ethical questions concerning animal rights and its social implication. Topics to be discussed include: animal-machines, ethical meat eating, radical vegetarianism, and the evolution of pets.This course bears on several of the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). By transforming our attitude towards and relationship with animal, we enjoy the mental health benefits of a deepened appreciation of and connection with them (SDG#3 Good Health and Well-Being). By exploring the key difference between human and animals, we deepen our understand toward ourself and different species on earth (SDG#14 Life below water & SDG#15 Life on land). Finally, by reimagining our relationship with animal, we can envision for a just society in which all species could co-exist peacefully (SDG#16 Peace, Justice and Strong institutions).

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Economic Reform and Social Impacts in China
courses.description: (UGEC2883 is double-coded with SOCI2106.)  Focusing on economic reforms, students will be taught the impetus of the institutional changes in China and how they affect the cultural, socioeconomic and organizational lives of Chinese people. Key social science concepts and theories like institution, ideology, socialism, marketization, social control, civil society, industrialization, urbanization, stratification, family, socialization, and specialized terms in China studies like guanxi (關係), danwei (單位), hukou (戶口), harmonious society, China dream, floating population, rural-urban divide, one/two child(ren) policy, will be introduced and discussed from an integrated perspective. After taking this course, students should be able to grasp the transformation and development in key areas of China, including economic reform, political system and change, rural and urban development, social inequality, family and marriage, cultural and ideological issues, as well as other institutional developments.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEC2883 is double-coded with SOCI2106.
Not for Sociology Majors; and students who have taken GESC2118, SOCI2106 or UGEA2190.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Students are expected to grasp the basic knowledge about China’s major social institutions such as socialist market economy, party-state apparatus, stratification system, and lineage values. They should also be able to understand the evolution of these institutions over the past several decades.
• Students should be able to understand how social scientists analyze and examine the formation, evolution, and influences of the major social institutions in contemporary China. They are expected to grasp the key concepts and theories developed from social scientists from sociology, economics, political science, etc.
• Besides basic facts and social science perspectives, students are encouraged to critically evaluate some controversial topics from different angles through writing assignments. The topics will include key dilemmas in contemporary China regarding economic growth and social equality, state capacity and democracy, traditional culture and modernization, etc.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction: Basic Information of the Chinese Society
* Provide basic information about the socio-economic characteristics of the contemporary China.
Week 2 & 3: China before Reform Era
* Provide information about the political systems, economic institutions, and social control mechanisms of China during Mao’s era.
Week 4
& 5: Economic Reform
* Provide information about the processes of economic reform since 1978, as well as its impact on the economic system afterwards.
Week 6 & 7 & 8:
Impacts on the Political System and the Preservation of the Party-state
* Provide information about the impact of the economic reform on the political system in China afterwards. Also, we will discuss the puzzle regarding the preservation of the Party-state despite the massive political reform.
Week 9
: Impacts on Rural-urban Development and Migration
* Provide information about the differential impact of the economic reform on the urban and rural development, as well as the resultant great migration since then.
Week 10: Impacts on Social Stratification and Inequality
* Provide information about the impact of the economic reform on the transition of the social stratification system and the enlarging social inequality.
Week 11 & 12: Impacts on Social Conflicts, Civil Society, and Social Control
* Provide information about the impact of the economic reform on the growing social conflicts and the newly emerged social control mechanisms.
Week 13: Impacts on Population and Demographic Transition
* Provide information about the impact of the economic reform on the population and demographic patterns.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Money, Land and Housing

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G02

courses.description: When money is fiat, land is scarce, housing becomes a good hedge of inflation. However, when housing is both an investment capital as well as a necessity, the city is split into an owner-renter dichotomy, with the former preferring an increase of housing prices but just the opposite for the latter. When the pendulum of housing price swings to one side, housing capital can result in negative equity, asset bubble, or even financial crisis. Swinging to the other end, housing can become unaffordable, even if public housing or subsidy can be provided. Decent living environment and sustainable community are the concerns of cities. This introduction course explores the reasons of the housing price fluctuations and the implications of the dichotomy on the city lives.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Urban Studies Majors. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.course_syllabus:
The following topics are included in the course:
PART I: Relationships between money, land and housing
Why housing can be a good hedge of inflation?
How does the monetary policy affect the housing market?
Why interest rate and inflation rate affect housing price?
Is high land price or restrictive land supply a cause of high housing price?
How does the housing policy affect the housing market?
PART II: Social implications of housing issues
What is the owner-renter dichotomy of housing?
What are the implications of the housing dichotomy on our city lives?
Why housing can become unaffordable?
How does housing price fluctuation affect financial stability and wealth inequality?
Why are there housing cycles and housing bubbles?
What is property hegemony?
PART III:
Is public housing or cooperative housing a solution?
A sustainable housing policy.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Belt and Road for Collaborative Modernization
courses.description: (UGEC2917 is double-coded with URSP2010.)  The Belt and Road initiative (BRI) refers to the Silk Road Economic Belt and the 21st Century Maritime Silk Road. It is a significant development strategy proposed by the Chinese Government spanning approximately 60 countries in Asia, Eastern Europe, Middle East and Africa, with a total population of 4.4 billion. This initiative takes advantage of global transportation routes, core cities, and key ports to build international economic co-operation corridors. The effective operation and management of the BRI require collaboration among a broad range of disciplines comprising civil engineering, material science, government operations, economics and finance, social and political science, and environmental science. A critical and multi-disciplinary understanding of the BRI can provide insights into basic requirements, geopolitical impact, physical barriers, and sustainability potential of the infrastructural projects it proposes to undertake and help relevant stakeholders address large-scale and complex challenges in the lifecycle management of those infrastructure projects. This course involves forward-looking perspectives to assess, predict, influence and enhance the in/direct network effects and benefits of the BRI on the cities, urban systems and peoples of the Belt and Road region.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEC2917 is double-coded with URSP2010. 
Not for Urban Studies Majors; and students who have taken URSP2010.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction
1. Globalization in Perspective: introduction of globalization as a term, process and ideology.
2. Historical Silk Road: historical origins of the Silk Road; continuities and shifts in terms of Maritime Silk Road, interactions and encounters along the Silk Road.
Global Implications
3. Geopolitical Shifts: branding and popularizing the Belt and Road Initiative; imperial histories and ambitions informing the initiative.
4. Eastern and Western Perspectives: the opportunities and challenges arising from Belt and Road Initiative with reference to the European Recovery Program; the geopolitical theories of Alfred Mahan, Halford Mackinder and Henry Kissinger; the philosophy of Confucius and Taoists.
Facilities Connectivity
5. Construction Management in BRI countries: risk management in international construction joint ventures and overseas development institute; large-scale transnational high-speed railway construction projects.
6. Green and Sustainable Urbanization: In search of better livability in BRI cities: Liveability in dense and vertical cities; green finance; carbon auditing and carbon trading; green strategies for achieving sustainable development goals.
Unimpeded Trade
7. Trading, Logistic, and Professional Service: Hong Kong as regional BRI centre for trading, logistic and professional services; manufacture shifting and upgrading experience in ASEAN economies.
8. The Energy Market: energy market opportunities and uncertainties in Northeast, Southeast, Central Asia and Africa; global oil and gas markets; renewable and sustainable energy goals.
Financial Integration
9. The Bond Market: infrastructure financing; international bond market and Hong Kong’s debt market; corporate social responsibility on Green Bond Issuance; the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank and the Silk Road Fund.
10. International Settlement: currency wars and special drawing rights; consumerism and RMB internationalization; Hong Kong as the offshore RMB centre; the New Development Bank.
Regional Responses
11. Middle East: geopolitics and energy nexus; religious and national concerns.
12. Central and Eastern Europe: rail and maritime connectivities; integrating trade and resisting xenophobia.
13. India: regional rivalry, economic integration and border disputes

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Language and Society
courses.description: (UGEC2925 is double-coded with LING2301.) This course explores human language in the broader context of culture and society. How, for example, does one language community interacts with another language community in the multilingual world? Does language change and what are the processes involved? To what extent does the same language vary due to gender, power, status, and identity? How do men and women, people with higher and lower social status talk differently? How are these relationships reflected in the use of politeness markers and other linguistic devices? What are the implications of sociolinguistics on education and language planning? Through introducing students to major issues in sociolinguistic studies, students will be able to develop a better understanding of how language functions in societal contexts from a linguistic perspective. Discussions will also focus on common sociolinguistic phenomena in daily communication, with a specific emphasis on the use of various languages and dialects spoken in Hong Kong. Exploring these topics will enhance students’ awareness of language as a cultural phenomenon and sharpen their sensitivity to the nuances of language use in the context of a multilingual world, with special reference to the sociolinguistic context of the Greater China area.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Thinking sustainability: Health and Global Challenges
courses.description: In this course, we will discuss the direct and indirect health consequences related to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) adopted by the United Nations and analyze the wider socioeconomic dimensions of these topics. After the pandemic we faced, we realized that a health crisis will have implications beyond the health sector and development must balance social, economic and environmental sustainability. It is therefore important for us, as global citizens, to recognize the issues related and understand how we can take part in this. Traditionally, health indicators have been an important aspect of development indices and health is a foundation of societies. Therefore, our course aims to discuss SDGs through the lens of health, by providing an overview on how the current global challenges on sustainable development impacts the population health and encourage students to look for solutions. We will cover the health-related SDGs by blended learning, including 2. Zero Hunger where we will discuss malnutrition, 3. Good Health and Well-being where we will discuss road injuries, infrastructure and management, 5. Gender Equality where we will discuss intimate partner violence, 6. Clean Water and Sanitation where we will discuss water safety and supply, 8. Decent Work and Economic Growth where we will discuss labor rights and occupational injuries, 11. Sustainable Cities and Communities where we will discuss impacts on health, socioeconomics and environment of inadequate housing and poor living environment, 13. Climate Action where we will discuss Climate-related disasters and disaster risks, and 16. Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions where we will discuss concept and impact of peace and justice on health. Through face-to-face tutorials and case-based discussions, we will discuss selected topics in greater details, including the road safety aspects of Goal 3 “Good health and well-being”, the protection of workers from work-related injuries in Goal 8 “Decent work and economic growth”, the disaster risks in modern developments in Goal 13 “Climate action”, and how to educate the younger generation on the promotion of peace in Goal 16 “Peace, justice and strong institutions”. Development of modern societies and the interaction between humans and environment will be discussed, and through the advocacy framework we will discuss the current challenges related which draw immense global attention, and allow students to exchange interdisciplinary ideas, identify the challenges we are facing and propose advocacy campaign in hope to identify and deliver solutions locally and internationally.

courses.course_syllabus:
The course includes 8 online lectures introducing the 8 health-related SDGs and discussing related health issues with local and global data. Two SDG online lectures will be available on Blackboard every other week. The online lectures will start with SDG topics more related to personal health, ie. rights and equities. We will then move on to SDG topics related to the health of societies and health consequences related to the interaction between human development and nature. At the end, we will discuss SDG topics related to health issues that need to be address with global collaborations. The face-to-face tutorials will cover the 4 chosen SDGs, namely “Good health and well-being”, “Decent work and economic growth”, “Climate action” and “Peace, justice and strong institutions”, where we will have case studies and students will require the knowledge learnt in online lectures to participate in the discussions.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Islam in Hong Kong
courses.description: This course aims to address the historical development and localisation of Islam in the cultural context of Hong Kong. It firstly introduces the basic knowledge of Islam and Islamic culture worldwide; and the prominent cultural and social position of Islam in the contemporary globalised world. It then applies Hong Kong as a case study to examine the historical evolution of various Muslim communities of Hong Kong, such as Indian, Pakantsian, Indonesian, African and Chinese Muslim communities. It also discusses how these Muslim communities interfaced with each other and integrated with the local society. By establishing a more inclusive and diversified understanding of the local Muslim community, this course responds to the UN Sustainable Development Goals #11 'Sustainable Cities and Communities. Meanwhile, it pinpoints local Muslim communities' challenges in the current globalised world. Islam is one of the most important religions in the contemporary world, which is also a key to achieving a safe and peaceful global environment; therefore, this course also echoes the UN Sustainable Development Goals #16 'Reduced Inequalities'.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for History Majors. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #11 Sustainable Cities and Communities
SDG-GE #16 Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students should understand core concepts and theories related to one of the most prominent religions in the contemporary world – Islam and Islamic cultures worldwide. They shall learn that understanding Islam is core to developing a safe and culturally inclusive world enourgaed by the UN Sustainable Development Goals #16 'Reduced Inequalities' and 'Peace, 'Justice and Strong Institution'.
2. Students should learn about the historical development of Islam and various Muslim communities in Hong Kong.
3. Students shall develop their capacity to review the social roles of Islam and Muslim cultures in Hong Kong society.
4. Students shall be able to outline the importance of respecting and appreciating cultural diversity in both local and global contexts. Understanding and respecting social diversity is also the key to making an inclusive and sustainable global community outlined by the UN Sustainable Development Goals #11 'Sustainable Cities and Communities.
courses.course_syllabus:
Section 1: Understanding Islam
1. The origin of Islam and its historical development.
2. Islam and its cultural diversity from a global perspective.
3. The cultural and social features of Islam and Muslim communities.
4. Islamic world in a global context.
Section 2: Islam in Hong Kong
1. The historical transformation of Islam in Hong Kong.
2. The introduction of various Muslim communities in Hong Kong.
3. The localisation of Muslim communities in Hong Kong.
4. The roles of local Muslim communities from pollical, economic and social aspects.
5. The social roles and contribution of local Muslim communities.
Section 3: The future development of Islam in Hong Kong
1. The worldwide challenges of inheriting religious traditions in the contemporary world.
2. The current challenges faced by the local Mulsim communities.
3. The sustainable incorporation and integration between Muslim communities and Hong Kong society.
第一部：認識伊斯蘭

2. 環球視野下的伊斯蘭及其文化多元性。

4. 全球化下的伊斯蘭世界。

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Museum and Heritage
courses.description: This course reviews the historical development of concepts and theories related to museums and cultural heritage. It introduces diversified definitions of museums and heritage in the contemporary. Through selected case studies and field trips, it demonstrates the operations of museums and heritage sites; and analyses their social roles in modern society. It aligns with the UN Sustainable Development Goals #11 'Sustainable Cities and Communities, which emphasises making more inclusive and sustainable cities and communities. It also reviews the historical evolution of international conventions related to museums and heritage outlines how global and regional cooperation, such as the development of UNESCO World Heritage, is vital for sustainable heritage conservation and management. It directly responds to the UN Sustainable Development Goals #17, 'Revitalise the Global Partnership for Sustainable Development which suggests that successful global development requires inclusive and international partnerships.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for History Majors; and students who have taken HIST3441. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #11 Sustainable Cities and Communities
SDG-GE #17 Partnerships for the Goals
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students should understand core concepts and theories related to museums and heritage in the contemporary world.
Students should learn about the historical evolution of social and cultural roles of museums and heritage, especially in the social context of the East Asian region. They shall further develop their capacity to review the social functions of museums and heritage in the rapidly changing contemporary society. It shall help students pinpoint the core values of the UN Sustainable Development Goals #11 'Sustainable Cities and Communities, which emphasises making more inclusive and sustainable cities and communities.
Students shall be able to outline the importance of international and regional cooperation on issues related to heritage conservation, such as the establishment of UNESCO and the
Modus Operandi
of the UNESCO World Heritage. It allows students to recognise the importance of global solidarity in achieving a successful and sustainable international development emphasised by the UN Sustainable Development Goals #17, 'Revitalise the Global Partnership for Sustainable Development.
courses.course_syllabus:
Section 1: Concepts and theories related to museums and heritage
1. The origin of the museum and its historical development.
2. The concepts and definitions of cultural heritage and their historical evolution.
3. Understanding and interpreting cultural heritage in the East Asian context.
Section 2: The social roles of museums and heritage and their public engagement
1. The transformation of the social roles of museums and heritage.
2. The educational functions of museums and heritage: how museums and heritage sites could collaborate to provide a culturally diversified learning experience for different society stakeholders, including children, the elderly, and people with physical and mental disabilities.
3. The social inclusion of museums and heritage: how museums and heritage could help motivate local societies' sustainable development and address the value of social justice worldwide.
4. The reuse and revitalisation of heritage in modern society.
Section 3: Achieving sustainable heritage conservation and management through International and regional cooperation
1. International conventions related to heritage conservation and management.
2. The
Modus Operandi
of UNESCO World heritage and its sustainable development goals.
3. The challenges and opportunities of international and regional cooperation regarding heritage conservation and management.
第一部：博物館及文化遺產的概念和理論

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: The Peoples of Hong Kong in History
courses.description: Being one of the most cosmopolitan cities in the World, Hong Kong encompasses people of different racial, ethnic and social backgrounds, that attributes to Hong Kong’s hybridity and diversity. This course introduces students to the history of Hong Kong by looking closely at the many varied peoples in Hong Kong. Hong Kong, the gateway to China and a former British colony with dominant Chinese population, how the life, experience and identity of different races, ethnicities and classes differs? What roles did they play in the rise of Hong Kong from a fishing village to a global hub for opportunity? How did their different stories together turn Hong Kong into a cultural melting pot? This course is relevant to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), particularly in the area of SDG#8 Decent Work and Economic Growth, SDG#10 Reducing Inequalities and SDG#11 Sustainable Cities and Communities.

Have a better understanding of the history of Hong Kong and the history of different communities in the city.
Recognize and critically analyze how and why various contexts affecting ethnic relations and social identities.
Identify and examine the roles and contributions of different communities in the evolution of Hong Kong’s society and the development of Hong Kong’s economy (SDG#8 Decent Work and Economic Growth).
Appreciate Hong Kong’s social diversity and cosmopolitanism, and develop empathy to the culture of different communities (SDG#11 Sustainable Cities and Communities).
Evaluate and reflect on how to promote social equality and inclusion in Hong Kong (SDG#10 Reducing Inequalities).

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: History of Hong Kong
courses.description: This course introduces the history of Hong Kong from a British colony to the Special Administrative Region of China. It covers major events and issues of Hong Kong, emphasizing the development of political system, social structure and economic pattern, and evaluate the role of Hong Kong in modern China, in the Asian-Pacific region and in the world. The course critically examines how colonial governance and Sino-British relations affected Hong Kong, offering students a multi-perspective in understanding how Hong Kong has becomes what it is today. This course is relevant to three Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), particularly in the area of SDG#8 Decent Work and Economic Growth by looking at the development of Hong Kong from an entrepôt to a global financial centre, SDG#10 Reduced Inequalities by looking at how Hong Kong evolved from a society of racial segregation to social inclusiveness, and SDG#16 Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions by looking at the public policy in promoting social reform and social justice.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for History Majors; and students who have taken GESC2150, GLBS3406. HIST2500 or UGEC3542.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.course_attributes:
SDG-GE #8 Decent Work and Economic Growth
SDG-GE #10 Reducing Inequality
SDG-GE #16 Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions
courses.learning_outcomes:
Have a better understanding on the history of Hong Kong.
Recognize and critically analyze how and why various contexts affecting the development of Hong Kong.
Identify and examine the economic roles and positions of Hong Kong in modern Chinese history and in a global context (SDG#8 Decent Work and Economic Growth).
Articulate fair evaluation on issues surrounding the daily life in Hong Kong (e.g. inequalities in economic and political power, housing problem, etc.) after understanding their origins, and able to reflect on how to promote social reform and justice based on the experience of the past (SDG#10 Reduced Inequalities and SDG#16 Peace, Justice and Social Institution).

courses.title: Exploring Hong Kong Heritage
courses.description: This course explores the significant social roles of cultural heritage and its importance in achieving sustainable social development in the specific context of Hong Kong. This course applies Hong Kong as a case study to explore the conceptualisation of heritage in Hong Kong's historical context; and the historical development of Hong Kong's cultural heritage policy framework, Including its limitations and effectiveness. This course covers tangible (historical structures) and intangible heritage in Hong Kong. Through fieldwork study and intangible heritage workshop, it aims to help students understand the conservation and revitalisation of Hong Kong's heritage and its substantial social role in local society. Through investigating various local examples in Hong Kong, this course further debates the importance of cultural heritage in terms of local community building and reconstruction of historical discourses. Furthermore, it investigates how various local cultural heritage sites interact and engage with their neighbouring landscape. Students are also encouraged to examine the tensions between urban development and cultural heritage conservation in Hong Kong.This course motivates the students to investigate the dynamic between cultural heritage conservation and sustainable urban development by using their local experience and exploring possible solutions to associated challenges. Thus, this course aligns with the UN Sustainable Development Goal #11, 'Sustainable Cities and Communities, emphasises making cities and communities sustainable.

courses.course_attributes: SDG-GE #11 Sustainable Cities and Communities
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students should understand core concepts and theories of both UNESCO and intangible heritage.
2. Students should learn about the historical evolution of social and cultural roles in the social context of Hong Kong; and the local system and policy framework of heritage conservation and management.
3. Student should develop their capacity to review the social functions and cultural heritage of Hong Kong society and why it is crucial for the long-term sustainable development of Hong Kong. It shall help students pinpoint the core values of the UN Sustainable Development Goals #11, 'Sustainable Cities and Communities, which emphasises making more inclusive and sustainable cities and communities.
4. Students shall be able to outline the challenges of heritage conservation and revitalisation in Hong Kong; and explore potential solutions for sustainable cultural heritage conservation and inheritance in Hong Kong.
courses.course_syllabus:
Section 1: Concepts and theories related to UNESCO World Heritage
The concepts and definitions of cultural heritage and its historical evolution.
International conventions related to heritage conservation and management.
The Modus Operandi of UNESCO World Heritage and the List of Intangible Cultural Heritage (ICH)and its sustainable development goals; and its applicability in the context of Hong Kong.
Section 2: The historical evolution of the historic structures conservation system in Hong Kong
The transformation of Hong Kong's conservation system of historic structures.
The social functions of cultural heritage: the challenges and opportunities of revitalising Hong Kong's historic structures.
Cultural heritage and the construction of local communities: the reuse and revitalisation of cultural heritage and its social connection with local communities.
Section 3: The conservation and sustainable inheritance of Hong Kong's intangible cultural heritage.
The definition and categories of intangible cultural heritage: oral traditions and expressions, including language as a vehicle of the ICH; performing arts; social practices, rituals and festive events; knowledge and practices concerning nature and the universe; and traditional craftsmanship.
The development of the Hong Kong conservation system of ICH.
The sustainable inheritance of various categories of ICH in Hong Kong.
第一部：聯合國世界文化遺產的概念和理論
文化遺產概念的源起及發展。
有關文化遺產保育和管理的國際性公約和守則。
聯合國世界文化遺產及非物質文化遺產名錄的管理機制及其在香港的適用性。
第二部：香港歷史建築物的保育制度的演變和實施
香港歷史建築物評級及保育制度的演變及發展
文化遺產的社會性教育功能：活化古蹟為香港社會可持續發展所帶來的機遇以及挑戰
文化遺產與本地社區營造：保育及活化利用文化遺產與本地社區營造的聯繫。
第三部：香港非物質文化遺產的保育和可持續傳承
非物質文化遺產的定義和種類：口頭傳統和表現形式，包括作為非遺媒介的語言；表演藝術；社會實踐、儀式、節慶活動；有關自然界和宇宙的知識和實踐；及傳統手工藝。
香港非物質文化遺產保育制度的演變及執行概況
香港各類型非物質文化遺產的可持績傳承。

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Environmental Crises and Cultures of Survival
courses.description: (UGEC2950 is double-coded with ANTH2380.)  This course pays attention to the environment and its relation with human experiences. Through the lens of environment, we bring human diversity into presence, examining ways of life of peoples—from Indonesia highlander to Tokyo urbanites—and their words and deeds to tackle crises of planetary scale—climate change, nuclear disaster, air pollution, waste, deforestation. Facing these crises, can anthropological inquiry of the environment help us to explore a humanity that can accommodate living beings of all kind? How can such inquiry inspire us to make changes that create a world we can live together? We’ll follow these trails in the environment to look for engagement and conversation: cultural perception on the origin of agriculture, resource use and religious belief, debating traditional ecological knowledge, globalization and state intervention, environmental justice, land dispossession, waste and pollution, disaster and extreme environment. Through ethnographies of people who are struggling to survive, this course asks why they are pushed into poverty, how their resources being exploited, what they do to fight for justice; it covers SDGs related to the issues of sustainable agriculture (SDG2), tacking climate change (SDG13) and promoting peace, justice and institutional accountability (SDG16).

courses.course_syllabus:
Part I: Cultural Knowledge of the Environment
1. Cultural Perceptions of the Origin of Agriculture
2. Religious Belief in Resource Use
3. Traditional Ecological Knowledge
4. Materialist Conception of Nature (I)
5. Materialist Conception of Nature (II)—State Intervention and Globalization
Part II: Contemporary Culture of Environmental Politics
Topics of contemporary environmental crises are contemplated through case studies and ethnographies of people who become vulnerable. We will cover related SDGs to explore possibilities of action to achieve a sustainable way of life for humans.
6. Extraction (SDG16)
- the cause of uneven distribution of environmental risks and how local communities struggle for survival and justice
7. Waste
8. Toxicity
9. Disaster and extreme environment (SDG16)
- the government’s immediate response to disaster and affected communities’ action to restore respectful life
10. Conservation (SDG2)
- the functioning of conservation agencies and the conflicts between conservation and local community
11. Climate Change (SDG 13)
- the impact of climate change to local ecology and people’s livelihood, their actions and adaptations
12. Conclusion—Rethinking Development (SDG 16)
- the insistence on productivity in modern societies, and the possibilities of sustainable future

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Magic, Myth and the Supernatural
courses.description: (UGEC2960 is double-coded with ANTH2340.)  This course will examine phenomena often viewed as irrational and superstitious to see how they can be understood in cultural terms. All societies have some beliefs in another world, yet beliefs vary widely between societies. The course will examine traditional anthropological topics such as magic, traditional healing, divination, fengshui, witchcraft, and ghosts, as well as more recent issues such as ESP, psychokinesis, qigong, vampires, zombies, monsters, UFOs and alien abduction. The role of myth in modern society and the cultural creation of reality will be highlighted. The power of a cultural approach in explaining the supernatural and the limits of what science can explain will also be discussed.
