courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Social Problems in China
courses.description: (UGEC2963 is double-coded with SOCI2216.)  China’s opening to the world has led to not only massive social and economic transformations, but also the emergence of social problems. This course explores some of these social problems, especially since the economic reform after 1978. The nature of these social problems and their possible causes will be critically examined, in the context of modernization, with the help of related concepts and theories in sociology. By the end of the course, students are expected to have a basic understanding of the major social problems in contemporary China and their implications for social and economic developments of China in the future.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEC2963 is double-coded with SOCI2216.
Not for Sociology Majors; and students who have taken SOCI2216 or UGEA2190.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will be able to gain a basic intellectual understanding of the nature and possible causes of the major social problems faced by a changing China.
2. Students will be able to develop critical thinking on the public perception of social problems in China.
3. Students will be able to apply the theoretical perspectives and concepts gained from this course to analyze social problems they encounter in contemporary China.
courses.course_syllabus:
With the help of related concepts and theories in sociology, this course will critically examine the nature of some of the social problems and their possible causes faced by China under modernization. The topics include:
1. Theoretical approaches to social problems
2. Modernization and social problems in China
3. The evolution of the Communist Party and State since 1978
4. Rural problems
5. Urbanization and migration
6. Social inequality
7. Social resistance
8. Aging population
9. Crime trends and responses of criminal justice system
10. Environmental problems
11. Illicit Drugs and AIDS
12. Good/Bad Technology

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Gender in Asia
courses.description: (UGEC2970 is double-coded with ANTH2330.)  This course focuses on gender in the Asian region. A comparative approach will be taken to reflect diversity and resemblance, continuity and discontinuity, and historical and contemporary influences on gender within countries in the Asian region. Societies studied may vary from year to year, and may include Hong Kong, mainland China, India, Japan, Korea, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Chinese across societies. Gender issues and conditions will be examined within different contexts, covering such areas as language, class, work, family and kinship, health, sexuality, education, religion, development and politics.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEC2970 is double-coded with ANTH2330. 
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2330. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.course_attributes: Shared Learning Activities with ANTH5240
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. 
Students learn to appreciate that in Asia, a vast and culturally diverse region, in an era of globalization and spread of consumerism and tourism, the concepts, roles and relations of gender in
Asia
are changing rapidly. Students will examine how gender as one of the guiding principles of social life takes various forms in different Asian cultures.
2. 
Students will learn a cross-cultural perspective to understanding the similarities and differences, as well as the change and continuity in the region.
3. 
A
focus on how gender interacts with the family and marriage will challenge students to rethink taken-for-granted concepts and social behavior, and in the process develop critical thinking on such contested phenomena as public-private divide, the body and the social, religion, ethnicity, and class.

courses.title: Criminals and the Law
courses.description: (UGEC2983 is double-coded with SOCI2116.)  Students enrolled in this cross-disciplinary course will address three basic questions: “why do people become criminals”, “who makes criminal law”, and “how is criminal law enforced”. Specifically, this course will include topics such as the social causes of criminal behaviour, the role of criminal law in social control, and the operation of the criminal justice system (their internal interaction and external interaction with other social organizations). Comparative and local empirical research will also be drawn to explore the crime problems and the development of criminal law and the criminal justice system in USA, PRC, Taiwan and Hong Kong. In addition, to strengthen the students’ understandings on the current criminal justice system, students will be given one field opportunity to directly experience police departments, courts or prisons in Hong Kong.

courses.course_syllabus:
This course is an introduction of concepts and theories on crime, law and criminal justice system and their application to Chinese society. It will focus on how social structure and social policy could influence criminal behaviours and how society reacts to such behaviours.
1. Overview of Crime, Law and Justice: subject matters and key research questions
2. Types of crime, crime patterns, and crime statistics (official data, self-report data, and victimization data)
3. Organization of crime, such as fencing networks and black society
4. Social change and crime trends
5. Theories to explain crime: deterrence, rational choice, disorganization, anomie, social learning, social control, opportunity/routine activity, labelling, and conflict theory etc.
6. Classical Thoughts on Law and Society
7. Law-Making (state power and benefit groups; balance between liberty and public safety; penology) and Law-Processing (the role of law in social control; Paradigms and models of the criminal justice system)
8. Police: operation, theories and research
9. Courts: operation, theories and research
10. Correction: operation, theories and research

courses.title: Globalization and Culture
courses.description: (UGEC2990 is double-coded with ANTH2520.)  Globalization is economically transforming the world, as national borders become increasingly irrelevant before the global flow of money and goods. But globalization also has a great impact on cultures across the globe, as products from Coca-Cola to iPods, and ideas from human rights to ideals of beauty to ideologies of terrorism, intrude everywhere. This course examines how globalization is fundamentally transforming the meanings of culture. The course objectives are to enable students: (1) to have greater insight into the processes of “the globalization of culture"”, and (2) to better understand the nature of their own culture and selves within a globalizing world.

courses.title: Living healthy: social influences and social determinants
courses.description: Health is a fundamental aspect of human existence. We all want good health, effective treatments of illness and affordable health care. Yet we are faced with many challenges and controversies in our pursuit of good health: glaring inequality in health and longevity, the prevalence of unhealthy lifestyle, the conflicts between patients and doctors, the uncertainty of medical treatments and medical knowledge, and the ever-increasing health care spending. In this course, we dissect these issues from the perspectives of social sciences. We first assess the social determinants of health and illness and examine the following topics: the social distribution of health and illness, societal inequality and health, social networks, social capital and health, health lifestyle and public policy, and the interaction between genetics and social environment. We then address the social organization of health and health care and discuss the following topics: the social construction of health and illness, the social context of patient-doctor relationship, and the social organization of healthcare systems. Throughout the course, we will emphasize the current COVID-19 pandemic and use it to illustrate how social and cultural factors influence health and well-being. This course helps the students understand and relate to the following UN sustainable development goals: SDG#3 good health and well-being, SDG#10 reduced inequalities and peace, SDG#16 justice and strong institutions. By illuminating the social and cultural determinants of health and well-being, this course will enrich the students’ understanding of what contributed to good health and well-being, of the unequal distribution of health and well-being, and of the role of social and political institutions in producing health. It also seeks to motivate the students to think about public policies and social interventions that may promote health and well-being, reduce social disparities in health and strengthen health-promoting institutions. SDG#1 No PovertySDG#2 Zero Hunger SDG#3 Good Health and Well-beingSDG#10 Reduced InequalitiesSDG#11 Sustainable Cities and CommunitiesSDG#16 Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions

courses.learning_outcomes:
To understand the social and cultural determinants of health and the social distribution of health and well-being (SDGs #3 and 10)
To understand the social and political institutional context that may influence health and the distribution of health (SDG #16)
To critically consider policy and social interventions that may foster health, reduce health disparities and strengthen health-promoting institutions, and reflect on the role the students can play (SDGs #3, 10 and 16)
To gain insight into the constituent components of the healthcare system and the social and political factors related to the quality, cost and accessibility of healthcare.
To learn to critically assess biomedicine from sociological perspectives
To learn to critically compare medicine to other social systems.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Gender and Sexuality in Contemporary Society
courses.description: (UGEC3203 is double-coded with GDRS3005.)  This interdisciplinary course introduces and examines gender and sexuality from a contemporary and regional perspective. Based on a cross-cultural perspective, we will read and analyze different meanings of gender and sexuality, and how these meanings are constructed. In a context of modernization campaigns and globalization processes, this course illustrates how gender relations and sexual politics are related with historical backgrounds, cultural heritage, market expansion, ideological shifts, and capitalist dynamics. The topics of gender and sexuality will be interwoven with that of migration, work, family, popular culture, mass media, and consumerism. The course will help students to understand issues of discrimination against women and girls, unpaid care and domestic work, access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights, and equal rights to economic resources, and to reflect on how to promote gender equality (SDG5 among 17 Sustainable Development Goals, SDGs, in the 2030 development agenda). Students will be encouraged to explore localized knowledge and living experiences of gender and sexuality, and to think critically about how to reduce inequality (SDG10) related to social systems of sex and gender.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Living Feminisms: Creating a Nonviolent and Collaborative Future
courses.description: (UGEC3204 is double-coded with GDRS3006.)  Living Feminisms is all about how to put feminism into practice. Specifically, it is concerned with living out feminist consciousness in every step of making fundamental and lasting social change. With this in mind, Living Feminisms is not an exposition of feminist theories per se but an exploration of how social change effort would look like when we take up feminist consciousness that transcends separateness and duality. It explores the root causes that lead to the domination system that has plagued humanity for centuries, examines the possibility of having a fundamental and lasting social transformation that supports life of all, and takes a closer look at a few selected alternative practices such as restorative justice and sharing economies that hold out hope in times of crises. The course also equips students with practical knowledge of being a change agent, introducing some practices with feminist consciousness that transform limiting beliefs about social change, nourish resilience by taking care of social and political trauma, and cultivate need-based facilitation skills and leadership that help navigate conflicts in the process of making internal as well as external transformation. To put it in a nutshell, Living Feminisms is a course that cultivates change agents with feminist consciousness.Living Feminisms deeply resonates with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) adopted by all United Nations Member States in 2015 as a blueprint for building a sustainable future by 2030. The course directly touches on alternative practices working towards the SDGs 5 (Gender Equality), 8 (Decent Work and Economic Growth), 10 (Reduced Inequalities), 11 (Sustainable Cities and Communities), 16 (Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions) and 17 (Partnerships for the Goals).

courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students will acquire both knowledge and skills of social change that are in line with feminist consciousness. Specifically, they will be able to explain the roots of the domination system and a series of factors contributing to its perpetuation, and able to make change by transforming internal and external resistance. Students will be empowered to take lead in change effort through collaboration with others and mastery of conflict transformation skills.
Students will learn to appreciate making a sustainable future requires transformation in areas broader than the conventionally defined economic realm.
courses.course_syllabus:
Class 1: How We Got Where We Are and Where Are We Heading?
·
Riane Eisler and Douglas P. Fry’s biocultural approach that explains the perpetuation of domination systems through the interaction between genes, brain development and culture, and points to ways where hope lies
Class 2: How Change Happens? A Lesson from Feminists
·
Investigating over 100 organizations in 15-year longitudinal research, Aruna Rao et al. develop a model of change that sheds lights on the mechanism of social transformation
·
Cristina Bicchieri’s work delves into the formation and change of norms
Class 3:
What Makes Things Stuck? Inaction Explained
·
How can we explain inaction of people witnessing immense suffering of others? Is the notion of false consciousness adequate? Joanna Macy, a Buddhist scholar and a veteran environmentalist, offers us some glimpse
Class 4:
Practice
: Retelling a New Story and Reconnecting to Life that We All Share
·
Understanding the impact of separateness at cognitive level is important but far from complete, Sharif Abdullah and Gretchen Ki Steidle offer us some practical advice on healing the deep-seated separateness by retelling a new story about human beings that fosters interdependence
Class 5:
Taking Action: Violent or Nonviolent or Both?
·
Taking action to initiate change at various levels of a society is commonplace for activists. What is important is the kinds of action we undertake What is nonviolence? How does it work? What are its limits?
Class 6:
Social Trauma and Social Transformation
·
Trauma is an overwhelming experience that outweighs the containing capacity of our nervous system How does trauma relate to and shape our political behaviors? Rather individualizing trauma as a single person experiences, how can we theorize collective trauma?
Class 7:
Practice
: Self-Care & Inner Resources
·
Change agents are prone to feel despair, powerlessness and hopelessness because they are more acutely aware of the enormity of suffering How to nourish our heart to make it open to pain and suffering while keeping the passion alive?
Class 8:
Reconciliation and Justice: Exploring Transitional Justice
·
Common collective responses to atrocities are either forgetting or vengeance. Is transitional justice a viable third way? How does it work? What are the experiences of the 40 Truth and Reconciliation Commissions that have ever set up in human history can tell us?
Class 9:
Sexual Violence: Exploring Restorative Justice
·
Our current justice system is a kind of retribution that punishes those who violate the law. How does it look like if we shift from retribution to restoration that focuses on needs and rebuilding of broken relationships? How controversial is it when applying to sexual violence?
Class 10:
Collaboration and Feminist Leadership: Coming to Terms with Power
·
Activism often entails working with others. Is power necessarily evil? How does feminist leadership look like? How can we consciously use power in a way that does not subjugate but empower others? How can we replace power-over with power-with, power-to and power-within? Power-cube analysis
Class 11:
Alternative Organizing - Holacracy, Sociocracy and Deep Democracy
·
There are always implicit agreements as to how to make decisions, define the nature and the scope of a task, evaluate outcome, and handle conflicts if we do not consciously decide how and what to decide
·
Quite a many grassroots organizations have been experimenting with new ways of organizing that is more efficient than representative democracy in meeting the needs of all. These alternative forms of governance include Holacracy, Sociocracy and Deep Democracy.
Class 12:
Practice
: Workshop on Convergent Facilitation
·
Convergent facilitation, developed by the feminist Miki Kashtan, a form of facilitation that caters for both willingness and efficiency in order to come up an agreement, decision and/or concrete strategies that maximally work for the needs of all within a group. The workshop will cover the whole process from the start to the end convergent facilitation is a proven one as it was applied to a group who disagreed with each other about legalization of abortion
Class 13:
Beyond Neoliberalism? Sharing Economy
·
Our current economies are profit-driven that more often than not serves a few but exploits most of other people Is it really hopeless to revise capitalism? Is Sharing Economy a viable alternative?
Class 14: Conflict Transformation: From the Personal to the International
Disagreements and conflicts among activists are commonplace. However, acquiring ways of resolving and transforming conflicts within groups is a skill that is urgently needed but seldom given enough attention this last lecture will touch on conflict resolution and mediation.

courses.title: Innovating the Future: Gender, Science and Technology
courses.description: (UGEC3213 is double-coded with GDRS3025.) This course examines the gender dimensions of innovation and novelty. The key questions are: How/Why/What/When innovation(s) are gendered? We will discuss the fluidity and messiness of doing and undoing gender in innovation practices and meanings produced. Broadly defined, innovation refers to new ideas, new knowledge, new technologies, new designs, and creative practices with the goal to solve social or technical problems. Many innovations may seem gender-neutral but are inherently imbued with gender perceptions. The course will equip students with ways to apply gender analysis to decipher innovations and innovative processes. The course incorporates sustainable development goals (SDGs) on Gender Equality and Reduced Inequalities to become more discerning toward more sustainable practices to advance Industry Innovation and Infrastructure. Using case studies from the technology culture, the routine practices, and the emergent new economy, students will learn to untangle how gender intersects with the seemingly neutral artefacts of innovation and technology. The course further covers how emergent issues of diversity and inclusion, AI and information technology, social entrepreneurship and social innovation, and leadership style could reshape the existing relationship between gender and innovation to advance sustainability and social resilience.

courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction: When are Innovation(s) Gendered?
·
Innovations in science and technology often seemed gender-neutral, when do they become gendered?
·
To innovate for a more sustainable future, having SDG goals in mind are important in any innovative ventures, and the course begins with the SDG goals on gender equality and reduced inequality to identify gaps in science and technology.
Week2: Doing and Undoing Gender in Innovation
·
We will discuss the ways that gender analysis contributes to our understanding of
innovation.
·
Embedding gender analysis in science research could help filter out inherent biases to
further advance the innovative processes.
Week 3: Why/How is Innovation Gendered?
·
While debates about the gender dimensions of technology are many, has feminism
changed science? Why and how innovation is persistently gendered?
·
How do scholars explain the gender gap in innovation?
Week 4: Gender and Technology
·
We will discuss different feminist approaches to study the relationship between gender
and technology and the ways to reduce gender inequality in the technology field.
Week 5: Gender/Sexuality in Science and Engineering Education
·
We will discuss the ways that experiences in science and technology may contribute to
persistent gender inequality. What are some ways to bridge this gap?
Week 6: Gender and STEM Career
·
We will discuss how different identities play a great role in STEM career that may reproduce inequality.
Week 7: Science, Technology, and Medicine
·
We will discuss how people infused gendered bias on scientific discovery and how
gender and sexuality shape the use of new technologies in the field of science and medicine.
Week 8: Gender in Creative Industries
·
Innovation is not limited to science and technology. The emergent creative industries are
also the place for innovative practices to take shape. We will discuss how gender and the
creative industries are mutually shaped.
Week 9: Gender and Entrepreneurship
·
Entrepreneurship is understood as the process to start and launch a business and
is an important part of innovative endeavors. Scholars have explored how the entrepreneurship
process is inherently gendered.
Week 10: Gender, Social Entrepreneurship, and Social Innovation
·
Social entrepreneurship and social innovation are an emergent field where cross-sectoral
and interdisciplinary collaborations are encouraged to come up with better solutions to
complex social problems. We will discuss how gender interacts with this emergent field.
Week 11: Sustainability, Diversity, and Inclusion
·
Sustainability, diversity, and inclusion are currently widely incorporated in social
entrepreneurship and social innovation. We will discuss how gender analysis could contribute to
these pillars.
·
How do these pillars support and incubate innovation for sustainable development? (SDG Goal 9 on building resilient infrastructure, promote inclusive and sustainable industrialization and foster innovation)
Week 12: (En)Gendering Innovation, Entrepreneurship, and Leadership I
·
We will discuss how gender-sensitive leadership could help engender innovation and
entrepreneurship.
Week 13: (En)Gendering Innovation, Intrapreneurship, and Leadership II
·
What if the changes in gender and innovation need to happen from within an organization? We
will discuss how intrapreneurship could reshape gender relations within the organization and
provide the ground for gender-sensitive innovation.
·
intrapreneurial leaders are key actors to advance cross-sectoral innovation and knowledge creation
for a sustainable future. We will revisit the SDGs and think about how to integrate them into the science and technology fields.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: A Screen of One’s Own: Women and Films
courses.description: (UGEC3214 is double-coded with GDRS3026.) This course examines the rich tradition of feminist film theory and provides students with an understanding of its main concerns and debates. Topics will include the key semiotic and psychoanalytic approaches of the 1970s-1990s, classic films which have inspired feminist debate, avant-garde cinema, local cinema, independent cinema, and postmodern cinema, as well as recent cinematic re-conceptualizations and exploration of gender and sexuality local and abroad. In systems of representation from fine art to mainstream cinema to advertising, women have been constructed and existed as spectacle or passive object “to-be-looked-at,” in Laura Mulvey’s now often quoted words. Following her trail, feminist critics turned their attention to mainstream films and popular media addressed to female spectators and exposed the contradictions within and between the notion of “women’s pictures” and the diversity of female experience. Local cinemas and independent creators also tell their own unique stories of women’s lives in dramatically different cultural contexts. Critics from other fields further complicate these images by examining them through lens including race, class, ability, queerness, and more.Mulvey’s groundbreaking analysis of gendered looking relations in classical Hollywood cinema has since generated numerous analyses of the place of women as spectacle or passive object in films “cut to the measure of [male] desire.” Critics around the world showed how different groups of women attempt to take control of their positioning through viewing or using texts in their own ways, and by creating their own. What happens when female-identified artists, audiences, and theorists look back, and seek to rebel against such cinematic traditions by experimenting with alternative visual languages and narrative tools? This course starts with the paradigm of narrative film analysis that Mulvey outlined in the 1970s and move on to explore a wider range of questions in feminist film studies, including spectatorship, authorship, popular culture, character stereotypes in genre films, self-representation, (g)local cinema, and new feminist media. Students would be introduced to trailblazing works by female filmmakers worldwide, special focus will be placed onto important works in Hong Kong cinema for critical examination and comparative studies. Through critical reflections on notions such as gender stereotypes, representation, power, diversity, and equality, the course engages directly with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) adopted by all United Nations Member States in 2015 by engaging directly with the SDGs 5 (Gender Equality) and 10 (Reduced Inequalities).

courses.learning_outcomes:
Learning Outcomes
Become familiar with key theoretical concepts such as the gaze, desire, intersectionality, as well as feminist, queer and transgender creative resistance to traditional gender hierarchies.
Able to deconstruct media text, and understand their hidden meaning, especially in relation to cultural production and the construction of sexual and gender norms, and how they pertain to existing inequalities in society
Critically engage with biased and stereotypical media representations related to gender and sexuality
Possess knowledge about and appreciate works by female, queer and transgender filmmakers
Understand, relate and apply key feminist film and media studies concepts to daily viewing and creative practices
Conceptualize, structure, articulate and present original ideas, both in written assignments and during tutorial discussions, on feminist film and media studies
Design, direct and regulate own study plan for problem-based learning, from identifying the problem, setting learning objectives, researching on relevant information, reflecting on what has been learnt, to applying the knowledge to future problems
Become familiar the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) adopted by all United Nations Member States in 2015 by engaging directly with the SDGs 5 (Gender Equality) and 10 (Reduced Inequalities), and are motived to implement them and promote them.
courses.course_syllabus:
Lesson 1 Introduction: Feminist Film Theories, Queer Spectatorship, and Critical Literacy
Lesson 2 Feminist Film Theories: History and Key concepts (focus on the origin and background of the emergence of Feminist film theories and their contributions, related to SDGs 5 and 10)
Lesson 3 The Gaze, Desire, and Female Images (focus on representation of women as “marginalized / objectified groups”, and how biased media representation marginalizes them, related to SDG 5)
Lesson 4 After Mulvey: The Gaze, Feminist Spectatorship, and a screen of one’s own (focus on attempts to find new representations of women, related to SDG 10)
Lesson 5 What women can we see: Housewife, immigrants, old women, lesbians, and other (de)politicized identities (focus on representation of “marginalized groups”, and how biased media representation marginalizes them, related to SDG 5)
Lesson 6 Women in the Underworld: Sex, violence, and fetishism (focus on representation of “marginalized groups”, and how biased media representation marginalizes them, related to SDG 5)
Lesson 7 Women in Action Films: Sluts, victims, femme fatale, trophies, ass-kicking chicks, violent women, and action heroines (focus on under-representation and biased representation of women in the popular genre, and how it is changing, related to SDGs 5 and 10)
Lesson 8 Monstrous feminine: A Comparative Study of Women in Horror Films from Hong Kong, Japan, Thailand, Taiwan, and Hollywood (examining gender stereotypes and its relationship to gendered horror representation in media, related to SDG 5)
Lesson 9 The Imperial Gaze: (Post)coloniality, Geopolitics and Gender Representation (examining racism and its relationship to gender representation in media, related to SDG 5)
Lesson 10 Pornographic Bodies and Perverse Pleasure: Cult films, sexploitation, and pornography (focusing on representation of female sexuality, and how it is affected women’s lives, related to SDG 5)
Lesson 11 Gender in Production: Women in media industry, Visibility, and Recognition (examining the gender inequalities in media industry, and what is done to change them related to SDGs 5 and 10)
Lesson 12 “Girl Power” Feminism and Popular Culture: The rise of “women films”, Queer cinema, the trans-question, and intersectionality (focus on movements that strive for greater equality and diversity in representation of gender and sexuality, related to SDG 10)
Lesson 13 A Feminist Critic’s Guide to Active Watching (focus on critical reflections and possible actions to strive for greater equality and diversity, related to SDG 10)

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Media Representations of Minorities in Hong Kong
courses.description: (UGEC3215 is double-coded with GDRS3214.)  How do we understand the notion of “minority”? And how does “minority”, look like, in cinema? This course examines the rich tradition of critical film theory and provides students with an understanding of its main concerns and debates, concerning “minority” identities and subalternity. Addressing key discussions about media representations of “minority”, the course will look at the politics of representation and its impacts, both on- and off-screen. We will be looking at how media works to construct “the Other” in different contexts, and delve into important work which have inspired minority cinema, subaltern cinema, avant-garde cinema, local cinema, and independent cinema among other counter-movements, as well as recent re-conceptualizations and exploration of representations marginalized identities, positions, and experiences, local and abroad. Across different systems of representation, from fine art to mainstream cinema to advertising, different groups, especially marginalized ones with little access to the mechanisms of production, have been constructed and existed as spectacle or passive object “to-be-looked-at,” in critical film theorist Laura Mulvey’s now often quoted words. Lacking representations both behind the camera and in front of it, how are the lives of different social “minorities” affected by biased media representations? How are stereotypes and biases created, disseminated, perpetuated, and reproduced through media, and to what consequences? Mulvey’s groundbreaking analysis of gendered looking relations in classical Hollywood cinema has since generated numerous analyses of the standings of different socially and culturally marginalized groups, such as ethnic minorities, queer communities, and people with disabilities, etc., as spectacle or passive object “in films cut to the measure of desire” of the dominant social groups.What happens when “minority” artists, audiences, and theorists look back, and seek to rebel against such cinematic traditions by experimenting with alternative visual languages and narrative tools? Critics showed how different marginalized groups around the world attempt to take control of their positioning through viewing or using texts in their own ways, and by creating their own. Minority cinemas and independent creators have been actively carving out space to tell their own unique stories of lives at the margin in dramatically different cultural contexts, and these images are further complicated by engagements with them through the intersecting lens including ethnicity, class, gender, sexuality, ability, queerness, and more.In the course, we will look at how socially marginalized groups, such as gay and lesbians, transgender persons, ethnic minorities, women in different stages of their lives, people with mental illness, teenagers, the elderlyand many others are portrayed, and seek to expand their on-screen existence in Hong Kong media. In the exploration, we will engage with key questions in critical film studies, including spectatorship, authorship, popular culture, character stereotypes in genre films, self-representation, systems of media production, pro-sumer culture, (g)local cinema, alternative cinema, and new media. Students would be introduced to trailblazing works by “minority” filmmakers and media creators worldwide, and important cinematic and media movements that challenge the status-quo. Special focus will be placed onto important works in Hong Kong and Asia for critical examination and comparative studies. Through critical exercise and reflection on notions such as power, diversity, equality, and freedom, the course aligns with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) adopted by all United Nations Member States in 2015 by engaging directly with the SDGs 5 (Gender Equality) and 10 (Reduced Inequalities).

courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1
Introduction: What is “minority”? (SDG 5 & 10)
- Introducing the notion of “minority”
Week 2
Theories about Minority, Other, and Subalternity (SDG 5 & 10)
- Introducing theories about “minority” as state and status, and other related theories
Week 3
Construction and representation of minorities in media (SDG 5 & 10)
- Placing the discussion of “minority” within the realm of media, and explore the mechanism of constructing and recreating “minority” through media production
Week 4
Minority lives in Hong Kong: Who are they? (SDG 5 & 10)
- Understanding the notion of “minority” in the context of Hong Kong society and cinema
Week 5
Sexual minorities: The very different existence of gays and lesbians (SDG 5 & 10)
- Explore the different representations of sexual minorities (namely homosexual men and women) in Hong Kong cinema, and the possible reasons behind the different strategies of portrayal
Week 6
Gender minority: Transgender, transexual, transvestite, or… what are you? (SDG 5 & 10)
- Examine how the transgender community are subjected to biased and inaccurate portrayal, and how it hinders understanding and de-stigmatization
Week 7
Who has sexual agency and who don’t? Teenage sexuality and the asexual existence of children and older women (SDG 5 & 10)
- Examine how the sexuality of teenagers and older women are rendered invisible in media, and its consequences
Week 8
Problematic (gendered) existence: Mothers, divorcee, widows, and the “leftovers” (SDG 5 & 10)
- Examine how women of different statuses are (not) portrayed in media
Week 9
“Broken people”: Mental illness, disabilities, victims, and people at the bottom (SDG 10)
- Looking at how ablism and other hegemony at work in media to the exclusion of different social groups
Week 10
The constructed notion of “South-east Asian”: Who is a Hong Konger and the inconvenient racial others (SDG 10)
- Inspect how the construction of the “Hong-Konger identity” is done via the exclusion of certain communities in Hong Kong, focusing on racial differences
Week 11
Are they also one of us? New immigrants, indigenous people, and boat people (SDG 5 & 10)
- Continue to discuss the construction of the “Hong-Konger identity” via the exclusion of certain communities within the Chinese population of Hong Kong
Week 12
Talking back from the margin: The counter-narratives of minority cinema (SDG 5 & 10)
- Introducing efforts from different communities to change the narratives
Week 13
Presentation & Conclusion

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Family and Society
courses.description: (UGEC3224 is double-coded with GDRS3009.)  This course examines issues revolving the family as a social institution in different cultures. It explores processes of how the family is constructed in different forms as it intersects with various social systems including kinship, marriage, class, ethnicity, religion, and political economy. Particular attention is paid to how family as a gendered construction, while being a basic principle of social life globally, exhibits great diversity as it shapes and is shaped by local histories, traditions, and state policies. In an era of globalization and transnational mobility, the ideology and practice of the family are rapidly changing, but there are simultaneously trends of reversion and localization. Students will read ethnographies and develop cross-cultural perspectives on classic and contemporary issues concerning the family, such as work and domesticity, motherhoods and fatherhoods, sexual orientations, reproductive technologies, surrogacy and adoption. Students learn to critically think and articulate about family issues, and will acquire enhanced knowledge and skills in reflexive thinking and positive communication, cultural sensitivity, and diversity and inclusion. The course is relevant to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) adopted by all United Nations Member States in 2015, in particular SDGs 5 (Gender Equality), 10 (Reduced Inequalities) and 16 (Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions).

Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:

reflect on and apply concepts of cultural relativism, and to analyze ethnocentrism and explore ways to terminate racial discrimination.
reflect on their ability and steps to take as change-makers and agents of justice and peace.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. The Family: An anthropological perspective (SDG #5, 10, 16)
The family is often imagined to be a social institution with a set of values and relationships shared by everyone in society. This is far from reality. In this lecture we look at the definitions of family across cultures, and look at how family interacts with different social systems such as religion, political system and modes of production, and investigate how family values may differ in different ethnic groups and how they change over time. Concepts of cultural relativism and holism will be introduced.
2. Kinship and lineage (SDG #5, 10)
Kinship and lineage have played an important part in the political economy of society, in the past as well as in present time. In this lecture we discuss the commonalities as well as the differences across cultures, and look at the factors leading to continuity and/or change, such as urbanization, globalization, appearance of reproductive technologies, adoption, surrogacy, and changing values in sexuality.
3. Role of marriage in family (SDG #5, 10, 16)
This lecture looks at how marriage may or may not be related to family formation, and the role of marriage in society. In addition, marriage regulations and practices are highly related to gender ideologies. These relations exist in diverse forms and have transformed over time, for example as governments promulgate new marriage laws and as civil society demands for reform.
4. Domesticity and gender division of labor (SDG #5, 10, 16)
How was the idea “man are breadwinners; women are homemakers” formulated in history and how is it challenged in contemporary society? This lecture will discuss issues of domesticity and how gender division of labor at home is related to the gender division of labor in society. We will examine the roles of religion and science, as well as of the church and government in the production of gendered social arrangements. Students will learn to identify systemic barriers to gender equality.
5. Violence against Women (SDG #5, 16)
Why are women the majority of victims of domestic violence across cultures? Why do many women choose to stay in abusive relations? In this lecture we look at the social and cultural factors that influence women’s decision to confront, escape, or endure domestic violence, and discuss how family and ideologies and practices have played a part in the perpetuation of VAW in different cultures. Students will investigate potential solutions for VAW as a form of gender inequality.
6. Parenthood and socialization (SDG #5, 10)
Do all parents love their children? Do parents in different cultures raise their children the same way? Why is raising children in families with same-sex parents, single parents, and migrant parents considered problematic? If socialization is the way to reproduce socially acceptable individuals, what form, content, and means should it take? This lecture seeks to dispel the misconception that parent-child relations are natural and uniform, by looking at the diverse forms of parenthood and ways of socialization in different cultures.
7. Spousal relations: duties, affection, and intimacy (SDG #5, 10)
How is spousal relationship culturally constructed? What are the components of spouse-hood and how do they relate to politics, economics, religion and other social systems? Why do extra-marital affairs happen and how does society deal with it? This lecture looks at the ideology and practice of spouse-hood across different cultures, and asks what role it has in formulating the family as social institution.
8. Globalization, affluence and livelihood (SDG #5, 10, 16)
This lecture looks at global transformation processes and how they affect the family both as a social institution and as a network of related individuals. We look at how consumerism, social media, and converging values seemingly sync-ing familial structures and emotions across the globe, but at the same time noting how families in different societies, as they undergo globalization and wealth polarization, are torn by desires of economic growth and downward social mobility.
9. Transnational mobility and family (SDG #5, 10)
In an era of globalization, more and more people cross national borders for a better life, creating transnational families as family members live in different countries in the form of split households, or as individuals become members of family in a different culture. In this lecture we look at this growing phenomenon and discuss issues about acculturation, family relations and power dynamics, how affines and agnates create transnational communities, and what happens to those who are left behind in the hometown.
10. New kinship and alternative family (SDG #5, 10)
We will discuss how arrangements such as same-sex marriage, cohabitation, and polygamous relations would challenge conventional understandings of kinship and family in society. We will reflect on these issues in relation to contemporary debates on heterosexual normativity, monogamy, and same-sex relations.
11. Doing family in China (SDG #5, 16)
The concept of family has various levels of meanings in Chinese culture, and throughout Chinese history these have transformed in response to the needs and ideologies of the time. While Han families may share certain idealized views of the family as a social system, its practice is perhaps as varied as the number of families. Ethnic groups and Chinese overseas communities add to this complexity as their worldviews, religions, and socioeconomic environments acculturate thinking and behavior that differ from what is understood as Chinese core values.
12. Doing family in Asia (SDG #5, 16)
This lecture will bring together ethnographic cases in Asia to illustrate the interaction of different social systems revolving around the family. By comparing changes and continuities of family formation and relations in the region using a cross-cultural perspective, we are able to reflect on our own culture, and understand the pros and cons of the ideologies and practices that we are socialized in.
13. Family, power, and intersectionality (SDG #5, 10, 16)
This lecture discusses individuals’ multi-layered identities and how these intersect with family membership. We will examine roles, statuses and power generated from positions in the family, gender and ethnicity, at work and school, on the media and more. The multiple locales in which individuals perform their everyday experiences are examined holistically, which helps us rethink how seemingly “natural” behavior are really cultural constructs, and how taken-for-granted ideas of family membership shape our everyday lives, our life goals as individuals, and the regulations and resources that constitute society.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Gender Biases in Education and the Workplace
courses.description: (UGEC3225 is double-coded with GDRS3024.)  Educational and occupational accomplishments vary dramatically among individuals and profoundly affect lives. Importantly, gender is among the powerful individual characteristics that affect people's experiences in educational and work settings. Gender shapes youths' experience and outcomes of education across the globe and across history. This course is designed to introduce to students, with a critical mindset, important contemporary issues at the intersection of gender, education and jobs. The topics address the role of gender in school- and related preferences and achievements, with a focus on social and cognitive approaches. For example, what is quality education (SDG goal 4) and why is it important to evaluate it with a gender perspective? Do men and women really differ in their abilities, and if so, by how much? Is personal interest a better explanation of gender imbalances in occupations? What are the ways that biases exist in education and the workplace, and how do teachers, parents, and employers contribute to gender biases (SDG goal 5)? Can gender equality in performance and hiring be improved by removing stereotypes? The literature will cover childhood, adolescence as well as adulthood in order to provide insight into the age-related changes of the gender issues. Particular attention will be paid to issues that relate closely to daily life, both local and international. Empirical evidence will be reviewed to illustrate the gender biases and substantiate the explanatory theories. Potential interventions to address gender biases in education and the workplace will also be discussed.

courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Be aware of gender differences and similarities and gendered treatments in learning and occupational contexts in daily life
2. Be knowledgeable of the classical and latest research on gender in educational and occupational contexts and outcomes
3. Be more informed about the causes of gendered phenomena in educational and occupational contexts and how to deal with them constructively
4. Be able to reflect on how gender has affected themselves as a learner and achiever
courses.course_syllabus:
This course is designed to introduce to students, with a critical mindset, important contemporary issues at the
intersection of gender and education and achievement. Collectively, the topics address the gender-education nexus in academic, occupational, and social domains from childhood through adulthood. We will pay particular attention to issues that relate closely to daily life, both local and international. Theories and data will be drawn mainly from Psychology but will also come from other disciplines.
In terms of SDGs, the course is most relevant for goal #4 (Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education) and goal #5 (Achieve gender equality and empower the marginalised gender).
Major concepts and topics:
1. 
Quality education and equitable workplace
Open discussion and review impressions on education and occupational contexts locally and internationally to assess if our current education is inclusive and equitable, and if gender equality and marginalization of gender are still pertinent questions in our society.
Why is it important to achieve gender equality and empower the marginalized gender?
2. 
Gender differences and similarities in educational and occupational achievement
This topic includes questions such as: Gender differences is a topic that has fascinated researchers and is a topic of daily conversation. Do men/boys really differ from women/girls, and how? How big are the differences? Does it depend on contexts?
3. 
Gender-related academic and occupational interests and goals
Some argue that the gender gaps in academic and occupational outcomes may not be entirely the result of differences in ability or prejudice, but differences in the interests and goals of men/boys and women/girls. Are there gender differences in what people prefer as study subjects and occupations? What do men and women look for in their jobs?
4. 
Gender socialization in schools
In modern society, we spend almost ¼ of our life attending school. While a lot of gender socialization occurs at home, the school is also an important ground for gender socialization. What messages do schools and teachers send to students? How does sexism occur at schools and what interventions have been tested?
5. 
Gender segregation at schools: The case of single-sex education
Single-sex schools exist in many countries over the globe. However, few may notice that such institutional segregation of gender in the context of education has been a matter of intense social and scientific debate in the West. What are the rationales for the setting up of single-sex education? Do they live up to the tests of scientific studies? What are the possible consequences of gender segregation at schools?
6. 
Motivation, stereotypes and engagement: Does gender matter?
On the personal level, various psychological mechanisms may be at work to produce gender differences in educational and occupational achievement. What are some of these mechanisms? For example, how does s
tereotype threat and self efficacy theories apply to create gendered phenomena to make education inequitable?
7. 
Gender biases in the workplace
Women’s status in the workplace has improved drastically over the decades. However, have we gotten rid of gender biases in the workplace? What are some of the ways that gender biases manifest in today’s workplace, personally or institutionally, explicitly or implicitly?
8. 
Interventions to address gender gaps in the workplace
If gender gaps still exist in the workplace, what can be done about it? For example, what interventions may be effective in narrowing the gender gap in STEM participation? Many companies have adopted a quota policy to increase their representation of women. What have research shown about the impact of having more women or just more diversity in groups?
The teaching and learning approach will be a mix of teacher-guided and student-centred activities. Lectures will introduce the background knowledge of each topic and review the required readings. Then, students will be engaged in active group discussions. Before class, students have to post intellectual questions concerning the assigned readings. They will also look for additional discussion materials (academic articles, news reports, blog posts, etc.) and share them in class during discussions and presentations. The teacher and tutor(s) will monitor and guide the discussions. Towards the end of the course, students will present a poster on a self-selected topic related to gender and education/achievement in a mini-conference, and write an essay on the same topic to conclude their learned knowledge and demonstrate their ability to critically analyse the topic.

courses.description: (UGEC3227 is double-coded with GDRS3021.)  This course critically explores the development of LGBTQI+ studies as an interdisciplinary field of inquiry. It traces how LGBTQI+ communities develop against the backdrops of social forces and social oppression. It analyzes the cultural, social and legal environments that LGBTQI+ people live with, in diverse spheres such as families, education, employment, health and the media. The discussions focus on both the structural constraints that LGBTQI+ people face, but also the agency and resilience they display. It explores the development of contemporary LGBTQI+ identities and social movements, as well as the politics involved. The course also asks how gender and sexual diversity is understood in different parts of the world in an era of globalization. Students are also exposed to different practices, policies and laws that are related to LGBTQI+ people’s lives.The Sustainable Development Goals vow to work towards a society where no one if left behind, particularly those who are most vulnerable and marginalized. In many parts of the world, LGBTQI+ people are historically amongst the most vulnerable and marginalized in society. This course will discuss the unequal treatment they face in cultural, social, political and legal systems and discuss how such inequality may be addressed.

courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, the student will:
- Students are expected to be able to debunk how sexualities and intimacies are shaped by larger social forces and therefore socially constructed.
- Students are expected to be able to analyze the social and historical development of LGBTQI+ identities and communities.
- Students are expected to gain an understanding of LGBTQI+ lives in contemporary societies from empirical examples in diverse spheres of life.
- Students are expected to be able to critically examine how sexualities intersect with other social categories, such as race, ethnicity, class, age and disability;
- Students are expected to critically assess social messages regarding sexualities and intimacies and question the extent to which they themselves agree or disagree with the conventional ‘definitions’ and ‘norms’ in society.
- Students are expected to be able to explore and assess different practice, policy and legal options that are related to LGBTQI+ people’s lives.

- Introductions
This week provides an overview of the theories and content covered by the course.
- Same-sex attracted individuals and gender diverse people – anthropological, cultural and historical traditions to the social construction of sexuality – defining diverse sexualities as different and deviant

- Social oppression and the emergence of the early gay liberation movement
This week explores social oppression faced by sexual minorities and the growth of the early gay liberation movement.
- Sexual identities: ‘ethnic group’ or social construction? Global/local identities? Queering identities?
This week explores some of the contemporary debates about the nature of sexual identities.
- Gender diversity and transgender
This week introduces students to the social, legal and political realities that transgender people face.
- Intersex
This week introduces students to the social, legal and political realities that intersex people face.
- LGBTQI+ and intimacy and personal life
This week explores the intimacy and personal life of LGBTQI+ people.
- LGBTQ+ and education and employment
This week explores the education and employment experiences of LGBTQI+ people.
- LGBTQI+, health and well-being
This week explores the health and well-being of LGBTQI+ people.
- LGBTQI+ and the media
This week explores how media represents LGBTQI+ people.
- Margins within the margins? LGBTQI+ and intersections
This week explores how LGBTQI+ identities intersect with other social categories.
- Where are we heading? LGBTQI+ politics? Rights and equality? Post-gay era? Beyond gender and sexuality? The utopia to aim for and the realities to live with
This week explores future directions of LGBTQI+ identities and politics and concludes the course.

courses.title: Public Policy and Social Minorities in Hong Kong
courses.description: (UGEC3228 is double-coded with GDRS3008.)  This course examines the social construction of minorities and the history of Hong Kong public policy towards them, including legal changes, social institutions, immigration policy, and political mobilization. Current debates in public policies such as anti-discrimination legislation, education policies of ethnic minorities, disciplining of youth and anti-poverty scheme will also be evaluated within this context. We will draw on an array of intellectual resources ranging from political economy, critical race theory, feminism, phenomenology and queer theory to examine issues about racial/ethnic minorities, the economically underprivileged, minorities with disabilities, sexual/erotic minorities, gender minorities and youth in light of the latest scholarly discussions on multiculturalism, pluralism and the politics of difference and social recognition.The course is relevant to the Sustainable Development Goals 5 (Gender Equality), 10 (Reduced Inequalities) and 16 (Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions) with a focus on how public policy plays an important role in obstructing and facilitating the attainment of these goals.

courses.course_syllabus:
1
Conceptualizing Public Policy
- To give students a schematic view of the course
- To understand various approaches to defining public policy as both a subject matter and an intellectual discipline
- To conceptualize public policy as consisting in normative ideas, normative frameworks, and rules and regulations
2
Ideas and Concepts in Public Policy I
- To explore ideas and concepts such as equality, equity and justice that are key to the study of public policy
- To introduce the politics of needs interpretation, inquiring in what sense a need is a claim and when a need is considered worthy of being met by public policy
3
Ideas and Concepts in Public Policy II
- To continue the exploration of key ideas and concepts in public policy with a focus on the historical development of citizenship, social exclusion and social minority
4
Power, Privilege and Oppression
- To learn to make conceptual distinctions between prejudice, discrimination, privilege and oppression
- To appreciate the social privileges each of us has and how they influence life chances
- To complicate the idea of social justice, shifting from a distributive paradigm to the politics of difference
5
Conceptual Tools for Analyzing Public Policy
- To identify some key processes and elements of public policy analysis and learn to classify approaches to policy analysis by type
- To master how to apply the rational model, rights-based approach and “What is the Problem Represented to be?”, WPR for short, an approach that analyzes public policy from a poststructural perspective
6
Setting the Scene: The Formulation of Hong Kong Public Policy
- To understand the historical, social, legal and political context in which public policy in Hong Kong has been formulated since the late 70s up to now
- To discern some significant changes before and after the resumption of sovereignty of Hong Kong by the People’s Republic of China
7
Racial/Ethnic Minorities
- To discern the tension within liberal democratic regimes and how the tension might translate into one among races and/or ethnicities within a nation or a place
- To explore multiculturalism as a response to that tension with a brief historical overview of its emergence
- To question the idea of race and ethnicity and inquire racial and ethnic minorities in Hong Kong with a focus on how public policy contributes to their marginalization
- To examine the current Race Discrimination Ordinance and evaluate how well it curbs racial and ethnic discrimination
8
The Poor, New and Old
- To situate Hong Kong in the global neoliberalism to explain the government’s reluctance to address the problem poverty
- To discuss how poverty is measured, and the differences and similarities between absolute poverty and relative poverty
- To examine the Comprehensive Social Security System (CSSA) and the government’s initiatives on poverty eradication in recent years
9
Minorities with Disabilities
- To problematize the idea of disability by critiquing the medical model, one that takes disability as a physical impairment
- To examine how the current public policy on disability that is strongly informed by the medical model establishes norms that divide the normal from the abnormal
- To explore Crip Theory and the phenomenological approach as alternatives to the medical model and their policy implications
10
Sexual and Erotic Minorities
- To understand the plight of sexual and erotic minorities in Hong Kong and their struggle for equal rights
- To discuss when discrimination is wrong by engaging in some controversial court cases about sexual orientation discrimination
- To discuss the idea of accommodation in the form of legal exemptions and examine its limits
11
Gender Minorities
- To examine institutional discrimination against gender minorities in public policy with a focus on the political struggle within and without the institutions, showing the dynamics between public policy and civil society
12
Youth
- To revisit the “What is the Problem Represented to be?” approach with the policy on youth
- To analyze the construction of youth in Hong Kong policy in the colonial time and post-97

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Understanding Masculinities and Social Change
courses.description: (UGEC3229 is double-coded with GDRS3007.)  This course examines men’s diverse experiences as boys/men and public discourses and practices about masculinities. It will focus on how the gendered social order influences men’s actions and the way men perceive themselves, other men, women, and social situations. It will pay special attention to the exploration of the relationships between multiple dimensions of social relations and inequalities including gender, race/ethnicity, class, and sexual orientation. It will address issues such as: male socialization, boyhood culture, male body images, male friendship, male sexuality and fertility, men’s experiences as fathers, male aggression and violence, men’s commitments to sports and work, and media representations of boys and men in contemporary culture. It will also explore female masculinities and queer masculinities and to what extent they post challenges to hegemonic masculinity. Students will be introduced to the latest developments and their global networks, and to evaluate the prospects for social change in how men may think, feel, and act otherwise.The course resonates with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) adopted by all United Nations Member States in 2015 by engaging directly with the SDGs 5 (Gender Equality) and 10 (Reduced Inequalities), and 16 (Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions) through critical engagement with different discourses and phenomenon related to masculinities.

courses.course_syllabus:
1: Making men and men in crisis
In this lecture, we will introduce briefly the current situation and discussions surrounding masculinities in the world today.
2: Theorising Masculinities
In this lecture, we will introduce men's studies as a discipline, and outlines some major theories / thoughts / points they propose.
3: Gendering boys' and men's lives
In this lecture, we will talk about how gender is "taught" and "learned", beginning from the family.
4: masculinities and the schooling of boys
In this lecture, we will talk about how gender is "taught" and "learned" in the family, and continues in schools. We will look into school rules, curriculum, and classroom dynamics, etc.
5: masculinities, work and labor
In this lecture, we will talk about how gender plays out in the workplace - how it affects one's choice of work, workplace dynamics, etc.
6: men, sexuality, the body and power
In this lecture, we will talk about how men relate to the concept of sexuality.
7: masculinities in global contexts
In this lecture, we will talk about how masculinities is understood and played out differently in different cultures.
8: Chinese masculinities
In this lecture, we will focus on talking about masculinities in Chinese culture and traditional Chinese societies, and its recent developments.
9: men, masculinities, and sports
In this lecture, we will focus on the construction of masculinities in sports.
10: homophobia and queer masculinities
In this lecture, we will talk about how requirements of masculinities intersects with marginalised sexuality.
11: female masculinities
In this lecture, we will talk about how masculinities can be embodied by someone of female gender, and how it challenges the notion of normative masculinity.
12: men and feminism and men's movement
In this lecture, we will talk about how men's role in feminism, and its backlash.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Buddhist Art and Architecture
courses.description: (UGEC3308 is double-coded with FAAS3110.) This survey explores the historical development of Buddhist visual and material culture from around 5th century BCE to 20th century CE in Asia from a trans-regional perspective. Major topics include, but are not limited to, (1) worship icons, (2) materiality and ritual protocols, (3) iconography and iconometry, (4) illustrations, manuscripts, and pictorial narratives, (5) relics and other charismatic objects, (6) sacred space and monumental architecture, (7) artistic styles and their development and diffusion, and (8) patronage and socio-political context. The course also introduces the religion of Buddhism viewed uniquely in light of archaeological context.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEC3308 is double-coded with FAAS3110. 
Not for Fine Arts Majors; and students who have taken FAAS3110. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students will be able to:
Gain proficiency in analyzing individual works of painting, sculpture, and architecture created by each Buddhist tradition in different part of Asia.
Identify regional variances, trans-regional diffusions, inter-regional commonalities, and historical transformations among cultures of the pan-Buddhist world.
Fostering familiarity with the philosophical tenets of Buddhism and their historical development.
Develop skills in writing academic essays and in delivering public speech.

courses.description: (UGEC3309 is double-coded with FAAS3113.) This course—an interdisciplinary study of art history, archaeology, anthropology, and religious studies among others—introduces the visual and material culture of the Korean peninsula and its adjacent regions from the Neolithic Age to the early twentieth century CE by surveying major historic monuments and excavated artifacts. Major topics include (1) state formation, (2) tombs and mortuary furnishings, (3) the influx of Buddhism and its successful development, (4) capitals and provinces, (5) elite culture of the court, aristocrats, and the literati, (6) ceramics and lacquerware, and (7) trans-regional interaction, especially, with China and Japan.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Animals, Culture and Modern Society
courses.description: (UGEC3481 is double-coded with CURE3003.)  How do we understand and connect to animal kingdom?How do human-animal connections shape modern culture and society?How do cultural studies and humanities expand our scope on animal and nature?Culture is ordinary, in Raymond William’s saying, but the ordinariness is merely treated as a reflection of human everyday life. Although cultural studies has sustained concern on everyday life with mass production, consumerism, sexism, racism and postmodernism, the discipline always lags behind the concern of nature and animal species. As the issues of animal abuse, environmental protection, factory farming, animal protection policy and law-making, as well as media various portrayals being the hot topics of our (post)modern world, the study of animal with the perspective of cultural studies and other humanity disciplines can explore the possibilities of better human-animal relationship. This course is designed with an empathic concern of other-than-human animals. By exploring different issues of human and animals’ life, this course looks for a harmonious balance of nature and modern culture.This course focuses on three areas, through which we can explore the different aspects of animal and cultural studies. These areas are:A. Entering Jurassic Park – Remaking Animals in Leisure (Lecture A1-A4)B. Attacking Godzilla – Representing Animals in Media (Lecture B1-B4)C. Finding Nemo – Revitalizing Animals in the City  (Lecture C1-C4)Each area covers a set of animal issue discussion. Area A, apart from theorizing animal with cultural studies, tackles the basic animal issues: pet-nurturing, zoo-building, forest-sustaining and tourism. This is to provide a foundation for understanding animals with a critical reflection of everyday life. Area B, set with the concern of media, discusses issues of animal representation in cartoon, cinema, literature and journalism. This is to read how animals would be represented and how this affects human understanding and related policy-making. A screening will be run after Lecture Area B. This is to provide an alternative understanding of animal representation in popular media. Area C further deals with the matters of animal-city relationship in seeing how dogs and cats, cattle and swine, and fishes and dolphins are (mal)treated in the street, the farm and the sea respectively. This is to end the course with a leading thought of perfect balance of nature and modernity; and more queries of human-animal relationship will be raised for contemplation.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Film and Cultural Politics in Southeast Asia
courses.description: (UGEC3482 is double-coded with CURE3033.) This course is a survey of Southeast Asian cinema read against the backdrop of its distinct historical, political, ecological, and cultural conditions. Initially a Cold War construct comprising Singapore, Indonesia, Thailand, the Philippines, Vietnam, Malaysia, Cambodia, Brunei, Laos, and Timor-Leste, the term ‘Southeast Asia’ has come to refer to a highly complex and pluralistic region of over 660 million people, 25,000 islands, and 150 ethnolinguistic communities. With its national identities formed from the encounter with and struggle against American, British, French, Dutch, Hispanic, Indian, Japanese, and Chinese influence, Southeast Asia’s movies have served as venues for propaganda and resistance. This course looks at how the remediations of different genres such as noir, melodrama, western, and sci-fi tackle controversial issues of gender, race, religion, poverty, migration, and the environment. Instead of smoothening the continuity of official historical narratives, it uncovers how documentaries, epics, and horror reexamine the trauma of past colonization, authoritarianism, and violence. To conclude, the course explores how television serials, anthology films, and online databases trace nascent cross-border and intra-regional communities beyond the limits of sovereignty.

courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:
To become acquainted with the key filmmakers, works, themes, and issues in Southeast Asian cinema
To explain how film and media representations visualize and problematize the distinct social, economic, political, and historical conditions of diverse Southeast Asian cultures
To apply a comparative, transnational lens to examine film and media representations that illustrate how these diverse Southeast Asian cultures have become articulated in Hong Kong
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Visualizing Southeast Asia
How do scholars, filmmakers, and artists imagine Southeast Asia?
Week 2: Inter-Orientalism
How have commercial movies, television shows, and tourism campaigns visualized the landscapes and populations of Southeast Asia with an orientalist gaze?
Week 3: Remediating Genres
How does Southeast Asian cinema reinvent the generic conventions of Western, spy, martial arts, and science fiction films?
Week 4: Crime Noir and Slum Voyeurism
How do film noir, crime thrillers, and poverty porn characterize the settings of Southeast Asian megalopolises with destitution, squalor, and violence?
Week 5: Racial Border-Crossings
How does Southeast Asian cinema ruminate on issues of race and multiculturalism?
Week 6: Migrant Labor Mobilities
How do melodramas and documentaries spotlight the victimization of migrant workers?
Week 7: Ghosts, Monsters, and Spiritualities
How do ghost, monster, and horror movies explore the link between spirituality and development?
Week 8: Historical Memory
How do period epics and experimental films construct and reexamine historical representations?
Week 9: Documentary Trauma
How do reflexive documentaries explore the trauma of political violence in Southeast Asia?
Week 10: Stardom
How have popular movie stars in Southeast Asia shaped social identity?
Week 11: Theaters and Spaces
How do cinema and historiography represent the spaces of film distribution and exhibition?
Week 12: Seriality and Regionalism
How do omnibus films, serial dramas, and digital artworks imagine a pan-regional community?
Week 13: Field trip to sites in Hong Kong with historical or cultural significance to Southeast Asia
Possible destinations include the Dr. Sun Yat-sen Museum, Kowloon City, and Filipinas Heritage Trail.
Week 14: Presentation and submission of paper
As a synthesis of the class materials and discussions for the entire semester, the final paper will examine the film and media culture of Southeast Asia in Hong Kong. Students can opt to work on the final paper individually, in pairs, or in groups. Possible topics include how Vietnamese boat people, Filipino and Indonesian domestic workers, Burmese Buddhist monks, or Kowloon City’s Thai community are visualized in Hong Kong’s cinema, news, advertising, and social media.

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: Korean Media and Popular Culture
courses.description: (UGEC3483 is double-coded with CURE3034.)This course aims to introduce Korean society and culture through Korean Popular Culture in relation to media and cultural studies scholarship and its socio-cultural contexts. In particular, we will examine the meaning of media and culture and its social changes in contemporary Korea through exploring various emerging trends and cultural studies as methodological tool within modern and contemporary Korean issues. Global popularity of Korean popular culture and the transnational Hallyu (Korean Wave) boom continue to percolate beyond Asia and inspire various critical questions regarding trans-nationalism, cultural imperialism and musical authenticity and hybridity. The course readings engage wide range of various issues and arguments of media and cultural studies scholarship as methodological tools; such as cultural representation, meaning of hegemony, cultural industry/economy and globalism of media, post colonialism, audience of mass media and fandom culture, gender and queer issues, and then further focus on the specific context of Korean popular culture including the pivotal notions of colonial modernity, Japanese imperialism, cultural hegemony in colonial Korea, meaning of Americanization, issues of popular memory and decolonization discourses, nationalism and globalization and Korean Wave, body/gender/sexuality / LGBTQ issue in Korean Media and Popular culture, cyber culture and internet memes, transnationalism and diaspora issues and its aftermath. We actively discuss various audio-visual artifacts including Korean news, music video, films, TV dramas, and pop music in each class in order to understand better the texts and contexts within the historical and sociocultural paradigm of recent sociology, media/communication studies scholarship.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGEC3483 is double-coded with CURE3034. 
Not for Cultural Studies; Public Humanities; Religious Studies Majors; and students who have taken CURE3034. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
To
recognize various conceptual ideas and critical thinking on comprehensive Korean media and popular culture and major issues and historical incidents in relation to modernity, coloniality, Americanisation/Americanism, globalization in Korean popular culture.
To explain how Korean media and popular culture and its cultural representation and industrial system reflect and resonate with the various socio-economic, political, colonial/postcolonial conditions of globalized Korean popular culture
To appropriate glocal and transnational critical perspectives to examine various Korean media and popular culture and its cultural representations that illustrate how these diverse Korean media and popular culture have become articulated in the global context

courses.subject: UGEC
courses.title: International Relations in Southeast Asia
courses.description: (UGEC3546 is double-coded with GLSD3405.)  This course aims to elevate students' understanding of Southeast Asia by examining the dynamics of interaction between nation-states, regional organizations, and non-state actors in Southeast Asia under the context of Globalization. After looking into the history, interests, strategic concerns, and senses of vulnerability shared among these actors, students are encouraged to think critically about the significance of this oft-overlooked region in the study of world politics. Hence, this course stresses analytical skills instead of hard facts about the region. Topics of the course include: 1) Definition of Southeast Asia and its history; 2) Basic International Relations Theories; 3) Actors in Contemporary Southeast Asia International Politics; 4) Evolution of ASEAN and regionalism in the World Politics; 5) Economic development of Southeast Asia and; 6) Regional Security in Southeast Asia.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students are expected to demonstrate abilities to:
1) Apply different IR theories to account for the dynamics of international relations in Southeast Asia
2) Describe the significance of different actors in Southeast Asia
3) Describe the evolution of the concept of "Southeast Asia"
4) Examine the contemporary security and economic relations among and between ASEAN member-states and other actors
5) Rethink critically the importance of Southeast Asia in the global arena
